QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRADE RELATIONS WITH THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. In view of the serious damage which United States agricultural subsidies are doing to Australia's agricultural exporters and the potential for our traditional markets in the Middle East to be undermined, I ask the Prime Minister whether he is prepared to support our proposal for a senior Australian bipartisan delegation to visit the United States to emphasise the unified Australian position on this issue to senior Administration officials and to the leadership in Congress. Is he prepared to join with me in leading such a delegation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me preface my direct answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question by saying that we are obviously most concerned about the rural recession in Australia. I would like to put on record the fact that yesterday the members of the structural adjustment committee and I had a most constructive meeting with representatives of the National Farmers Federation (NFF) and the Grains Council of Australia in which those gentlemen put forward, I think in a very deliberate and constructive manner, an outline of the depths of the problems confronting Australia's rural community. Within that presentation, they certainly put a lot of emphasis upon the considerable difficulties that have been created for Australia's very efficient rural producers by the actions of the European Community and the United States. In particular, I refer to the most recent subsidy war between the European Community and the United States having caused wheat prices to plummet.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable members will recall, my colleague the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development made very clear yesterday the depth of our concerns about the United States export enhancement program, which the Administration unfortunately is proposing to expand in 1991-92. I think all honourable members should know that the NFF conveyed to us that the feeling in the Australian rural community is one of very, very deep contempt for and concern about the actions of the United States. Those actions are putting very great strains, as far as those NFF members are concerned, upon their perception of the alliance relationship. To be fair to them, they made it quite clear that they support the Government and the shared bipartisan position in Australia in regard to the Gulf, but they quite honestly have conveyed to me that a continuation of these activities by the United States will put an almost unbearable strain, as far as their membership is concerned, upon their capacity to sustain that position.

This morning, the Leader of the National Party of Australia wrote to me suggesting that we send a bipartisan mission to the United States. So the initiative in writing, I might say, came from the Leader of the National Party. It is all right him shaking his head, but I am giving him the credit where he deserves it. He wrote to me; it was he who wrote. The Leader of the Opposition, by contrast, put out a press release.

In that regard, I take much more seriously the approach of the Leader of the National Party, who actually wrote on this matter rather than conduct the matter by press release. I appreciate the constructive manner in which the Leader of the National Party approached this, and now that the Leader of the Opposition has raised the matter I concede that he is quite serious about this matter. We will have to take into account the important issue of timing, which I think those opposite will appreciate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's your standard answer.
—We get this thoughtless, pathetic interjection-`That's a standard answer'. If the honourable member would contain himself and listen to what I have to say, he might be satisfied.
—You always give that answer.
—The honourable member for Mitchell will cease interjecting.
—You always give that answer.
—I warn the member for Mitchell.

—The honourable member opposite does himself no good and certainly gives no support to the Leader of the National Party by his thoughtless interjection. As I was saying, it was a matter of timing. The interests of those on the other side of the House are better served by the Leader of the National Party than by the thoughtless interjection of the honourable member opposite. It would be better if he kept quiet.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Leader of the National Party has recognised, there is an important issue of timing. I do not say this in rejection of the proposition. I am simply saying, as the Leader of the National Party will agree, that there is an important issue of timing involved in this. It needs to be considered in detail to ensure that such a mission will have the maximum impact. As the Leader of the National Party is nodding his acquiescence, I am sure he agrees. If we are going to do this, it ought to have maximum impact. In particular, if we are going to have this mission it would need to be timed for when the export enhancement program was due to be considered by Congress and obviously when key players in the Congress were available.
Let me conclude by saying that I appreciate the sense in which the proposition has been put forward and I will give it serious consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Treasurer concerns the supervision of financial institutions. Is the Treasurer aware of remarks made today by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia detailing the bank's responsibilities in the prudential supervision of financial institutions? What are the Government's intentions in respect of the remarks of the Reserve Bank Governor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My intentions are only to agree with him. The Governor of the Reserve Bank made some remarks, I might say very pointedly, to critics of the Reserve Bank supervisory regime and its supervision. I do not ascribe to the Reserve Bank Governor remarks pointed at the Opposition, though pointed they are. The Governor said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Reserve Bank supervisory role in relation to the banks has drawn some criticism recently. This has been ill-informed to the extent that it seeks to measure our supervisory performance in terms of the bad debt performance and losses of banks. That is to miss the main point, namely, that it is not the role of the Reserve Bank to stop banks from writing bad loans and suffering losses. Rather, the aim is to minimise the likelihood that such bad loans or losses will put a bank's viability or its depositors' funds at risk. The bank's primary concerns are to preserve the stability of the financial system as a whole and to protect, but not guarantee, bank deposits. The stability of the financial system is not in question and no bank depositor has lost any money.
He went on to say:
The main responsibility for the prudent conduct of a bank's operations must rest with the board and management of that bank.
This is a very damning indictment of the Opposition's criticisms. The Governor said:
This has been ill-informed to the extent that it seeks to measure our supervisory performance in terms of the bad debt performance and losses of banks.

Earlier this week the shadow Treasurer asked me to discipline the Reserve Bank for its supervisory role whereas the Governor says quite specifically that that view-that is, seeking me to discipline it-was ill-informed to the extent that it seeks to measure the supervisory performance of the bank in terms of bad debt performance and losses of other banks. In other words, it is the Governor politely putting down the Opposition's criticism, which is based falsely on the premise that bad debt performance and losses of a bank are the responsibility of the Reserve Bank, which he says is an ill-informed comment. He said that it misses the main point, and the main point is the point I have been making to the Opposition now repeatedly for days, namely, that it is not the role of the Reserve Bank to stop banks from writing bad loans. It cannot be the role of the Reserve Bank--

TALK.START.PARA: —A straw man!

—A straw man! Do not be so absurd. What an idiotic comment from the shadow Treasurer-`It is a straw man'. The Governor said that it is not the Reserve Bank's role to stop banks from writing bad loans. There are stacks of bad loans that have been written out there. The shadow Treasurer has tried to ascribe that as part of the Reserve Bank's responsibility, which clearly it is not.

ANSWER.PARA: Rather, the aim is to minimise the likelihood, the Governor says, that such bad losses or loans will put a bank's viability or its depositors' funds at risk. That is the point I made yesterday: not one dollar of a depositor's deposit has been lost in the eight years this Government has been in office. That is the test of the system operating, and that is why the Governor makes it quite clear. He said:
The bank's primary concerns are to preserve the stability of the financial system as a whole and to protect, but not guarantee, bank deposits.
The stability of the financial system is not in question. No bank depositor has lost any money.
I could not think of a more pithy, more timely condemnation of the ill-founded criticism of the Opposition than that which is contained in this note.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the very pithy and timely remarks also to be found in the speech of the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia:

QUESTION.PARA: State Banks have undertaken voluntarily to comply with the Bank's prudential requirements. For practical purposes the Bank's day-to-day supervision makes no distinction between State banks and Banking Act banks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never claimed that-never. The Governor goes on at pains to say why a State bank is not part-and the Prime Minister has marked it for me:

ANSWER.PARA: The Reserve Bank does not, however, have powers in respect of State banks that it could exercise if a Banking Act bank were in similar difficulties.

He says:

In other words, it is clearly not a Banking Act bank. But I have always said that it has been informally supervised. To use the expression I have used: it has voluntarily complied with the Reserve Bank's liquidity guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it is not part of your empire.
—Do not try to pretend there is any comfort for the Opposition in this speech. It is an utter bucketing of the Opposition.

—Has the Minister for Transport and Communications received a report from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) regarding a review of its coverage of the Gulf war in response to criticisms by Gerard Henderson and a number of other prominent Australians? Is the Minister satisfied with the outcome of the inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all honourable members would be delighted to learn that the result of that inquiry by the ABC into the question of bias in the ABC cleared the ABC of any substantial wrongdoing in regard to the issue of bias. There is to some extent a degree of legitimate levity around the chamber. May I point out, however, that there are one or two elements of that inquiry that did acknowledge that there were elements of the handling of the issues relating to the Gulf war which could have been done better, including one report-which was of very substantial concern to me-related to the alleged collision of an Australian warship in the Gulf that went through substantially unsubstantiated. I think it does have to be said that the ABC has provided a comprehensive and in many cases an excellent news coverage of the Gulf war, and we in our community have all benefited from that.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite evident that these sorts of studies, which are the only means that are currently to hand to investigate whether or not there is any wrongdoing, any bias or any inadequacy in ABC reporting, simply cannot keep continuing to be done by the ABC and no-one else. It does the ABC no good to have itself placed in that position. It is unique amongst Australian broadcasters in that regard. All other broadcasters-the public broadcasters as well as the commercial broadcasters-are obliged to submit themselves to an inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) when a citizen or group of citizens raises a complaint as to bias. I think at the moment-I could be wrong-there is a Tribunal hearing going on in relation to standards in current affairs programs and commercial broadcasters. That situation ought not to persist for any substantial length of time in the future.

As a result of that the Government is currently considering what ought to be the means by which the ABC becomes more publicly accountable. There are basically two options. One option is to contemplate the establishment of an independent operation that directly considers these complaints as they come in. It would exist on its own account and would be the forum by which the ABC would be rendered accountable. In various forms that has some support among ABC senior management. Then there is the option of putting the ABC under the ABT like any other commercial broadcaster.

The Government will consider those two options. It seems to me that either would produce the situation that most would desire in terms of public accountability for the national broadcaster. We would expect to bring down a decision on that in the next month or two.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I also refer the Treasurer to the speech given by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia today in which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: If we were to become aware of a problem in a State bank, we would press the management and/or board to clarify the nature and extent of the difficulty and to put in place strategies to maintain the viability of the bank, protect its depositors and deal with the problem.
Has the Treasurer yet determined whether the Reserve Bank made such inquiries and put in place such strategies with the State Bank of South Australia within the last 12 months? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I wish to say about this matter is what I said yesterday when referring to the Reserve Bank's relationship with any of the State banks. The Governor also mentioned it in his speech when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Banks owned by the State governments are not subject to the Banking Act since the Constitution precludes the Commonwealth from legislating over State banking.
He goes on to say:
The Reserve Bank has no statutory power to supervise State banks although State banks have undertaken voluntarily to comply with the banks' prudential requirements.

Voluntary compliance is precisely the term that I have been using during the last week or so. If the Reserve Bank is aware of a problem the first thing it wishes to do is to have a bank comply with the liquidity ratios which other banks are required to observe, and to see that there is loss provisioning and that those loss provisions are adequate.

I do not know whether the last time the bank had any contact with the State Bank of South Australia in terms of loss provisioning it had an idea of the asset quality which it has an idea of now. But the fact of the matter is that that accounting of the provisioning for losses coming from the collateral security of the loans and the asset quality backing them have come from the methodology employed by its owners through J.P. Morgan. It is on that basis that it believes that many of the loans will impact upon the capital of the bank to the tune of, from memory, $970m. The State Government has said that it will make that deficiency good, in which case the ratios again will be observed-more than observed-and the loss provisioning will be adequate.

The Reserve Bank can only enjoin bank boards to adequately provision for losses in these circumstances, but the accounting for those losses was undertaken by the management, by the Government. That occurred also in Victoria when the State Bank of Victoria approached the Government of Victoria, and the Premier of Victoria wrote to the Reserve Bank saying that the Government of Victoria would indemnify the State Bank for $500m, which it did, from memory, in late 1989 or early 1990. The same thing has happened with the State Bank of South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Over the last several days reports have canvassed a health proposal which could eliminate Medicare and replace it with a private health insurance scheme to be supplemented by a voucher scheme for pensioners and the disadvantaged. Can the Minister inform the House of some of the consequences of such a change?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The proposal is the latest in a series of social policy and health ideas floated by the Leader of the Opposition in the last few months. The proposal, of course, must create doubt and uncertainty in the minds of all Australians, who, under Medicare, have unquestioned entitlement to health care regardless of their financial status or how old or sick they are.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed scheme, which appears to have been designed by the New Right think-tank called the Centre for Independent Studies, throws this entitlement to the wind. Indeed, the people of Australia will have no choice but to take out private insurance. Those who are deemed not to be able to afford their own insurance-namely, low income earners and pensioners-will be handed out government vouchers equal to the cost of basic health insurance. It seems that vouchers would be issued on the basis of some kind of sliding scale of disadvantage.

Honourable members probably recall that in the last Parliament we heard a great deal about poverty traps from the Opposition; apparently the Opposition is considering creating what one might describe as the supreme poverty trap. What is emerging as the Opposition's intention is a somewhat insidious agenda-and I think this was confirmed by spokesmen in interviews this morning-firstly, to move towards fully privatised health services, including hospitals, and, secondly, to move towards the deregulation of the health insurance industry.

Of course, these ambitions assume an environment of competition in the marketplace. It is obvious to any observer of the American health system, for example, that the dominance of market driven forces in that country during the 1980s certainly did not lead to any diminution of costs and may have lead to the escalation of costs. The United States, with a predominantly private system, is spending something of the order of 11.2 per cent of gross domestic product on health, whereas Australia spends only 8.1 per cent.

The significant cost in any free market system is the overhead component of health insurance, that share which is diverted away from providers and hospitals to pay for administration of the paper flow. The administrative cost of private health insurance in Australia averages about 12.7 per cent. If we compare this with Medicare, we can see an extraordinary difference. In its 1989-90 annual report, the Health Insurance Commission reported that a little over 4 per cent was spent on administrative expenses. The reason for this marked difference is that under a universal scheme like Medicare everyone is eligible for equal benefits. No marketing is necessary, no-one has to be assessed against the risk of insuring himself or herself and no-one misses out; it is a universal scheme.

Even worse than these cost problems, though, are inequities in the treatment of sick people, to which I referred yesterday. Once again, the poor and disadvantaged will have to become the recipients of a hand-out in the form of a voucher, which will only pay for basic health insurance. In what is expected to be a predominantly private system, basic cover will not be adequate for a comprehensive range of services. On any sliding scale, as I have suggested, the creation of a poverty trap is unavoidable.

One might ask what will happen to those in the older age group who are still earning and suffer an illness. There will not be any voucher for them. They will have to rely on the private market. Again one must ask a question about the effect of the replacement of the community rating system in which everyone pays the same rate with a risk rating system, whereby those who are unfortunate enough to be sick will be forced to pay either through higher insurance or out of their own pocket if their risk prohibits insurance cover.

It is extraordinary that the Opposition would take a scheme which is supported by 71 per cent of the Australian population, a scheme which supports a hospital system in which 85 per cent of recent users claim satisfaction with the treatment that they are receiving, and in fact dump it for an untested New Right think-tank idea of vouchers which effectively would free up-not restrain-costs in terms of the Australian health system. According to sources, the Opposition is not suggesting less expenditure in terms of health, but somewhere between $3 billion and $4 billion of additional expenditure to ensure those who are most disadvantaged, chronically ill or most at risk do not have the certainty of universal health insurance and of the current system.

—One can understand that ideas might be floated; what one cannot understand is a Leader of the Opposition who fails to stand up and publicly detail a proposed system or a shadow spokesperson who, appearing on the media this morning, essentially only prevaricated, pointed to the fact that there are some fundamental problems but failed either to defend the existing system or to say anything at all substantial about where he is going.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget is providing automatic support to cushion the recession and helps protect those most vulnerable. That is coming by way of lower tax receipts and higher outlays which, as I say, is cushioning the recession as the savings of the Commonwealth decline but as the savings of the private sector naturally increase.

ANSWER.PARA: Fiscal policy under this Government is set in the longer term, that is, a longer term framework where in a stronger economy the surplus continues to grow because the structural grip on outlays is now quite profound after years of outlays management by this Government and where, as I say, lower Commonwealth savings now are offset by higher cyclical savings by the private sector.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received letters from the honourable members for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) and Gilmore (Mr Sharp) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by standing order 107, I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important; that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Perth, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The uncertainty caused to all Australians by the Opposition proposal to abolish Medicare and replace it with a voucher system of medical insurance.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic under discussion today is the voucher system for medical insurance which has been proposed by the Opposition. What we have once again from the Opposition is poor policy making, yesterday's solutions, policy that has not been thought through and the honourable member for Wentworth, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), once again making policy on the run, throwing ideas around and leaving the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), to defend his position.

SPEECH.PARA: The solution proposed by the shadow spokesman on the other side of the House is a seminar in which `we are going to return to Thredbo and we are going to sit around brainstorming and we will come up with a policy'. One of the Opposition's best and favoured prescriptions is the voucher system.

Who do we have on the brains trust? Who do we have as part of the policy group in the Opposition? We have a trio of former failed shadow Ministers. We have the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) who is, I must say, a thoughtful man. He came up with some good ideas when he was shadow spokesman but unfortunately every time the leadership changed he found it impossible to get a leader who would accept his views.

The honourable member for Mackellar was followed by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who came up with a policy. He had a couple of tries. His policy failed basically because, as he admitted himself, it meant that the wealthy and the well would have to pay more. That, of course, was unacceptable for the Liberal Party. Indeed, he now languishes on the back bench. Some have said that the reason for this is that he did not go to the right school. Others have suggested that it is because he does not talk properly. We know that the reason he is on the back bench is because of his failed health policy which was unacceptable to the Liberal Party.

Then along came the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). He had a policy, or so he said; he told us he had a policy. We waited and we waited and then, in February of last year, he assured our re-election by advocating maintaining Medicare and, of course, fiddling with the edges. Now we find the honourable member for Lowe grappling with the same problem.

After eight years the Opposition is still unable to throw off the ideological baggage. It is still unable to say that Medicare is popular and it has been successful. We are not denying that there are some problems with Medicare. We are suggesting that in ethos, in efficiency, in fairness and in quality and access in the real world Medicare has delivered the goods.

Honourable members do not have to take my word for it. Allow me to quote from Professor Stuart Altman, a health economist and adviser to Congress in the Reagan Administration, hardly a purveyor of Labor Party philosophy. When he was talking about health care policy after investigating our system in Australia he said that the problem in the United States had been that they were unwilling to make difficult decisions about health care and were unwilling to make political decisions which maintained and contained costs. He said:
If you want an exciting, well-functioning health care system stay in Australia.

That is what we have, and that is why we should stay here. Why on earth would people want to change a system that works, is popular and is efficient? Would somebody do it if it was unfair? If it was unfair, I think that, yes, somebody would look at it. But we have a basic community rating principle which says that the burden of health care is shared by the whole community. That is something that provides for universal coverage, coverage of all. In today's Herald-Sun, an article by Sue Dunlevy stated:
Liberal opponents of the scheme said it could also leave many people without health insurance . . .
Those Liberal opponents, of course, are members of the health policy committee of the Opposition; they are uncertain about the effects of this scheme and they are concerned about it.

We have a fair system, but it must be unpopular, because the Opposition wants to change it. But the Health Insurance Commission's most recent survey showed that Medicare is unprecedentedly popular. As many as 71 per cent of those surveyed who have used Medicare suggest that they are very satisfied with the service they have been getting. Opposition to Medicare is at an all time low. Only 22 per cent of the population oppose it and even amongst those with private health insurance, 60 per cent of people support Medicare.

So we find that Medicare is something that is popular. It is popular because people find it affordable, they understand it and they know how it works. This is especially so for people who have had use of the service. As the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) mentioned in Question Time today, 85 per cent of people who have used the service support it and believe that the system has served them well.

So why is the Opposition wanting to change the system? It must be that it considers the system to be inefficient. But if we look at the efficiency of the system, we find overwhelmingly that the Health Insurance Commission's costs for administration are about a third of those of private health funds. It is an efficient system; it is efficient for those who are providers and it is efficient for patients who want to be paid. It is efficient in every way. The efficiency of the system is beyond question, and the Opposition does not question that. The Opposition must have some belief that there is in the market a better way of doing it. But-and it is important that people understand this-once there is health insurance for providing health care, there is no longer a perfect market. As long as that is the case, it needs to be understood that efficiency cannot be determined in that way. The Opposition is advocating not the absence of health insurance but that everybody takes out private health insurance. As soon and as long as we have that in the health system, we no longer have a perfect market.

It needs to be understood that it is not the consumers who make all the choices when it comes to spending in health care; providers make all the choices. All of the costs that are involved in providing medical services are a result of decisions made by providers. It is important that that be understood. Even Adam Smith, when he talked about his perfect market, said that what is necessary to have a perfect market is perfect knowledge. There is no way in which consumers understand or can know what a good doctor is and what an appropriate service is, so in this area of health care it is not the case that the market can operate in that way.

Perhaps overseas experience indicates that the system is more efficient where the market operates. As I have already indicated, there is a huge indictment of what happens in the United States by medical professionals and by any objective observer. Jimmy Carter, former President of the United States said:

Although American medical skill is amongst the best in the world we have an abominable system of delivery of health care-gross inequities towards the poor, particularly the working poor, and profiteering by many hospitals and some medical doctors who prey on the vulnerability of the ill.

The United States has an inefficient system. It spends nearly 12 per cent of gross domestic product on delivering health care-we spent 8.1 per cent in this country-and the service does not provide universal coverage, fairness or equity. The commonest cause of bankruptcy in the United States is ill health. Some 37 million people in the United States have no health insurance cover. When one looks at the costs of delivering health care in that country, one cannot suggest for a moment that the free market, as it operates there-unfettered medical entrepreneurship as it operates there-is the answer.

One would say, `Okay, we need to cut costs; we understand that. Maybe we should look at another system'. Maybe we should look at the proposals pursued by the Thatcher Government. In the United Kingdom the national health scheme has been held intact by the Thatcher Government. Among all the other changes that have been brought into the system in that country, the national health scheme has been held intact.

Recently it decided to review the scheme with a view to privatisation and change, but the conclusion of an all-party social services committee was that there would be no benefits. We find in the United Kingdom the rationing of services beyond anything that we can understand in this country. If a person is over the age of 55, he is not eligible for dialysis in the United Kingdom. If he is over the age of 65, he can forget about his hip transplant because that is not a possibility. That is the sort of rationing that is necessary in other countries to contain costs.

We understand that there are difficulties in providing a service for everybody. It is possible and feasible to provide a fantastic service that covers everyone in the country, but what is the cost-another $5 billion, $6 billion or $7 billion? If Opposition members are willing to make that sort of allocation, they should stand up and say so and not float proposals such as this, which will effectively change the way in which health care is delivered, making it something which the wealthy and the well will get more easily while the sick have to pay more. That is what is being advocated by the Opposition in this proposal.

Families and individuals will receive vouchers to put towards the cost of private health insurance. They will get basic private health insurance for their vouchers. What will be the premium? We do not know. What will be basic cover? We do not know. But we understand that that is how it will operate. If it is to operate in that way, there can no longer be a community rating principle applied.

A 50-year-old working man, who obviously is in a higher risk category than a 20-year-old, will have a much higher premium because the voucher system will not operate once he earns above a particular amount. An 80-year-old pensioner would be covered completely by the voucher system, but that cover would be funded by the Government. The cost to the Government is going to be massive because the risk premium on an 80-year-old pensioner is huge. For an 80-year-old person who just falls outside the pension system-and many of these people are not wealthy-the premium would be sky high.

How on earth can there be any equity in the system? If the community rating principle is removed, the well and wealthy will be better off and the sick will have to pay more. It is against this principle that we will fight. We hope that the Opposition will go to the next election carrying such a proposal. Let us look at the total costs. The Opposition must be pursuing this policy because of a saving, but a quote from the Herald-Sun reveals the following:

. . . Opposition sources yesterday disclosed early estimates by the party had shown the voucher health insurance system could add to federal health costs by as much as $1 billion, which would threaten Dr Hewson's stated aim of cutting government spending.

We have here a policy which is supposed to be better for everybody, which is going to cost more and yet which is consistent with saving money. We cannot find any rationale for that. We find that those people who are unsure of their health-the sick, the aged or those who are presently supported by the system which covers them-will have uncertainty. For those who are wealthy, well off, and can afford to pay there will be a better situation. There will be increases in numbers of people uninsured. Opponents of the system in the Opposition have already indicated their concern about that.

We will find no control over the price of services, unfettered entrepreneurial activity in the medical area and something else that the Opposition has been suggesting for a while-that is, the removal of health care into the social security area. That might be possible because social security is going to be doled out by Touche Ross and Co. or by the soup kitchen, according to the proposals of the honourable member for Wentworth.

We are not suggesting that Medicare is perfect; we never have. I have stood up in this place many times and suggested ways in which we could improve it. Incentives need to be provided for preventative health care and for doctors to see patients less. Indeed, the use of day surgery and other changes are important. But we do not need to let loose the endless agenda of the medical profession.

As the former Senator Peter Baume said, health care delivery has only a marginal effect on health outcome. So many other factors are important-diet, lifestyle, poverty, education, housing, welfare, employment and child-care. All of these things are important determinants of health in the population in general.

What the Government is pursuing, and what this Minister is pursuing, is a national health strategy which integrates all of those things. That is a sensible solution to add to a system that works effectively now. We have a system which is by any measure efficient. It is popular in an unprecedented way. It is fair, it is simple and it is accepted and understood by people. It is sheer lunacy for us in this place to consider returning to an unfair system-one with uncertainties in it, one that is more costly and one that is really born of ideological fantasy.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least for once we have managed to wake up the dormouse of Perth. That is something for a start. The decay in capital infrastructure resulting from a severe shortfall in capital investment, particularly in the public hospital system, threatens to impair the standard of service delivery.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) actually uttered words to the effect that if one did not charge a fee for a service, of course it would be overused. I agree with that absolutely and entirely, and I am sure my colleagues here do. There has to be a price signal in there.

If it is right for the Government to issue a price signal for pharmaceuticals, why is it not right for the Government to issue a price signal for medical items? If the Government were consistent, it would say, `We are going to charge $2.50 for every pharmaceutical item and we will charge, say, $2.50 for any visit to the doctor'. It has not done that. It is just pure hypocrisy for the Government to have a diversified approach such as this.

I understand that on Thursday the Minister will release a report from the Macklin Committee. One of the issues in that is over-servicing by GPs. I understand the Government will say that the main problem with over-servicing is in the GP area. If the reports emanating out of the Minister's office are accurate, he will say that we need to change the question of fee-for-service for GPs into some other system. What will he do? He will not put on a capitation fee. He will not go the United Kingdom way; he has just said how bad it is. Presumably he will not go into the question of salaried GPs. I think that would be out of the question even for the Minister. I do not think that is really an option. Presumably he will move the health maintenance organisation way. HMO is when one decides to pay a doctor a certain amount to look after one's health care for a year. If one is not sick, of course, the doctor makes a profit; if one is very sick, the doctor makes a loss. So there are incentives there for doctors to cut costs-and, of course, to cut corners. It means that there is a more limited service available to those individuals in that system.

One of the ways in which costs are constrained overseas has been to use HMOs. The system is very effective. But they have to be used in competition with a higher cost private system. If people are not saving money in one system as compared with another, no-one will want a worse service. One has to have a private system which is viable and active at the same time. Sadly, this Government is doing its best to destroy the privately based system. It is basically saying that everybody has to be under the Government from cradle to grave.
This morning on a radio interview the Minister raised the question of rationing. He said:
. . . I think what you're talking about really is rationing-
this is about our range of proposals-
. . . like petrol rationing after the war.
Here is another quote from a news release:
Resources are limited, and rationing is unavoidable.

And the news release comes from?-Brian Howe, Minister for Community Services and Health. It is dated 12 December; it is not an outdated policy. The heading reads `Howe : Health Resources Must Be Rationed'. Talk about hypocrisy! He sits there with a straight face; he should hang his head in shame.

The Government has rationed the funds available to hospitals so that hospitals all around the country have a waiting list for people, particularly those waiting for elective surgery and especially for orthopaedic procedures and ophthalmic surgery-the things that affect the elderly in particular. The Minister is not quite in that age group yet, but he is getting there. I would look after it if I were him. He has done this in a very heartless fashion. Those people are the ones the Minister is supposed to be protecting; the Medicare system is supposed to look after the elderly and the underprivileged. They are the ones who are suffering. The rich and the fit can get by; they can actually go into private health funds because they have the money and they can bypass the queues. The people who suffer are the elderly and the disadvantaged, and they are the ones in particular who are faced with those problems. But the Minister does not worry about trivial details like that; he is just worried about saving a bit more money.

The Minister made some amazing comments about the voucher system. Let me say categorically that the Opposition is not espousing a voucher system; we are looking at a range of options of which that is one. We will have a range of discussions within and without the Party and reach a conclusion. The whole aim will be to reach a health system which has quality of care, which has good access to that care, which gives good, efficient delivery, and which is simple to understand. Quality, access and efficiency are the three things we should aim at, and three things which Medicare, sadly, does not have.

The Minister's idea of a voucher system was that people would get a voucher for a hip replacement, for a touch of pneumonia or for a quick pregnancy. The mind boggles that somebody could imagine such a system. The problem is, of course, that the patients who are suffering, waiting for their elective surgery, are cast aside by this Government. It says, `They only need elective surgery. What is elective surgery?'. Elective surgery is serious. It includes things like hip replacements. People have their hips replaced because they are in pain and cannot walk. It is no wonder that people want their hips replaced, yet the Government makes them wait up to 18 months. What about cataracts? People have their cataracts fixed because without getting them fixed they are blind. The Government does not care whether people are blind and are on waiting lists for months on end. There is no compassion at all. There is pain involved in elective surgery and it is crucial that the whole thing is fixed.

The hypocrisy of the Minister is astounding in terms of accusing us in regard to this proposal when in fact what we are doing is reviewing the system and looking at a range of options. What is the Government doing? It has instituted the Macklin review to look at a range of options. The difference, of course, is that the Government's review cost the taxpayers $2.2m and ours is free. We will give the Government the benefit of our advice whenever it wants it. There is no problem at all.

It is amazing that the Macklin review has been set up in this way, but I guess that, because the Cass Review of Social Security took the heat off the Minister in his previous portfolio, it is not surprising that he is doing the same thing. He is passing the buck to see whether somebody else can make the proposals and take the responsibility.

I do not want to get stuck into Miss Macklin, but I must say that we were all amazed that she was appointed. What are her credentials? Is she a well-known health economist? No. Is she involved in hospital administration? Does she have medical or nursing expertise? No. Her only credential is that she worked for a Labor Minister in Victoria. She did a good job; she looked after him and kept him out of trouble. I suppose the Minister is hoping that she will keep him out of trouble, too. The way he is going, I do not think he is going to be kept out of trouble. These people should have impartial views, not just run their particular bent according to their riding instructions.

There is a whole range of issues covered by this portfolio. I will touch on one of them. There are some really heart-rending tales about which I despair. One which is currently in the arena-and about which I have contacted the Minister's office, I think it is fair to say, at least a dozen times in the last two weeks, and he would not disagree with that-is Allowah Babies Hospital. Allowah Babies Hospital in Sydney looks after disabled kids, and they are grossly disabled. Most of them have cerebral palsy, there are spastic kids and most of them cannot even lift their heads off a chair. At Allowah Babies Hospital they are given the most intensive therapy one could imagine. They are looked after minute by minute. They are given intensive physiotherapy and stimulation. The hospital makes those kids into something approaching healthy human beings. What happens if the kids do not get that therapy? According to this Minister they should stay in nursing homes, lie on their backs, vegetate, get bed sores and eventually die of pneumonia.

That is this Government's approach. It has done it by introducing the acute care certification-and I will not go into the details of that. The Minister has no heart and no compassion. When the heat was on a few months ago he promised to fix one of those babies-just one. There are another 40 of them in that hospital-and he has not fixed the one, let alone the 40. He did that just to take the heat off himself. That hospital is under threat of closure because of this Minister. Those babies will be put into nursing homes to vegetate because the Minister does not care about them.

What about Lesley Milne? Lesley Milne is a young lady who has renal failure. All she wanted was to grow up and see her child grow up. She has a child named Brook, who is about 10 years old now. She had renal failure and she needed a drug called erythropoietin, which basically would have meant the difference between life and death for her. It took us on this side of the House to organise funding for that drug because this Minister said, and has only recently changed the decision, that erythropoietin should not be available-`It is too expensive. Don't worry about the fact it saves lives or allows mothers to see their children grow up. It is too expensive. We will make sure that it is blocked out'.

Why is it going to be blocked out? As Minister Staples said the other day, it is because the drug companies supplying information did not meet certain criteria. The information they did not supply was not asked for until 2 1/2 years after it was first asked for approval. The information asked for was: is the drug sterile? Is any drug ever sterile? Can honourable members believe that!

There is no compassion with this Minister. The Medicare system is falling down about his ears and there are a whole range of systems that need to be attacked-that need to be fixed. We have no particular bias against Medicare as such. We are happy to look at the whole issue, to look at a range of problems, and we will come to a solution which gives quality of care, access to that care and efficient delivery of that care.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue that is the subject of the matter of public importance which the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) perhaps would liked to have forgotten is the uncertainty caused to all Australians by the Opposition's proposal to abolish Medicare and replace it with a voucher system of medical insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the nervousness of the honourable member for Lowe, because he knows that 71 per cent of Australians support the Medicare system. He knows that the basic principles of Medicare-free universal health insurance, equity and the efficiency of the system-have been recognised by Australians. He also knows that Medicare has been a fact in Australia since 1983 and that rather than cause a blow-out in health costs, Medicare has stabilised those costs.

Compared for example to the United States, which has a much more private sector orientated health care system which costs something like 12 per cent of gross domestic product, Medicare in Australia costs approximately 8 per cent of GDP. So the system has worked, it has been popular and it has provided a basis for funding.

The Medicare levy was never intended to fully cover all health costs in Australia. Indeed, no health insurance scheme has ever done that and Medicare does not seek to do it, either. Australia's health care system on the whole has been very effective and has received a great deal of support from the Australian people.

The Opposition has begun to float policy proposals, which has led to a great deal of politicking among Opposition members. After all, membership of the Opposition committee concerned with developing alternative health policies is composed of former spokespersons and former Ministers who have very different approaches. For example, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) would like to reinstate the scheme for which he was responsible but which turned out to be very, very difficult to cost and which blew up on the eve of the last election.
The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) is a failed Minister for Health but is someone who would pretend to propose radical alternatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not on the committee.

—The honourable member for Mackellar is the supremo in terms of the whole area of social policy, but he always fails to articulate his views in the House on social policy. However, he has been put in that position, and we all know that the honourable member has what might be regarded as quite radical views. We are not opposed to people having radical or even reactionary views, but if they have such views they ought to be prepared to espouse them and debate them in Parliament. The Opposition's committee floated the idea of private insurance health vouchers. That idea was good enough for the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to float last week, and he walked into Parliament knowing that the issue is a very divisive one within his own party but failed to follow up the speech in which he floated this idea. In fact he downgraded the issue because it was not really a policy but an idea which he wanted to mention and which he did not expect anyone to take seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that members of the Opposition have to learn that when they have ideas, they will be taken seriously by the Government-because the task of governing this country is too important to allow oneself to be led into a situation where, in an election campaign atmosphere, one finds that one's whole proposition has been blown apart. There they were, members of the Opposition, only months ago facing an election with a policy scheme in mind which in fact blew apart within weeks of the election itself, and which they were effectively walking away from as they were running in the campaign.

If we have a scheme which is working, which is effective and which is supported by the Australian population, why would we want to replace it with an untested scheme which effectively has been developed by a right wing think-tank and which essentially does not appear to be particularly relevant to the problems that face the Australian health care system? Mr Speaker, I will tell you why some people might do that: because essentially they recognise that an approach that favours private health insurance, a scheme or an approach which effectively underwrites the cost of health in terms of the private sector-and ultimately which underwrites the incomes of doctors-is one that, in terms of the sectional interests that are so important to their parties, would curry a great deal of favour and, indeed, would be very popular.

That is essentially the problem of the conservative party-they are conservative in the sense not only that they have conservative ideology, but also that they are essentially-(Quorum formed) Essentially, the motive as far as the Opposition is concerned is a sectional motive. It is a motive which would destroy a public system of health insurance and replace it with emphasis on the private sector. As the honourable member for Lowe said this morning as he talked about the merits of the approach, he would allow them to take out private insurance, to take the voucher around to a number of health funds and choose the health insurance of their choice. That is, rather than a system that guarantees people access to the health care system, he wants to put people in the situation where they are choosing between health insurance funds, choosing between the inefficiency, the 12 per cent of their revenue spent on administration, as opposed to the 4 per cent; and he wants to have them going around looking at all the tables. He wants to get them confused, to get them out of the situation where they have any real security-because security is not one of the issues he is concerned about.

The honourable member for Lowe says, `Well, of course, Medicare itself is an option; that is something that we want to retain'. He says, `Let's try to fix up some of the problems of Medicare and encourage people to take out private insurance by implementing a range of financial incentives'. That is, he is saying, `Okay, look, we want to say Medicare is all right because we know that people think it is all right, but let's spend some money to provide incentives for people to get into health insurance'. Finally he says, `I think if you look at Logan's proposal and you give compensation to a significant number of people in terms of giving vouchers to those people, it certainly would cost more and how much it would cost would depend on who you gave the vouchers to'. That is, rather than restraining costs, what he is about is expanding the costs of the health system.

What does that mean? It ultimately means giving more money to doctors, more money to professionals and more money to those people who already do very well out of the health care system. Do not worry about the Australian people; do not worry about our aged; do not worry about our chronically ill; do not worry about our people with disabilities-essentially this is about distributing money to those who are wealthy and not concerning ourselves with equity.

TALK.START.PARA: —If this matter of public importance were not so serious, it would be an absolute joke. The joke is that the Government seeks to mask its own policy failures in the health portfolio by bringing on this matter in the personage of the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth). Obviously Government strategists have got together and decided that some form of attack is at least the best form of defence. They know-certainly the previous Minister for Health, now the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) knows, and I think it is slowly dawning on the current Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe)-that the serious deficiencies in the health portfolio under their administration are absolutely indefensible.

SPEECH.PARA: For as long as the Government fails to face up to the problems that beset Medicare, this health debate will be a very serious debate indeed. For as long as the Government fails to face up to its responsibilities, for as long as it fails to recognise the problems and set about intelligently and intellectually-something the current Minister prides himself on-facing up to those problems and trying to solve them, we are going to have thousands of Australians who are locked out of our public hospitals and denied the care and treatment where and when they need it. We are going to have tens if not hundreds of thousands of Australians continuing to languish in those queues in pain and suffering, and in many cases dying before they even get between the sheets.

The most significant thing the honourable member for Perth said in his contribution was this: Medicare is not perfect. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will tell you something-it is not perfect by a long shot. Nevertheless, as the Minister begins falteringly to come to grips with his responsibility, I perceive that he is starting to recognise some of its imperfections, because he himself has put on the agenda for debate the fact that Medicare is underfunded. It is grossly underfunded. Medicare has never raised more than a third of total Commonwealth medical and hospital outlays-never. It is underfunded in that sense, and the majority of the money comes out of other taxes paid into Consolidated Revenue.

We do not have to look at the financial side of the equation to see that Medicare is underfunded, because we can look at the supply side and at the demand side as well. We will see that as money is restricted there is only one thing that we can do, and that is ration services-and that is exactly what this Government is doing. Medicare presides over a system whereby our services and access to health care are being rationed. It is no different from the Eastern Bloc where people queue up for bread-and so many of our fellow citizens have to queue up for access to a hospital.

The Government takes great pride in saying that there is a cap, a ceiling, on the amount of expenditure, the proportion of gross domestic product, that we as a nation spend on health care. We can even reduce that if the Minister is prepared to preside over longer queues and have people waiting for a longer length of time. So the system is grossly underfunded and he has to face up to that problem. Until he does, the queues will persist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to spend more money?

—The current system is wasteful. I think the Minister is starting to come to grips with this as he tentatively skirts around the very sensitive issue on his side of politics of bulkbilling. He knows that bulkbilling is wasteful. There is a complete breakdown in the relationship between the provider and the user. For as long as there is a break in that relationship, the system will continue to be wasteful. The Minister has got to do something about restricting bulkbilling or the Government will continue to preside over gross waste.

SPEECH.PARA: Public hospital costs are far more expensive than they need be. The public hospital system is far more expensive than the private hospital system. One does not have to be an economist to evidence that. One has only to be a patient or visitor to any public hospital around Australia to see ample evidence of the waste and inefficiency. Our hospital system, public and private, across the board has to be made more efficient.

The greatest perversity that exists in the system in terms of waste is the hundreds of empty private hospital beds around the country. Medicare has presided over a situation where, as my colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) said in his excellent contribution, those privately insured in Australia have dropped as a percentage from above 70 per cent to below 45 per cent. The opportunity for people to go to private hospitals is shrinking as more and more people drop out of the private health system.

If the Minister is prepared to face up to those current problems, he should look at what the future holds for him, because the demand is going to get greater and the system is going to require more and more money. A few minutes ago the Minister said, by way of interjection, `More money, more money', in a taunting sense. The system will require more money, and there are three fundamental reasons for that. Firstly, we have an ageing demography. As people grow older and stay alive for longer, they are going to make greater demands on our health care system. Secondly, we have advancing technology in the medical field which keeps people alive for longer. This technology is incredibly expensive, especially in its early years of introduction. Whether the technology is therapeutic or whatever, if it keeps people alive for longer, they will be making greater demands on the health care system. Finally, there is the community expectation. As individuals, we would all want the very best that the world had to offer if it could keep us alive for longer or keep our lives healthier. We are certainly going to want the best for our mothers and fathers. Will the Minister preside over a situation where, Solomon-like, he will say, `You cannot have it, but you can, because we cannot afford it'? The Minister was absolutely right when he interjected, `More money is needed', because more money is needed.

If the Minister wants to get into intellectual and intelligent policy debate and front up at this dispatch box and debate the issues, the real policy debate is where the money is going to come from. There is only one source of money and that is from the Australian community. The Minister can get that money from them when they wear their taxpayer hat or their consumer hat, or he can try to increase the quantum of money going to health in this country by a rational and sensible mix between consumers and taxpayers. Until the Minister faces up to that problem, he will not solve any of the fundamental flaws of Medicare that painfully persist for so many thousands of Australians.

The Minister could increase the Medicare levy. Despite the interjection earlier by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), for the last seven-odd years the Minister has persisted in the fiction that the Medicare levy funds the system. He has got to come clean and tell the Australian community that the Medicare levy has never funded the system and never will fund the system.

If we wanted to fund the system fully from taxpayer sources and get rid of those queues and waiting lists, we would need to have a levy of 5 or 6 per cent. Is that what the Minister is going to do after Thursday? Is he going to front up to the dispatch box and at last honestly tell the Australian community, `Mr and Mrs Average, we have been kidding you about Medicare. We admit that there are queues and waiting lists. It has never been fully funded. We are going to solve the problem: your taxes are going to go up by 5 or 6 per cent'? If the Minister did that, he would be intellectually credible and he would certainly have my respect.

There are other solutions, a range of options. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is courageously fleshing out a range of options that need to be discussed. The Minister should not dare leave this chamber! The Minister should sit down in his seat because he of all people has the responsibility for the next two years of solving this problem. One of the reasonable things he could do would be to join us in debate on this range of options. The Minister should come back into the chamber. There are thousands of people in queues while he skulks out of this chamber. He should come back and face up to this debate. He is a coward. Come back here! The Government is going to run away from these problems. The only way health care will be solved in this country will be to kick the Government out and put us in.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill highlights a very dangerous period for the wool industry; a very uncertain and confusing time for thousands of wool growers which will result ultimately in some very tragic individual situations for them over the next two or three years. The stability and certainty of 20 years of a reserve price scheme have gone. The incomes of wool growers on average will fall dramatically next year and the degree of that fall will depend on the price for wool, the inflation rate and interest rates. They will join many wheat growers and horticulturalists who are already suffering these massive falls in income. It means that in total for this financial year farm incomes, that is, the net cash operating surplus, will fall, at this stage on projections, by 68 per cent on last year, which in itself was down 27 per cent, and already is expected by the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics to fall another considerable percentage next year. Of all of those projections for next year, the most dramatic are for wool growers.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Bureau made these projections-and it really made them late last year in time for the Agricultural Outlook conference-it made them on the basis that the reserve price scheme would continue. One thing we have to face up to is that irrespective of whether the scheme was to continue-and now, as we know, it will not continue-wool growers were facing a dramatic decline in their income next year. On the basis of those projections-as I said, made at a time when the floor price was to continue-the net farm cash operating surplus for this year for wool growers would be down 82 per cent to $9,500, and next year it would be a massive 139 per cent for a loss of $3,700 for the average wool grower. I remind the House that those figures relate to an average capital value of well over $1m per property, so there would be no return on capital and no allowance for management, and input costs would be reduced dramatically.

One of the problems facing agriculture and particularly wool growers in the next few years-and it is highlighted in the survey recently released by the National Farmers Federation-is that if farmers dramatically reduce their inputs, as distinct from the past, in making themselves more productive than any other sector in Australia, it will carry with it problems for their longer term viability and productivity as well as their short term viability, as I have just highlighted.

As a member of the National Party, I believe our Party has a very proud record of support for the wool industry. As a newcomer to Parliament in 1972, I was here when the first reserve price legislation-except for the deficiency payment support legislation-was introduced. At that time, because I was entering Parliament, I sold the sheep we had because there was no longer anyone at home to look after them. That was my last direct involvement with the wool industry.

I wish to commend people like Doug Anthony, Ian Sinclair, Malcolm Fraser and others who were in the coalition Government at that time for the work that they did. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), as recently as today, has reminded us that the original concept of that reserve price legislation was to make sure that wool remained competitive with competing fibres. One of the fundamental errors made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and this Government was to change the whole basis of the scheme in 1987 in relation to the final say for setting the floor price and particularly in removing from the legislation the criteria that were essential to maintain a realistic outlook or attitude towards the scheme.

The coalition parties-both the National and Liberal parties-have maintained support for that scheme ever since those early days. We maintained that support-I emphasise this-right up to 1 February, when the Australian Wool Corporation was forced to suspend sales because the scheme was no longer sustainable, as the Government was not prepared to advance the additional $1 billion considered necessary by the Corporation to maintain the buying-in procedures, to maintain the stockpile in the scheme, until the end of June. That announcement meant that the floor price was gone. We have to be realistic about that-for all practical purposes it has gone.

When other members of the Party and I stated the reality that the floor price was gone, there was some comment that somehow the National Party had changed, that somehow it had deserted wool growers and forgotten about its reason for being-to protect country people and country industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did that years ago.

—I will come to the honourable member opposite, because he is one of the main reasons the scheme failed. The Minister said that this afternoon, so I would not make any more comment if I were the honourable member.

At all times we have to be aware of what is the best policy for those people. As we have at times indicated that things should be done for those people, equally we have a responsibility to be honest and, if what is in place is no longer to their advantage, to say so.
