SPEECH.PARA: The reason is obvious: there is an increasingly large stockpile of wool. That stockpile was heading towards six million bales at the end of this wool selling season, with a total debt approaching $4 billion, and an interest bill annually of some $600m to be paid by wool growers. The Minister has indicated that on the projections of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics that stockpile could reach 8.7 million bales at the end of the following wool selling season. The $440m annual interest payment to cover the existing debt of $2.8 billion could take 15 to 20 per cent of wool growers' incomes next year, but if the scheme continued the debt would be even higher. Our projections, when we rejected the attempt by the Government to introduce this super tax on wool growers of up to 50 per cent, were that that 50 per cent figure was realistic, not imaginary, because with the scheme the stockpile would be greater. If any equity were to be maintained in the stockpile, which was one of the criteria for the Wool Corporation, then a 40 to 50 per cent tax was a very realistic figure.

There were warnings about the problems to come. I wish to quote from the speech by Hugh Beggs, Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, to the Wool Council of Australia conference at Launceston on 7 November last year. Referring to the procedures required by the trade to get wool through the system and the time lags, he said:

The apparel manufacturer needs to start cutting in April/May for July onwards delivery. It is necessary for him to take a position in fabrics pre-Christmas, in fact, the latest that weaving can start for the first cuttings is during January. This means that orders for wool, tops and yarn are normally placed during November/December.
That is for the following autumn and winter sales in the northern hemisphere. He continued:

We already know that the pipeline is de-stocked and the trade is waiting for something to happen to the Australian floor price, but there will come a time within the next 4-8 weeks when people will have to appear in the market. The critical period is between now and mid-February.
That was a very accurate warning of what was to happen. I wish to quote one other point from his speech because it highlights one of the other problems confronting the industry. He said:
The most urgent problem facing the Australian wool industry is to bring our production back into line with world demand.

I also want to quote from an article by Hugh Beggs, a man I have considerable respect for, in the Stock &Land of 14 February. It is entitled `Reserve price ``had to end'' '. I want to make the point that this is the Chairman of the Wool Corporation saying that the wool price had to end. Some of the reasons he gave included:
There is no guarantee that stocks will stop rising on June 30, 1991, with or without quotas and we cannot accurately predict trade clearances.
Every bale of wool bought from now on must almost certainly cost more than its eventual value in interest and storage costs. This is not commercially rational.
To continue to operate the 700c/kg floor would almost inevitably lead to a stock pile of more than six million bales and a debt of $4 billion or more.

Such a level of debt covered by Government guarantee is politically unacceptable and the burden of funding and servicing of such a debt would be intolerable for the wool growing industry to bear, and too great to ask the taxpayer to subsidise for long. It is bad enough already.
The effect of the overhang of so much wool on the market would keep the price down to 700c/kg or near to it for so long that wool growing would become unprofitable for many years.

In the light of those circumstances the continued operation of the reserve price scheme became unsustainable and the corporation called for the suspension of all wool sales while we discussed the future with the Government and industry.

The views of these people should be respected in this matter. They indicate that the pain of continuing the scheme for wool growers was greater and would last for a longer period than if the scheme was stopped. I believe that the Minister has been disappointing in this regard. We learned at his press conference recently that as long ago as last October he was aware that the floor price was not sustainable. Yet he did not do anything to prepare the industry, or even prepare the legislation that was obviously going to be inevitable. The legislation that we are seeing today is hastily drawn and badly drafted. I believe that the Minister could have been more realistic in drawing attention to the oversupply situation and given a more realistic presentation of the hard facts facing the industry. But I acknowledge that it is a difficult situation.

Twice before within the wool industry there was a considerable stockpile of wool, up to 1.8 million bales at one stage. On both occasions the industry recovered and went on to a stronger future, not only for wool growers but for the balance of trade for Australia. We had those three great years of 1986, 1987 and 1988 where a false impression was created that a new plateau for wool had arrived. This was partly due to the buying of wool by Russia and China.

I was a member of a National Party delegation that went to China late last year. We concentrated on discussions with wool industry people. I became angry with what I believed was the lack of information provided to wool growers in Australia about the real situation of the wool industry in China. China, because of its internal wool policies and other internal policies of creating employment in its counties, of the factory suit situation for employees, of allowing some unnecessary competition to occur in its buying procedures, created a completely false impression for the demand for wool by China, both internally and for export. While we were there we learnt that there was a stockpile of domestic wool in China equal to more than a year's supply and that the floor price, or the buying-in price, for its wool had just been halved.

We also learnt that unfortunately because our floor price was carrying the wool industries of the other wool producing countries when the Chinese were buying wool for re-export-they were certainly not buying foreign wool for the domestic market to any degree because they were under a variety of incentives and controls to reduce their own stockpile-they could buy South American wool consistently 15 to 20 per cent cheaper.

In those heady days there was the belief that there was that new price relationship, that we had broken the barrier between a wool synthetic price ratio of 3 : 1 to 5 : 1 or 6 : 1. Production increased to over 1,000 million kilograms, in spite of the fact that the biggest sale for any year that we have ever had was 900 million kilograms. It has now declined to an estimated 530 million kilograms this year. Next year, if quotas were in, the realistic figure would have been a maximum of 600 million kilograms on the quota proposal. But let me just look at the rapid decline in the two last years which indicated the oversupply situation and falling demand. In 1989-90, there were 1,029 million kilograms produced, 523 million kilograms sold. This year it is projected that 1,019 million kilograms will be produced and 530 million kilograms sold.

That is the reason why the coalition parties pushed so hard for a significant sheep slaughter or, to put it slightly more kindly, a flock reduction scheme. We did it deliberately because we believed it was the only way to address that oversupply problem in the time available and to send a strong message to wool users around the world that Australia meant business in bringing supply back to demand. Even though the scheme was never pushed to the degree it should have been I understand that at this stage about 8 1/2 million sheep have been contracted to be removed. I believe that the wool industry will regret its failure to support that scheme more wholeheartedly.

We arrived at the situation in mid-January, with the opening sales of early January looking good and then a sudden collapse. There is no shortage of reasons as to why the market collapsed. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who is at the table, gave his view of some of these reasons in Question Time today. There was the activity of the Vines Committee in Europe, asking people what their reaction would be to a lowered floor price. There was the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and his famous correspondence. There were, according to many others, sales from the stockpile by the Wool Corporation at a critical time. Others would say that there was the submission of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics to the Vines Committee. I think, above anything, there was the fact that wool users had filled the pipeline to the degree that they wanted to because they kept looking at the stockpile and the debt.

We now have this difficult situation with this legislation. The coalition parties have had many hours of discussion, in committees and with the industry, shadow Ministry and joint parties. We believe that the most important things to do are, as quickly as possible, to get confidence again in the industry and in the marketing of wool and to limit the debt to wool growers. The stockpile is the key to both of those objectives. We believe that sales should commence, as advertised, on Monday; that the management of wool stocks with confidence is of critical importance; and that the reality is that the floor price is more than suspended-it really is finished.

With limiting debt, I refer to the supplementary payments scheme, which we support. We support the $300m grant by the Government. We believe it is important to provide equity to wool growers. Interestingly enough, New Zealand did not when it suspended its scheme. But we believe there is a great danger here that the Wool Corporation debt, already $2.9 billion, could blow out to $4 billion if this scheme is allowed to remain open ended. The Minister and others have made certain guesstimates as to what it could cost, but those in the industry are tremendously worried that at a time when, in their view, they will not be able to sustain the interest payments of $440m a year, they could be up for $600m a year. If we look at, say, a $2.5 billion to $3 billion gross income for the wool industry next year, we can see what a hole $500m or $600m in interest payments will make in an income that is already dramatically reduced.

We believe that it is important to put a cap of $500m on that scheme, to bring some discipline into growers so that they do not just give their wool away, and to send a message to buyers that they cannot just take it for nothing. I believe that would be providing equity while at the same time limiting the debt load of all wool growers for the next few years. It is obvious that the Government scheme will not provide complete equity for the 700c regime. I have seen copies of guidelines which indicate that through a system of benchmark and notional price arrangements, there will be a percentage loss to growers.

In relation to the stockpile, we agree that the ownership, management and repayment responsibility of the stockpile should remain with the industry, but it is important to have very clear guidelines for and understanding by the trade on the reduction of the stockpile. The best way to have that is by legislation rather than by regulation, because it also protects the industry from any attempt to interfere with an orderly process. Within the first 12 months, there should be basically a freeze other than for certain exceptional circumstances. We believe that, to provide the necessary confidence to the industry, that should be in place now rather than just being in place until the end of this wool selling season, which is the proposal by the Government at the present time. People are asking what will happen after the end of June, and there is enough uncertainty about that while we wait for the Vines report and the recommendation for or suggestion of further legislation in May.

This legislation, as I said earlier, has been very badly and dangerously drafted. It gives the Minister far too much ability to bring in regulation-to govern by regulation-including one provision in particular. I refer to proposed new section 148 (2) (b), under the heading `Regulations', which says:
. . . amend any provision of this Act other than this Part.
That is a very dangerous power for a Minister to have, because it means he can basically override any part of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trust me.

—We do not, and I am sure the industry does not at present and will not in the future-and for very good reason. We will be moving an amendment to delete that clause, just as we will be moving amendments to indicate that in reality the floor price has ended, to put a cap of $500m-$200m of borrowed money for growers-on the supplementary payments scheme and also to legislate for the stockpile.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition does support the ministerial power to terminate appointments to the board. It is a general power which I think is necessary with this very difficult and mixed responsibility of statutory marketing corporations, because they are more than representatives of growers; they operate on a delegated authority from government. The power must not be used capriciously, and I believe at the present time it is important for the Wool Corporation to be in place until the end of June for the important role that still faces it and the industry.

At this difficult time the future is the important point for the industry. There is the problem of debt for growers. That will be a recurring debt every year with interest payments as well as reduced incomes. That is why we are strongly supporting a significant increase for rural adjustment and rural counselling and also stressing the importance of debt assessments via a combination of banks, rural adjustment authorities, State rural agencies and so forth. That is because, as the price of wool falls, the price of land will fall and there will be some very dangerous asset debt situations, which are not apparent at this stage, with growers not being able to sell. That may mean, of course, problems not just for farms but for whole regional communities. The income equalisation deposit scheme, which the Government ruined seven years ago and for which wool growers had to pay about an additional billion dollars of tax as a result, is the best way to bring some individual income stability back to growers, acknowledging that that can only happen when their incomes improve, because these measures really do not work for people with a low taxable income.

The Government has a responsibility with promotion, credit and live sheep sales, and it also has a responsibility finally to remove that confounded tariff on cool wool, which is still there even though the Government claimed it removed it. It also has the responsibility to get on with the business of reducing input cost to growers. That accounts for 60 per cent of the total cost problem confronting agriculture in this country. The Minister has not accepted his responsibility to do these things and to make in the rest of the community the adjustments that have been demanded of the wool industry. I move:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``, in the light of the urgent need to restore confidence by wool producers and buyers in the long term future of the industry, to end the confusion that the Government's policies have engendered and to assist the immediate resumption of wool sales, the House does not decline to give the Bill a second reading, but is of the opinion that the reserve price in respect of wool offered for sale should not be suspended only, as the Bill proposes, but should be terminated forthwith''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—The amendment is seconded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much comment has been made during the last week regarding the suspension of the wool reserve price scheme until 30 June. We now need to get some enthusiasm and vision into the wool industry to give growers confidence to press on. There is no doubt that things will recover, but it will take time. The situation will take several years to recover, given the stockpile of wool that we have. The decision to suspend the floor price has been made at a time when many Northern Hemisphere manufacturers are about to make decisions on fibres for the 1992-93 retail season. It is crucial that we now get on with the job of restoring confidence in the marketplace.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a vast imbalance between supply and demand. The record high years of 1988-89 and 1989-90 gave the industry a false sense of security. Buyers reacted to the high floor price in some instances by turning to cheaper fibres. If wool is to survive and prosper as a fibre, it must be competitive with its substitutes. That applies whether it is in competition with cotton or synthetics.

I do not believe that there was any real option but to end the stockpiling of wool that was steadily sending the industry broke. To continue to operate the 700c floor price would almost inevitably have led to a stockpile of some six million bales plus and a burgeoning debt of approximately $4 billion or more with no upper limit. It simply does not make sense to continue to overproduce and to buy our own product.

The level of debt covered by government guarantee would be politically unacceptable and an intolerable burden for the wool growing industry to bear. It would certainly be too great to ask the taxpayer to subsidise it for long. A continued depressed demand for wool would force individual growers to accept drastically reduced production quotas and the possibility of higher tax levels merely to service the likely debt levels.

I have always been concerned about quotas because of the various types of wool produced around the country. There is still a much better demand and price for finer wools than for coarser wools. Those growers who have not overproduced and who have stayed within their limits prior to the last four or five years would be adversely affected for being prudent and making the right decision. Consequently I have never been of the view that quotas work or are fair because they have a negative impact on the more visionary growers.

A number of unpredictable world events have proved to be all negatives for the wool industry-namely, the onset of war in the Middle East and the turmoil in Russia and Eastern bloc countries, causing them to stay out of the market. The consequent economic effects are taking place in those countries right now.

The Government has not been sitting idle over the last 12 months. A wide range of measures has been implemented by the Government and the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) to endeavour to restore confidence in the market and to put the wool industry on the road to recovery. I would like to give just a few examples: the floor price was reduced last year; the Vines inquiry was instigated; the interim Wool Policy Council was established; a business plan and strategic plan from the Australian Wool Corporation was called for; and of course, the wool mission resulted in the provision of $400m to Russia by way of a credit facility. However, despite the adoption of this range of measures, the situation has continued to deteriorate, largely as a result of continuing speculation that the scheme was unsustainable and because of other influences such as the crisis in the Soviet Union and the Gulf war.

Wool selling arrangements to apply after 30 June will be finalised in April after Cabinet considers the recommendations of the Vines committee of inquiry into wool marketing, which will report to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) by 31 March. The Government will contribute some $300m towards a supplementary payments scheme to woolgrowers who sell their wool during the remainder of the 1990-91 season. Supplementary payments will make up the difference between market prices for wool and what would have been received under the 700c per kilogram reserve price. The remainder of the cost of these payments will be financed by the industry through the Australian Wool Corporation.

The suspension of the reserve price scheme in mid-season leaves a potential equity problem. There will be those growers who have already sold their wool at 700c, much of which has gone into the stockpile, and those who will be offering wool for sale between now and July. In the absence of supplementary measures, those yet to sell would bear the brunt of the initial market adjustment caused by events over the last two years. The wool tax will remain at 25 per cent for the remainder of the 1990-91 season. The Government will provide assistance to those most affected in the wool industry through the rural adjustment scheme and the rural counselling program. The Government will provide additional substantial funds for these purposes, and it is important that that be done.

Whilst responsibility for the servicing of the debt of the Australian Wool Corporation and the wool stockpile will remain with the Corporation, the Government will lift the ceiling on its guarantee of the borrowings of the Australian Wool Corporation to $3.5 billion. The Government will extend its guarantee on all borrowings beyond 1992 for the period required to manage the run-down of the industry's debt. It is estimated that it will take about five years to bring the debt of the Australian Wool Corporation to a manageable level.

Final details for the orderly disposal of wool now held in the stockpile, management of the assets of the Australian Wool Corporation and wool promotion will be jointly developed by the Government and the Australian Wool Corporation upon receipt of the Vines committee report. There is a much better prospect of bringing both the Wool Corporation debt and wool stocks under control in the absence of a floor price and without the Wool Corporation buying in the market. During the period of suspension, the Corporation will not be permitted to buy wool. To all intents and purposes, the Wool Corporation stockpile will be frozen with the final details to be worked out between the Minister and the Wool Corporation.

Provision has been made for the Minister to appoint for a limited period an interim administrator or interim board of the Australian Wool Corporation. These powers have been included to allow the Minister to ensure the ongoing operation of the board. It is intended that the Minister consult with the industry in making such appointments. It is to be hoped that the Australian Wool Corporation will work with the Government to implement the processes that will need to be gone through to get new arrangements in the industry in place by 1 July 1991. If there is to be any reserve price scheme from 1 July, it will be self-funding and the floor price will be set conservatively against the prevailing market price.

Research and development is critical for the long term future of the wool industry. The Government will be prepared to consider increased assistance for research and development. To ensure that it is not compromised by Australian Wool Corporation funding difficulties, a Wool Research and Development Corporation will be established as a separate entity. However, it will share accommodation and administrative services with the AWC unless its own board determines that these services can be provided more efficiently by other means.

There is no denying that there is no quick solution for the wool industry. The current difficulties of Australia's premier agricultural industry, the wool industry, are well known and well documented. With the exodus of China and the Eastern bloc from the marketplace and with the continuing war in the Middle East, this decision was the one appropriate solution to redress the market problems and imbalances. The important thing now is for everyone to get behind the new arrangements and make them work. There is enough doom and gloom. Fair enough, the situation at present is grim, but it is time for all levels of the wool industry to adopt a positive approach and to get out there and sell the wool clip.

The decision has been made with the best long term interests of wool producers in mind. We all know that Australian wool fibre is the best, so it is up to us to convince the marketplace. I believe that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has acted responsibly in the management of the problems within the industry. No-one else has come forward with solutions that offered a better outcome for growers. It is a time for definite plans and tough decisions.

I noted in the Australian Financial Review of last Friday that Japan has been critical of the decision taken regarding the suspension of the wool floor price. There is concern that our trade could be affected. I have a good memory and remember a contract price for four years for sugar. The contract was signed by Japanese companies. Once the world price dropped below that price, the Japanese importing companies simply refused to honour their signed agreements. So Japan is the last country that should ever talk about the way in which any decisions we make in the interests of our producers affect trade negotiations. Given the Holy Grail attitude towards rice in Japan, I think that we, in making decisions in the long term interests of our industry, stand much cleaner on free trade and on doing the right thing than any critics in Japan.

The other thing that needs to be briefly touched on before I close is the effect of the debt and the interest rate that will be applied to wool growers and other primary producers in the grains sector over the next few years. I have just left a meeting with the National Farmers Federation. It is preparing a submission to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for its inquiry into the banking industry-which I think can be constructive and informative on the issues and problems affecting primary producers, including meeting their debt. The Queensland Farmers Federation is doing the same.

I think we are now seeing all sections of rural Australia understanding each other and working together-particularly, with regard to this Bill, the wool industry-in order to overcome what is one of the most severe problems that agriculture has faced for a long time. But we shall overcome it because, as I have said, we produce the finest wool and Australian farmers are the best in the world, working under the harshest of conditions. But unity and a sense of purpose are needed. In closing, I again compliment the Minister for the courageous and visionary way in which he has handled one of the toughest decisions that agriculture has faced since the war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) used the words courageous and--
—Visionary.

—Courageous and visionary. What a remarkable statement to make in this place. We are discussing here the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill-another piece of bandaid legislation; another example of a government staggering around trying to find a solution and not being prepared to give it. This piece of legislation is notable more for what it does not say than for what it does say. This piece of legislation will rely on a series of guidelines to be issued by the very individual who stands here condemned for the current state of the wool industry. This piece of legislation suggests that it is not enough to impose a long term $3,000m debt on the wool growers of Australia, but in fact seeks to add another $1 billion. I support wholeheartedly the attempts of the Opposition, by amendment, to keep that debt to approximately its current position of $3 billion. It is pretty easy to see why.

SPEECH.PARA: Every time this Government has tried to make some sort of attempt to defy gravity-to defy the logic and the arithmetic that was so patently obvious-it has added another $1 billion onto the debt. When the Government reduced the reserve price from 870c to 700c as some sort of interim measure, because it lacked the courage then to tell wool growers that it was time to consider their welfare and not their prejudice, the wool industry, through its reserve price scheme, owed about $1.4 billion. By the time the Government had got to the next stage of tripling or quadrupling the tax levels and talking about quotas, the industry owed about $2 billion. Now, of course, it owes $2.8 billion or $2.9 billion-we are not exactly sure even of that. But we do know that it is a massive debt, and the Government brings to us a proposal-it says on the grounds of equity-because it is not yet courageous enough to establish a totally free market with all of the pain and suffering that goes with that.

What does the Government tell us? The Government tells us that it will chuck in a lousy $300m but that the wool growers will have to put themselves in debt by a further $1,000m. When I talk about wool growers I do not mean only the beneficiaries of the scheme in the past-of course they are not exactly beneficiaries because they stand to lose $1.8 billion in growers' funds that existed when this fiasco commenced. The reality is that this money will just grow and grow because of the interest component. Let us look at the interest component. I guess it might be optimistic to claim that in a free market 200c clean will be a price indicator. If it is, then the gross on 1,000 million kilograms of wool-which is the possible level of production-would be $2 billion. It is suggested that at $3 billion the interest cost is $400m and, of course, on $2 billion that is a 20 per cent tax.

Yet we have legislation before us here today which is saying, `Let's increase that by another 30 per cent; let's increase it to 27 per cent on 200c a kilogram clean'. That is what this Bill suggests. That is what it leaves wide open. I hope that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) will join with the Opposition and say, `That is impossible. It is bad enough that we, the Government, through our procrastination, have let the debt grow to $3 billion'. The Minister is apparently of the opinion that wool growers-some of whom are not yet in the industry because this interest payment will go on for years-must service that debt. But the Minister has decided to make them pay and now he wants to load them up with an additional debt. The Minister gives us a piece of legislation that does not tell us where the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) might finish.

I am a wool grower. I am being told by this legislation to put my faith in John Kerin because he is going to issue guidelines to save me. I thank the Minister, but I would prefer that he did not take the job, because so far his representations on my behalf, and on behalf of all of those other thousands of wool growers in Australia, have been disastrous. The Minister listens to a few industry bureaucrats and he lacks the courage to tell them the simple arithmetic.

What was the simple arithmetic when we were being told to have confidence-that all the industry needed to have was confidence and the miracle would occur? I have looked at the weekly sales of AWC stocks as they stood for the period from 1 July to October 1990-a significant date in that year when the Minister came back to this Parliament with his second proposal for saving the industry and upped the tax levels substantially; in fact, potentially, to 50 per cent. Of course, a little later he came in with his quota proposal. I underline the fact that they are the Minister's proposals. I know where he got them from, but he brought them to this Parliament. The Minister argued for them; he is the person who is responsible for them, just as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is responsible for the banks in this country, as much as he would like to convince us to the contrary. We all take responsibility for the legislation that we bring into this place and we are all supposed to take responsibility for our departments.

But at that time when we were told that all we had to do was pay all this additional tax I discovered from the figures that actual sales of wool for that session-that is, until 19 October 1990-amounted to about 105 million kilograms. Yet all the claims of the Wool Corporation were predicated on an annual clearance of 700 million kilograms and that the fairy godmother or godfather, whoever it was, of wool was going to come along-it was nearly half-way through the selling season-and somehow or other in the second half of the season we were going to clear 500-odd million kilograms of wool, provided we could get the extra tax. That was the first item of arithmetic. It was impossible, but nobody had the courage to get up and say that. I certainly would have said it at that time, but of course the legislation was debated under the guillotine and I was denied the opportunity to do so. I certainly said it in my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal Party gagged you, Wilson.

—As the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, who interjects, would agree, the West Australian wool growers have led this debate on a rational basis. It has not taken the honourable member for Kalgoorlie long to get on the bandwagon now that he has woken up to where the votes are in the west. He does it with all sorts of things. He votes a bit differently, of course, but he knows what to say in public. But, even worse, what was the Government's proposed solution? It puts taxes up to 50 per cent as well as quotas.
—That's the Corporation's solution; you know that.
—That is the solution that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie voted for in this Parliament.
—That's what you voted for, too.
—That certainly never had my support. By the way, we did not vote for quotas; we voted against them.
—Yes, but you voted for it. Tell the truth.
—The honourable member for Burke should not get so nervous about it-just because the Government has destroyed the most profitable industry in Australia.
— Order! The honourable member for O'Connor does not need any help.

—The honourable member for Burke and the rest of his colleagues stand condemned-his Minister in particular. They are the people who have added $1,000m of debt to the wool industry every three months for the last nine months.
—I suggest that the honourable member for O'Connor resist the temptation to respond to the interjections and I ask the interjectors to resist the temptation to interject.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker; it is a pity that the honourable member's ability in arithmetic does not equate with his ability to interject, otherwise he too might have seen that the numbers were against him. But what did this magnificent scheme do? We kept saying that it was preserving 700c for the wool grower. But of course, when the tax was deducted and when some reasonable assessment was made of what the quota might be-and that was the same as a tax; the Government said to the wool grower that the Wool Corporation would no longer stockpile his wool and that he had to stockpile it himself-there was an actual payment to the wool grower of less than 250c a kilogram clean on that 700c. Yet time and again I have heard people say that if we had this dreadful free market, the price might fall to 300c. As a wool grower, I could be so lucky if it did. SPEECH.PARA: We have been through the most remarkable situation. We provide to the world a fibre which represents less than 2 per cent of the world apparel fibre market and we have said, `If you don't pay our price, we'll teach you a lesson. We won't let you use it'. To which people have responded, `Okay, we won't use it'. They have closed their mills; they have gone and found some readily available synthetics. They have fluffed cotton up a bit more and made it fleecy lined. They have got by. We have sat here kidding ourselves. But what is worse is that a government that claims-and I have always disagreed with the claim-that it is economically rational has gone along with this scheme for six months now when the arithmetic-not the ideology-said it would not work.

There are many aspects of this legislation that concern me. As I have already said, most importantly they are those parts of the legislation which give unlimited power to the Minister and leave open ended even the amount of debt. That part of the legislation gives me, as a wool grower, and my wool grower constituents, no guarantee as to how the debt might even be managed. The Government just tells us we have got to pay the bills. It is very clear on that point. The wool growers have to pick up the tab-but the mugs will continue to manage the system.

We do not need another bandaid. We do not need to have floating out there this idea-which I cannot believe even the Minister believes; I think the honourable for Hinkler alluded to it-that in July we might actually be able to resurrect the reserve price, at some very modest level. In the Minister's response he might tell us whether that is a possibility, because it means a continuation of the disaster. I do not want to know that.

I want to tell the Minister what the situation is. I do not like, for a start, government by committee. I do not have to be told by Mr Vines what is wrong with the wool industry. It is all there in the numbers. They are very clear and very simple. Those that one has to study are limited. In other words, it is quite appropriate to take a decision now, to put the certainty into the wool industry that everybody says he wants. And how do we do that? Quite simply. First, as has been recommended by the Opposition, the stockpile is frozen. Secondly, a receiver to the Wool Corporation is appointed as the obvious creditor. I do not think the banks that have lent the money need to do it. The Government is the guarantor; it has given that guarantee. That was another mistake. What is more, having done it, it is now responsible for any deficiency from the resolution. I say to the Government: put a receiver in; get the matter cleaned up; and pick the best possible man to ensure that the deficiency-which it still argues is the responsibility of the wool industry-is at a minimum. For once do the right thing. Do not let this thing drag on.

Let us look at the Government's proposal for supplementary payments. I can see the argument for equity. I just do not know how the Government will make it work. I have really applied my mind to that project. I do not know how the Government will prevent abuse. I do not know how it will give a wool grower in a future market the incentive to get the best price for his wool before he gets the balance from the Wool Corporation. I do not know how the whole thing will work when the Government will probably increase the Wool Corporation's debt by another $1 billion but not give it one more pound or kilogram of wool. At least the debts that the Wool Corporation has incurred to date have been for the purpose of buying wool. The next $1 billion that the Government proposes to put on the Wool Corporation by way of indebtedness is with no security at all; it just hands out the money. The Government has difficulties with the equity argument, but for once it should try to resolve them. It is the Government's problem-and the Government should fix it.

The Opposition is totally correct to demand a cap on the debts of the Wool Corporation and to demand that the Government show how for $300m or $400m it can provide an equity deal. Of course, if the Government removes some of the proposed complexities and looks at some net supplementary payment in July, it might find that it can make $300m go quite a long way. But the worst possible proposal is to feed it in one end, tax it, take it out, build it up, and then leave wool growers-some yet to enter the industry-with a debt for the next decade. It is stupid and it is wrong.

It is the Government's mistake because it could not understand the arithmetic of the Wool Corporation and it could not understand the history of cartels, buffer stock schemes-call them what you like-and do the right thing when the writing was on the wall, really and truly, at the beginning of this financial year. But certainly when the Government eventually dragged itself to make a decision and lowered the floor price from 870c to 700c it knew that it was gone. And $2 billion later we are still arguing about interim measures: the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill. What a dreadful thing for a Minister to have to bring to the Parliament-temporary provisions for an industry that was turning over $6 billion a year a couple of years ago and has traditionally provided $3 billion or $4 billion to the Australian economy. It cannot go on.

I raise a matter of concern to me about the deficiency payment process. I would like the Minister to respond officially. Although I have done some reading on it I need to know-and I think that wool growers are entitled to know-what the Government will do about the private traders in wool. They are very significant in the industry in Western Australia. Producers are deeply concerned that deficiency payments might be made only to those who sell their wool through the auction system. I hope that is not the case. I am not saying that that is the case because I do not know. They need to know about this matter. If that were to occur their future would be devastated. They have suffered enough.

I talked to one the other day and it was interesting. We talked about value added in Australia. He actually built a scouring works. But of course, the Wool Corporation has been buying so much of the Australian wool clip for so long that he could not find any wool to put in his wool scour. Of course, the Corporation was not prepared to give him any; it wanted to stockpile it all as greasy-`You may as well store the lanolin along with the wool'. It does not give a few Aussie workers, whom Labor members claim to represent, the chance to earn a living cleaning it up. This high-tech modern scour built in the last two or three years went broke. It could not get any wool to process because the Wool Corporation was buying it all-and apparently the Government did not even know about that. It is a classic example of its stupidity.

In terms of the Government's outrageous proposal, in terms of its totally ignoring the situation that has occurred, it should do something. We do not want temporary provisions; we want the matter resolved. The Opposition has given the Government a lead. It is a proper proposal and, no doubt, if the Government were to come to us and say, `Here is a positive proposal to wrap the whole thing up'-pre-Vines report; in other words, the Minister makes a decision in his own right for once-we will help it, and we will tell it why: this is too big for politics. This is about saving what is historically Australia's largest single industry. If we do not do something that is a lot better than these so-called temporary and vague provisions, the country will be in a lot of trouble.

Wool growers do not have to have politicians forced upon them any longer. Most of them now want out, and most of them want a free market, but they do not want to have to carry the burden of another $1,000m to make the Government look good out in the electorate. That is all these provisions are for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the contribution of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), I must say that on several occasions he made an observation that I completely agreed with, and that does not happen all that often. On at least four occasions the honourable member for O'Connor said, `I don't know how'. That is about the strength of it: he does not know how. He does not know how to find solutions to these difficult problems. With regard to the little tale that he introduced at the end of his speech about the Australian Wool Corporation driving a scouring process broke, I think the Parliament ought to listen to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) when he contributes to this debate because I understand that he is the member of this House who has been working on behalf of that operation. The honourable member for O'Connor has just come in here today to saddle up once again for a bit of cheap point scoring.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to start my contribution to the debate by saying that what I find utterly deceitful on the part of the Opposition is that, having come into this Parliament, having endorsed and gone along with every step that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has taken in this whole sorry wool tale, it is now going around Australia talking to people in the rural sector, spinning this kind of populist cant that the honourable member has just gone on with, about how dreadful the Government is for having stuffed up the wool industry. That is what its people are saying, when every one of us in this place knows that each time a vote has been taken, each time the proposal has been brought forward, the Opposition has supported the Government because there was nowhere else to go.

I support the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill. I join with the honourable member for O'Connor in making the observation that, whilst the Bill is called temporary provisions legislation, I think we are looking at something that will be a permanent change in the way in which the wool industry conducts its affairs. Certainly, the growers I have talked to are prepared for that and are keen to see it develop into the situation that I think will eventuate from this legislation.

It is not sufficient just to say now that the Government and the Minister brought in legislation at the start of the financial year and now it has to be taken further because it was got wrong then. I think most people who are going to take a responsible view of this debate will understand that at the time there were two roads down which the Government and the Australian Wool Corporation could go. There was much debate about which of those two was the one to take. There is no doubt that, at a time when Australia's balance of payments was fragile, we were in fact playing a game of bluff with the world in terms of our wool price. There was an expectation that, if we lowered the wool price to 700c, that may see buyers re-enter the market. There were some signs that buyers were prepared to re-enter the market but it has not proved to be the case. That is the reality, as the Opposition well knows, because today once again it intends to support the Government.

Again I go back to the point that it is all very well to come in here and support the legislation, but it is utterly deceitful to then wander around rural Australia claiming that the Opposition did not do that-as the honourable member for O'Connor tried to claim just a moment ago. That is a message that needs to be understood. There is no choice now but to move away from the floor price; I think that is well understood.

It is interesting to look at the equation. To maintain the floor price at 700c, increase the tax and carry the costs, particularly the interest cost of borrowing to sustain the stockpile, by some calculations which have been made public, and which I have seen, we are talking about a cost of something like 350c to 400c in equivalent terms. In other words, with this legislation and the removal of the floor price, if there was to be a fall in the price that got the stockpile moving, it could fall to 350c to 400c before any grower would be worse off than he is in the present situation. I think that is something that the growers, rather than people like the honourable member for O'Connor, understand very well. It is one of the reasons why they support this action.

They also recognise that the Government has been prepared to quarantine the existing stockpile and the undertakings that have been given in relation to the floor price up to the time of the announcement. The likely cost of that to the Government is $300m in these days when every cent of Government expenditure in the public budget is under scrutiny. I think a $300m commitment on the part of this Government-the proposal brought forward by Minister Kerin-represents a good faith position with the growers and one about which I am very happy to talk to growers in my electorate.

I also raise the anomalous position of people like the honourable member for O'Connor and others who are clinging to the notion that in some way a government supported floor price ought to remain in place. I have heard absolutely nothing from those people about the decision of the Industrial Relations Commission a couple of weeks ago in response to industry representations to award the shearers their 6 per cent national wage increase, but to award it on the basis of the industry's capacity to pay. It is an award that is made virtually in terms of the free market. When wool starts flowing, when the revenue is there to pay the wage increase, the Commission is prepared for the wage increase to flow on. On the one hand, these people are arguing that the grower should continue to receive a guaranteed floor price courtesy of the Government and the Wool Corporation but, on the other hand, the shearer should get the wage flow-on if and when the industry is in a position to pay.

I do not know whether the decision means that growers who have been shifting their wool will now pay the wage flow-on; those who have been getting the 2 per cent greasy through the system can pay and others not. There has been absolutely nothing from the Opposition about that anomalous position. It ought to be talked about.

I broaden my comments marginally in one other area; that is, in response to the observations made by the honourable member for O'Connor about the wool scouring operation in Western Australia. I do not know the details of that; I will leave it to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. It raises the issue of one of the major needs in this economy-to move as quickly as possible to much more value adding. As the Government works its way through its industry statement and the principles that will be behind that, I am certain that many of us will be making the point that import replacement is just as important as export enhancement. I raise that because there is a considerable amount of import replacement involved in value adding significantly in the first stages of downstream processing.

The lack of downstream processing cast a black cloud over the Opposition parties' 30 years in government from 1949-23 years and then a further seven years under Malcolm Fraser. Every commonsense Australian was saying, `This is crazy. We send coal and iron ore to Japan and we buy back cars, and we send wool and other primary products to countries and we buy back clothes. Why aren't we manufacturing more of these products ourselves?'. The reason was that it was easier to grow something, dig it up or cut it down. Every developing country makes its early money and earns its early foreign exchange by exploiting its natural resources. The hard part is actually turning these resources into something, which requires education, investment in plant and equipment, and marketing and management skills at an international level. Absolutely nothing of any substance was done during those 30 years when the Opposition parties were in government to add those components to Australia's intellectual and skill base.

That is the black cloud that remains over the contribution by the Opposition. That is why we are still having debates now on the wool stockpile. Why should the wool stockpile even need to be sold overseas? Why are there no corporations in Australia buying that wool stockpile and turning it into value added products for export?

Much more work has to be done on developing these aspects of the Australian economy. They are not aspects about which farmers are particularly concerned. Indeed, I have sat across the table from representatives of the National Farmers Federation who have told the Government that they are not interested in seeing these value adding concepts put to work if they threaten the future of their primary produce. In other words, if farmers see even the slightest danger in Australian manufacturers not getting it right, they would rather sell their raw wool bales overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —True.

—As the honourable member for Gippsland acknowledges, that is the position of Australian farmers. That position is driven by a great deal of self-interest, which I can understand. However, that attitude will not transform the economic equation in this country. Indeed, when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy took the original decision on the wool stockpile and asked whether Australia could sustain a floor price at 700c, we had to ask ourselves some questions. Where was the demand, and why had it collapsed? Is an alternative supplier emerging? Are our customers buying their wool somewhere else? There was no intelligence from either the Australian Wool Corporation or elsewhere to indicate any real problem. Other questions were: was there a substitute? Were the manufacturers of the world turning to some other product because our wool price was too high? Even then there was no real evidence that that was likely to be a problem.

SPEECH.PARA: If one believes that the collapse in buying was really the result of the cartels deciding to sit and use their stocks to try to drive the price down or alternatively to react early to a potential world recession by minimising their stocks, one believes it was a waiting game with buyers trying to hold out. That is what the available information pointed to. I have been trying to get producers to understand that if Australia performed the downstream processing, that game of international bluff would not be going on, and that is where the key to the problem lies.

Australia has to buy much more of its own produce. Australia is in a trade and export position where about 70 per cent of its primary and resource production is exported. When I see farmers march up Collins Street and Bourke Street mall in Melbourne asking Australians not to buy Californian oranges and to use Australian oranges instead, and using other simplistic equations in respect of stopping imports, they never mention the fact that we sell 70 per cent of our farm produce offshore. Other countries buy that produce and they, in turn, expect Australia to buy their products. So any reversion to the old Black Jack McEwen idea of putting up the barriers strikes directly at the heart of the very people whom we are trying to help.

It is not sufficient for the National Farmers Federation to argue that we should not encourage downstream processing in Australia because it is likely to threaten existing markets. The long term future for producers lies in much more development of these facilities and options in Australia so that they grow and produce much more predominantly for an Australian market.

I reiterate: this has been a very difficult process for the Government. As a member of the country task force established by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), I know many of us spent hours and hours over the last year travelling around Australia talking with producers from all sectors to try to resolve these problems in international trade. We all know that Australia is a principal victim of the trade policies of Europe and the United States of America. I have long supported the idea of trying to find ourselves an international cartel. Even the comments by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) in response to the current activities in the USA have led us to examine ways of finding our own trading bloc, because if the behaviour towards Australia in these trade situations is not resolved and the Uruguay Round is not resurrected, Australian producers will continue to be exposed in an unfair way which will adversely affect not only Australia's producers but the whole population. We have a responsibility to look at some other options.

I support the legislation. Rather than being a temporary provision, the Bill represents a shift to a new era for the wool industry. Those conditions which prevailed when the first decision was made still prevail. The product is still the best in the world. It does have a position in the international marketplace, but the best way for the situation to be resolved is for the wool growers and the industry to completely take over the marketing and dissemination of the product.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I wish to make a contribution to the debate on the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill, firstly as the member for Maranoa, which is an electorate that contains two-thirds of the Queensland wool clip, and, secondly, as a wool grower who, it might be said, has a vested interest. However, I rise today to put my thoughts forward in the best interests of the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia will undoubtedly always be a major supplier of the world's apparel wool. Australia supplies 80 per cent of the apparel wool to our consuming countries. That fact must be kept firmly in our sights in the debate and during the agony that will confront the industry in the next two to three years.

One of the major problems the wool industry faces is the supply of wool at predictable prices. For many months I have asked myself whether price, product supply or the world recession affects our consumers. Another scenario is that perhaps we have lost market share to other fibres.

I do think it is worth relaying to the House a point that I have been able to glean from a comment made by one of our major consumers of wool in western Europe: there is no way to properly run a farm, a combing mill, a spinning mill, a weaving mill or a knitting mill with strong price variations and with an acceptable risk profile without any hedging tool. The present situation stimulates and increases the use of other fibre alternatives. I really believe that says a lot and that it is one of the things the industry must look at, important factors relating to any commodity being predictability of prices, stability, and continuity of supply. I think we must also look very clearly at future marketing initiatives for wool, and we must certainly guard against any of the corrupt trading cartels which are out there in the world-and I think it is naive for anyone to believe that there are not corrupt trading practices out there. If we did have a free trade system it would be wonderful, but it is fairyland stuff to believe that such a situation exists now.

I do not underestimate the problem that this Parliament and the industry face because, when I was first married back in 1967, I walked straight into a wool recession which lasted for five years. I well remember the people who shore their sheep themselves to survive-they no longer employed shearers. I well remember the people who took their monthly accounts to their agents or their banks for payment-they did not have a cheque book. I certainly remember the heartbreak of families and individuals who were forced off the land because of that recession. I also remember the towns that lost a population, and a younger generation which moved to the cities.

In my electorate alone, I have many towns that I know are going to feel the pain of what is in front of the industry. I have many towns in my electorate which are called shearers' towns, and I believe they are going to be very badly affected. I guess one of the things that I worry about is that we will lose shearers from the industry, so as we do come out of this cycle-and inevitably we will-we must ensure that we have people in there, the infrastructure, to continue on as we get over the hard times in front of us. I have been involved in the wool industry for all my married life and, in fact, all my working life. It is certainly the industry that has fed and clothed my family and my family before me.

TALK.START.PARA: —And educated them, too.

—And educated them, as the Leader of the National Party of Australia says. That will continue as long as we get the right solutions into legislation. I find that the technical provisions in this wool marketing Bill do not really address all the problems that the industry faces. I do not believe that for some of the hard decisions that must be taken we need to have another temporary stay of execution. I cannot see why we should be procrastinating any longer. But I know that there have been out there commentators, journalists who have been writing about it, honourable members of this House, and the predictions from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE). I guess we could say everyone has been wrong. Two or three years ago, when the reserve price was set at 870c, who said it was set too high? There were certainly warnings, but there were not many people coming forward with a crystal ball at that time saying that it would destroy the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: There are people out there who are advocating right now the abolition or scuttling of the Australian Wool Corporation and its assets. I find that truly an unbelievable statement. It would be an act of vandalism, when we come out of this, to sell or scuttle the assets of the Wool Corporation. Advocates of this action do not understand some of the roles played by the Wool Corporation, what it is going to have to do and what it has done in the past. If we look at some of the roles of the Corporation, we see it has been out there training shearers and establishing shearer training schools. The industry has taxed itself to train its shearers. The industry has taxed itself to train its wool classers. It has taxed itself to ensure it has classers who are registered. It has a clip inspection service which ensures the product that we put on the world markets is of the highest possible quality and standard, and of a predictable standard. That is just one of the roles that the Wool Corporation has played.

I believe the industry has taken a leading role in the training of the required staff for the needs of the industry. There is a requirement also to type our varieties of wool and to ensure that these varieties are in fact consistent with our buyers' requirements. There are some 200-odd prime types, and if we go through all of these subsidiary types there are something like 6,000 to 7,000 types. I think it probably does people no credit to say that we have to sell the Australian Wool Corporation and scuttle its assets just in order to pay its debts. I find it, as I said earlier, an act of vandalism.

But when it comes to forecasting, I have always had a problem with the predictions of ABARE. I suppose it is down here in Canberra in this rare air and perhaps we should say, well, it has all the information available; it should be able to predict accurately what is going to happen in two, three or four years hence. I just want to record here today its predictions in January of 1989 to show how wrong it can be. It was predicting in 1990 that the market indicator would average 1,055c for the year in 1989. It said that in 1991 the average market indicator would be 1,080c and that we would have 20,000 bales in stockpile. Within six months of its prediction, the Wool Corporation had 2.5 million bales in stockpile.

So I question the relevance of ABARE if it can be that inaccurate. I think we must look at the economic models it uses, and inform it that it needs urgently to address its organisation and situation. Whilst there is a lot of criticism being levelled-and rightly so-at the industry organisations and the Australian Wool Corporation, we do not want to forget ABARE because it has something like 280 employees down there and costs us $16m to run. If the best that it can come up with are predictions like that, it would be better just writing history because I think all it has been able to do is record history. Perhaps it might be better off selling pencils and rubbers with the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

TALK.START.PARA: —History won't record them too favourably.

—No, I am sure it will not, as the honourable member for Dawson says. But there was a warning given back in 1988 by the then retiring full time chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, David Asimus. In May 1988, when prices had taken off-they were at 1,240c a kilogram-he said that consumer reaction to current wool prices was inevitable. He said that the first impact of consumer reaction to the recent wool prices would be felt in the spring of 1989. He was right. He said that it is impossible to estimate the extent to which consumers will be frightened out of the market. He went on to say that the floor price must be set at a level which would never have to be lowered. Unfortunately it was lowered and perhaps we could all hypothesise now and say that it is one of the reasons we are now in the position we are in today. He predicted that back in 1988, so there were people urging caution.

SPEECH.PARA: A further point I would like to make is that he was the full time Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation about to retire and be replaced by a part time Chairman. In other words the Minister, in what we might say was his wisdom or lack of it, downgraded the position of Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation to a part time position. I would say with hindsight the Minister would say that that in fact was a dreadful mistake which will have to be corrected. I think an industry such as the wool industry, as important as it is, really does need someone full time on the job and not just part time.

One of the other things I want to touch on is our international reputation as a result of what has happened in the last four months, and the Minister's word that the price was immutable. It is not just going to affect our wool industry; it is going to affect our beef industry, our wheat industry and all our export industries in which the Minister is involved. The Minister went around the world at the end of last year and assured buyers that the price was immutable. I checked with the Oxford dictionary-I thought I was right, and I am-and it says that immutable means unchangeable, not subject to variation. That did not last long.

The international world will never trust Australia whilst we have a Minister who says one thing and four months later goes back on his word. It will damage our reputation internationally for a long time. There are people out in the community who took the Minister at his word; there are processors who took the Minister at his word; there are banks who took the Minister at his word; and there are people out there in the bush who took the Minister at his word and made investment decisions based on that word. I was brought up to believe that `My word is my bond'. I hope somewhere in life we still have people who say what they mean and will stick to their word.

I want to touch briefly on the deficiency payments, because the Government is offering the industry $300m for a deficiency payment; it is calling on the industry to fund an open cheque. That is ludicrous. All that will do is add debt to the wool growers which eventually has to be repaid. I support the amendment that we on this side of the House have moved. To have wool growers fund an open cheque at a time when they can ill afford it, when we are facing the bleakest period since the 1970s, is just crazy. To add debt that has to be repaid to an industry has no sense.

I believe that if the Government is fair dinkum it should have a greater commitment to this issue. These deficiency payments should not be paid as the sales progress but paid at the end of June and dividends should be then processed and sent to wool growers at the end of the selling season. Clearly, there is no incentive between now and June, if the deficiency payments are paid as they go along, for growers to set a reserve price on their wool. They will say, `If I am going to get 700c, I will let it go.' I think we must give them incentives to hold wool back off the market if they, in their best judgment, think they may be able to get a higher price for it. I think the deficiency payment or supplementary payment, whatever one wants to call it, should not be offered to them until the end of June.

Another area I want to talk about is the area of private buyers. I fear that if we do not watch this supplementary payment the private buyers will be out buying wool. There is room for types to be quoted differently. That is where the Australian Wool Corporation comes in. If a deficiency payment is to be made, we need an independent authority which can type those wools. Perhaps the only way around this is to submit all wool through auction. We have a situation where wool could be bought privately in western Queensland and shipped straight to Adelaide or wherever, and it will by-pass an independent authority to type that wool in order that it can receive a supplementary or deficiency payment. Perhaps the only solution is to put between now and June all wool through the auction.

There is no doubt that the stockpile has got out of control. It certainly has the potential to depress the market. I believe that this matter must remain in the hands of the industry. We need a firm policy on the stockpile which will allow wool onto the market. Although there may be some merit in freezing the market and releasing wool at a predictable rate, I think every endeavour must now be made and every stop pulled out to see whether we can get Russia and China back into our wool market.

Whilst we may freeze our market, the New Zealanders will not freeze their 650,000 bale stockpile. That wool could well be sold to China and Russia, and New Zealand would grab the market share which we need vitally and should be getting. We must watch the situation very closely and make every effort to sell our wool and bring China and Russia back into the market. The Minister travelled there at the end of last year, and efforts must be stepped up to see whether we can get those two countries back into the market, because they are clearly a key to getting a greater quantity of wool onto the market.

Time is running out and there is a lot more I would have liked to have said. We must wait to see what the Vines committee of inquiry has to say on future marketing arrangements. It may come forward with suggestions for a new marketing scheme that will be acceptable to wool growers. There is clearly a need to be able to sell wool on a 365 days a year basis instead of the present 42-week selling period. There is a need for a more forward contract selling system. There is a need to promote Australian wool as opposed to overseas wool.

As far as the slaughter scheme is concerned, I would like to see a whole lot more done in the area of live sheep trade. To that end, I would like to see a former member of this House, Doug Anthony, called on to travel to the Middle East to see whether he can re-establish a viable live sheep trade with the Middle East. It is crazy to put sheep into pits when in 1983 we were able to sell seven million sheep to the Middle East. What a tragic waste of resources it would be if we did not pursue every effort to get the live sheep trade operational again.

In conclusion, I support the amendment of the Opposition on deficiency payments. I believe it goes a long way towards addressing the real problems of grower equity. It is not good enough to add debt to wool growers by way of deficiency payments, as proposed by the Government. I have reservations about the abolition of the reserve price scheme prior to the release of the report of the Vines committee of inquiry, but I firmly believe that next week we must recommence wool auctions. It is vital that we get wool back onto our processing pipeline and that we recom- mence sales next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill is probably the most important piece of legislation we have had in this Parliament. It is interesting to see that there are only two lonely people in the press gallery for this debate. I want to say a few things about the contribution of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I share an electoral boundary with the honourable member for O'Connor and I have supported him in his electorate and said that he was one of the very few in the Liberal Party of Australia who was telling the story of wool as it should be told.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had members in his own constituency say to me, `Poor Wilson; he has told me they would not let him speak in the debate'. Yet he comes into the House today and tells us that it was as a result of a gag. The truth is that the Liberal Party would not let him speak because it did not like what he had to say. What he had to say today was a mishmash of half truths. It certainly did him no credit. I will certainly be distributing his speech through his own electorate. He tried to blame the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) for what was clearly the responsibility of the Australian Wool Corporation. If the honourable member for O'Connor does not understand that, I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the wool growers in his electorate do. They recognise that it was the Wool Council of Australia and the Wool Corporation that made those crazy decisions. I am amazed at the loyalty of Minister Kerin who in his heart must have known they were embarking on a crazy course but defended the scheme up until it had to be scrapped.

I address another piece of nonsense that was mentioned by the Deputy Leader of the National Party and shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), that I had somehow or other helped to destroy confidence in the wool market by distributing a letter. I have a copy of that letter here. I listened with interest to the speech of the shadow Minister as he trudged his turgid way down his own road to Damascus. This letter does not mention one thing about not buying Australian wool. I sent the letter to the technical media in Europe because I thought it was important that they should know what was happening in Australia. I thought it was important to stress to them that they should understand what was happening amongst growers.

They, too, like the Australian wool growers, were subjected to an enormous amount of misinformation. Do not let hearts bleed for the Japanese, because I can tell honourable members that the Japanese know exactly what is happening in Australia, and the Japanese-while they protest-will not be caught at all.

For the record, I seek leave to table this letter so it is clearly shown-contrary to the lies of Mr Beggs and every other agro-political organisation in Australia, with the honourable exception of the Pastoralists and Graziers Association in Western Australia-that I at no stage told people not to buy Australian wool. My efforts were always constructively designed to help the industry.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I must say the contribution of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) was woolly, to say the least. It was a rambling contribution, and I think if the honourable member had had all day he would not have said much. There are a couple of points I do want to take up.

SPEECH.PARA: At no stage during 1989 did the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) say the indicator would be over 1,000c. It was in fact much more pessimistic than that. What the Australian Wool Corporation usually says, when defending itself against charges of not listening to ABARE, is, `Oh, in 1987 ABARE said there would be a decline in the price of wool'. And it did: it got it wrong. It got it wrong for the same reason the Wool Corporation got it wrong: it did not realise that China was going to disintegrate. It did not realise that China was going to go from a central wool buying system to a decentralised one where buyers were competing against each other and buying lines that they did not need. ABARE could not predict that, nor could the Australian Wool Corporation.

The truth is that when the Wool Corporation moved its indicator to 870c, all the other experts in this field-in both the private and the public sectors-were saying, `Do not do it; the market has turned'. That is not denied by the Wool Corporation. It has actually said to me, `We have to trust our judgment'.

The honourable member also mentioned David Asimus. Now I would like to mention David Asimus too. David Asimus was the man who actually cut back funding for promotion in wool, preferring to rely on the floor price. When the price was raised to 870c it was Asimus who wanted to put it to 1,000c. I think David Asimus's contribution to the wool industry has been abysmal, and I certainly want that on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many other names are you going to rubbish?
—Order! Interjections must cease.

—There are a few more. We have 20 people speaking on this Bill here today. The silence coming from the Opposition has been deafening. The National Party, with the honourable exception of the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), who got this right from the start, has been very solid. It has been going down the road of supporting the dishonest, deceitful Wool Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will just talk about research and development, because I do not agree with the Government increasing funds for research and development. The truth is that there is very little research and development of any value coming out of this country in respect of wool. There is far more coming out of the mills in Europe at no cost to the Australian growers.

Let us look where we are going with research and development. I remember 20 years ago when the Abel Star handpiece was developed. It was going to solve the second cuts in wool. As everyone knows, most second cuts come with the extension of the long blow when the down tube is dragging the handpiece out of the wool. Twenty years ago the Wool Corporation touted this as a great innovation. It was going to save the industry something like $15m-probably $150m today. What happened to it? It got buried because the Australian Wool Corporation tried to get its own friends in the Sunbeam Corporation to produce it instead of the company in Western Australia. Sunbeam was never able to do it, so that innovation-I believe one of the best-never hit the market. That company struggles on. That innovation makes shearing much easier, and it is going to be one of the things-when it is fully exploited-that keeps the cap on the increasing price of shearing. But that is what we have got from the Wool Corporation over the years-vested interests and dishonesty and pandering to friends.

We are now faced with a problem. I am not happy about this particular piece of legislation. The nub of it is this: we are going to enter into a free market system where there is no floor in the price of wool, where we are likely to have a very large rush of wool to the market because I believe it is going to be very difficult to stop people shearing before June, and certainly it is going to be a lot harder than has been indicated to me by members of the Opposition.
