There will still be playing in the field, muddying the water, the Australian Wool Corporation. So there is uncertainty in the market.

Because we have had no futures market-and there cannot be a futures market where there is a floor-no-one really knows what the price is. So all those uncertainty factors are present. There is no doubt the auction system will set the price, but it will do it in a very bloody fashion. I believe it would have been far better to delay wool sales until we get a futures market going so we can get some guidelines for price.

I might say in respect of price that we have had the Wool Corporation touting its figure, saying, `Oh, it will go to 200c' and that wool is finished for five to seven years. This is coming out of the Minister's own Department. I say to this House, to this country and to the wool growers of this country that there is no validity in those figures; they are as good as any plucked out of the air. I believe the indications coming out of Europe are that prices will be substantially better than this and, if markets can be increased, I believe that we could get back on track inside 12 months-back on the indicator line with the present 700c indicator. The Minister, who uses Andy Stoeckel's figures, will say the indicator line is 665c. My calculations are that it is in fact 695c. Whatever it is, it is not substantially worse than the present floor price, but substantially better than the prices that are being predicted.

I see no reason why wool should not return to its long term position of about 2 1/2 times the price of cotton. The only thing that will stop this is uncertainty in the market, and the fact that the Wool Corporation has allowed wool to be substituted. This substitution took place the very second that wool hit 870c on the way down. We are going to have to buy that market back, and buy it back with cheap wool.

We are told by the Wool Corporation that the demand for 21-25 micron wool is simply not there. I believe this is a nonsense. I believe this is the backbone of the Australian wool industry, and we are going to have to find markets for this. I can tell the Minister and honourable members opposite that there will be a hell of a lot more 19-micron wool on the market next year. There are a lot of people in Australia with the capacity to starve two microns off their sheep, and they will do it. We will see what that does to the price of 19 micron wool. Quite clearly, the wool that is being bought in substitution from South America, South Africa and New Zealand is not much better than 25 microns-probably a lot worse. So it is nonsense to say that the demand for such wool is not there. I believe the Wool Corporation has made a fetish of microns, and the people I speak with in the trade tell me that length, strength and texture or feel are much better and much more important than simply a micron measurement.

We are going to have to look at marketing because it has been a dismal failure. Something like $200m a year has gone into marketing for a continued loss of market share. It is an indictment. Zenna Ernenegildo in Italy, which makes very fine worsted material- the sort of material that gives one that Keating look-refuses to use Woolmark because it says it detracts from the quality of its product. Anything that uses pure wool can use the Woolmark. Zenna Ernenegildo says that its quality of wool is better than that. Zenna Baraussa, on the other hand, succumbed to a bribe from the International Wool Secretariat (IWS) and accepts $75,000 a year to use the Woolmark. It has nothing to do with promotion-it is thinly disguised as an advertising subsidy. It is simply a bribe which the IWS gives these people so it can come back to Australian growers and say, `Look, we have got these high class people to use it'.

It is interesting that of the 19-odd companies producing high fashion, high quality knitted goods on the English-Scottish border only one uses Woolmark, and that by default. They have not succumbed to offers from the IWS to be paid to use the Woolmark. We have a lot of questions to answer about marketing.

I believe one of the great tragedies is the blend market. Back in 1973, when I was a wool grower, we were told the United States was the biggest per capita user of fibre in the world. It was the smallest per capita user of wool. Twenty years and $200m a year later it is exactly the same. Nothing has changed. We have to get into the blend market, because that blend market will absorb a lot of that wool which the Wool Corporation says will not sell. I believe that with initiative we can do that.

We have to set about getting stability back into the stockpile. I have consistently maintained that the Government should buy the stockpile. I believe this because nobody but the Government can stabilise it; nobody trusts us with the Wool Corporation. Had the gutless individuals opposite come in here with a motion that the Government acquire the stockpile, they would have seriously embarrassed me because it would have been difficult not to have voted for it. But they did not have the nerve to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't have. You would have failed in the end. You are all talk.
—In this instance, I probably would because it is more important that I remain in the Labor Party and try to get some rationale into this debate than make a cheap hero of myself.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the Opposition has done nothing. It has simply applied another $200m. I believe that the Wool Corporation should be swept away. The Minister says that he was concerned that the members of the board of the Corporation did not resign and leave the Corporation without any management structure. I think it would be a terrible pity if members of the board resigned before we could sack them. Getting rid of the board does not get rid of the structure of the Corporation. That would go on. I believe that Jim Young is a good technician. He does understand what needs to be done and would probably function better if he was under the instruction of a receiver rather than a board which does not seem to know what it is doing.

The truth is that we as a Government have a responsibility because we did not stop the price being put to 870c and that was the cause of our dilemma. We do have a responsibility. The cheapest option for the taxpayer is to buy the stockpile now. There is no reason to doubt, although nobody really knows, that if the stockpile were bought now wool would be back on the trend line in 12 months and we could actually make money on it. In any case, the loss would not be all that great. I would support the price of wool until 30 June by selling the Corporation's assets. It would require an advance from the Department of Finance but I think we should sell the Corporation's assets. I am certainly rather taken to the idea of paying out the additional sum at the end of June when it has been averaged out.

The Opposition has come in here with a very small amendment, one which I certainly would not support because it is meaningless. It certainly does nothing for the industry. We have to make a level playing field for the merchants. We have to assure the merchants that never again will the Wool Corporation be able to get in there and compete with them. How can one compete with a corporation that has lost $1.2 billion of growers money? When it has that sort of money to play with it is no good to stockpile the wool. It has been sunk and lost. How can anyone compete on those terms? We have to let the trade know that never again will that happen.

We have to develop immediately, as I said earlier, subsidiary instruments such as the futures market. We have to establish around the futures market things like the options. Options need a buyer and a seller. They work on a catalyst model called the Black and Scholes pricing equation. It enables long term positions to be taken up where it is possible to work in the actual physical market and in the futures market. It enables people to cushion themselves against buying mistakes and against futures variations. It is an essential component. These are the sorts of things that cannot work where we have a Wool Corporation and a floor price. These things must be done and I would urge the Minister to do everything possible to make sure that they are done as soon as possible.

In the time left to me I wish to touch on something the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said about the wool scour in Western Australia. He was talking about Australian wool processors. They have built without a doubt the most modern, technically advanced wool scour in the world. It is one of only seven. It uses a de smitt process. It is true that Michael Hodgson put $9m of his own money into this venture, a very gutsy decision. It is true that he got caught up by the Wool Corporation putting in the 870c price and no wool being available. It is also true that his bank has not had the courage that in my view it should have had, but then that is the history of banks in Australia.

The Wool Corporation has not supported his scour. As it was supporting scours all over Australia, I wrote asking whether it could support him. It wrote back and said, `Oh, no, it's a situation where they entered this on their own initiative and they have an inferior product'. That rather took me back. I then went to the Wool Corporation's technical people and asked them to assess the product. They told me that it was an absolutely top product, one of the best in the world, the best they had seen. In many cases, they thought it was superior to the aqueous system.

I then got back in touch with the Wool Corporation which restated its belief that it was an inferior product. I asked what the Corporation thought of its technical people and of course I was told that they were excellent. I then faxed the Corporation a letter from its technical people. I heard that its technical people got into some trouble over this. This is the sort of thing we have had to put up with from the Wool Corporation. I believe that Australian wool processors have an action against the Wool Corporation and they should pursue it. The Wool Corporation has sabotaged a very valuable asset to Australia that will probably fall into foreign hands for a song.

If we are to have a wool industry in this country we have to look not at an ever decreasing amount of wool but increasing amounts of wool. The fibre market has increased dramatically over the last few years. The amount of cotton sold has increased. The amount of silk sold has increased. Only wool has declined. People say, `But you couldn't predict Russia'. Russia has continued to use cotton in quite large volumes, as has China. We have had a marketing stuff-up of enormous proportions. It has been a very expensive marketing debacle. It has been paid for by the Australian wool producers and they deserve better. But they have been kept in ignorance by the Wool Corporation. The Wool Corporation has made a fetish of faith-one must have faith! Some of it we heard from the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). We have heard no facts. The Corporation has denied facts to the industry. The industry has been kept in darkness.

My office actually photocopied 800 copies of the Stoeckel report-we breached his copyright-and sent them out to growers. Growers told me that it is the only information they ever had. I think Stoeckel's statistical stuff is very good. His marketing stuff is off-beam. It is an academic assessment; it is not in the real world. The rest of it is excellent material. I know that the many growers we sent this report to were very grateful to get it because, as they said, it was the first time they had ever had any information on the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one thing I have noticed about the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) is that he is consistent. He consistently sinks anyone who happens to be anywhere near the wool industry, as far as I can see. He sank the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, Mr Beggs and its past Chairman, Mr Asimus, whose name he got wrong. He sank almost everybody, including the International Wool Secretariat, the Ilkley research station, no doubt Isha Namiya in Japan, and everybody else that he could get his dog around.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the only thing we can say about him is that his consistency, as in many other occasions, has its exception. He managed to leave the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) unscathed. Sadly, we are now in the process of dismantling a scheme which was introduced in 1974. The reserve price scheme, as we have known it for a long time, is over. I believe it is a sad fact but, nevertheless, it is a fact. I have been a floor price supporter since its inception but I have to say not a supporter of the scheme which it has become in the last few years.

I would like to read a clause from the original Wool Industry Act which was introduced in 1972. That was before the 1974 settling of the reserve price scheme, as we have known it over the last 14 years up to 1987 before it was changed by this Minister. One of the clauses says:

The Corporation shall, at fortnightly intervals, make reports to the Minister and the Treasurer concerning the operation of its reserve price scheme, and shall include in the reports such information as the Minister directs concerning-
(a) the reserve prices determined by the Corporation;
(b) wool purchased and wool held by the Corporation; and
(c) sales of wool by the Corporation and proposed offerings of wool by the Corporation.

There was in those early days a great attempt by government to make sure that the checks and balances were in the system. In 1987 those checks and balances were taken out to the point where we have the present debacle. I am not one who is critical of all the moves that this Government has made since it became apparent that the reserve price scheme was in trouble, but I believe that that was the turning point; that was the mistake, that was the point at which the checks and balances became ineffective-in fact, ceased to exist. That system allowed the industry effectively to set its own reserve price, leaving it taxing powers and borrowing powers. That changed the floor price system, which was a base price below which we would sell to no-one, to an aggressive reserve price scheme which finally failed. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:
. . . the minimum reserve price . . . had become an instrument for chasing the market.

How did that come about? If the Minister had not changed the legislation in 1987, it would not have come about. I leave honourable members with that thought, because I think it is something that is often overlooked when people are looking at where the responsibility for this action lies. The responsibility may not lie so much in the actions that were taken up until this latest piece of legislation; if we want to find the fault, we can look right into the centre of 1987.

It is vital that the Government take notice of the reservations that the Opposition has about this piece of legislation; they have been outlined by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and others. I would specifically like to draw the Minister's attention to two matters. Mr Beggs, in November, said that the most urgent problem faced by the Australian wool industry is to bring supply back in line with demand. Last June and July, after the reserve price was dropped to 700c, many of us on this side of the House looked long and deep at what was possible to actually bring about this equalising of the supply and demand equation. We had heard from some members of the Corporation that they were going to sell a lot more wool to America, which has not happened, and that the situation was looking optimistic in Russia, which has not happened. We had not heard from them that China was in recession at that point, nevertheless we knew that, whatever the demand side of the equation, we could not fix it instantly. That has been proven ever since, but anybody who knows anything about these industries knows there is no quick fix for demand-side problems and usually no quick fix for supply-side problems.

In the process of looking at that, we came up with a solution to part of the supply-side problem, which was a very unattractive slaughter scheme. After some time, the Corporation was persuaded to employ a consultant to look into a slaughter scheme. It is worth reading a couple of paragraphs from that consultants' report to the Corporation-a report that, I might say, has stayed buried somewhere in the archives of the Corporation for most of the last four or five months. The consultants said:

It goes without saying that even the consideration of such a scheme is unprecedented in the wool industry. The notion of destroying millions of sheep, particularly young and otherwise productive sheep, is anathema to the majority of woolgrowers and indeed other Australians. It is simply a measure of the parlous state of the industry at present and in prospect.
They knew the horror of what they were proposing. But they then went on to say:
It is ACIL's judgment-
that is, the consultants' judgment-
that a flock reduction scheme provides the wool industry with its best, and probably its last, hope of retaining 20 years of investment in wool marketing via the reserve price scheme.

Tonight the Opposition has been accused to some extent-and it was accused the other day in a matter of public importance-of not contributing to this debate. However, it has also been said that we have taken a somewhat bipartisan view on the matter of this whole problem. That is true. We supported the Government in its reduction of the floor price; we supported the Government in its 20 per cent levy. We did not support the Government, I have to say, on its quota scheme, because we knew that those in the industry would not pick it up and would not like it-and they did not. We knew that it would not work. That scheme, of course, has gone out the window very quickly. And we did not support the 50 per cent levy. But we supported the major thrust of other legislation.

However, when we said to the Government, `Listen, you have to get the supply side under control', it took not the slightest notice. Admittedly, the Wool Corporation, after much twisting and turning, brought in what we could only describe as a half-assed scheme. It offered growers $1.80 for some old sheep and $6 for some young sheep, then changed it under a different contract-quite cleverly, I think-and offered them $5 the next time. That contract is still running. I understand that as of this afternoon it is the Corporation's view that 10 million sheep will be signed up for disposal or sale to the trade under that scheme. Whether it is true or not that all 10 million sheep finally disappear, the fact of the matter is that to get 10 million sheep out for an average cost of $3.70 is quite a surprising result. In fact, it is a very good result.

I notice that, in the second reading speech and other press releases made by the Minister surrounding this piece of legislation, it seems as though any further scheme will go. With descriptions of such schemes as being silver bullet schemes, with criticism of them because of the public relations effect in European newspapers, and with the problem of animal liberation and so on, some people, even on our side, have problems with the scheme. But other things much worse are happening in the world, especially in the Middle East, and I do not think that anybody is focusing too much on whether we get rid of 10 million sheep or 30 million sheep. I ask the Minister-I almost drop my dignity to the point of pleading with him-to get somebody to look at the possibility of using some of this money to make a final offer to wool growers at $8 to $10 apiece to get another 20 million sheep out. If it fails, the Government has not spent a cent; if it succeeds, it will certainly make a difference to the supply side of the equation coming up to the next selling season and to some extent thereafter.

I now turn to the matter of the deficiency payment. The way this deficiency payment is structured in this Bill is open ended. This has been mentioned several times already today. It could mean an extra $700m of debt added to the debt already owed by the Australian Wool Corporation on behalf of growers. We do not know; we have no idea where the market will be. But we know that there is no incentive under this scheme as we have presently seen it-although I understand that a few documents, marks 1, 2 and 3, were floating around during the weekend, and no doubt there will be some more-to attempt to influence growers to put some reserve on themselves, which, as people will know, has been in the past, and to some extent still is, even under the reserve price scheme, a part of the marketing system. Growers quite often put reserves on various lots of wool; it is something that they should be able to do if they want to, as well as using other systems.

But under this scheme, as initially announced, there is no incentive-or there has not been up until now-for a grower to do other than to throw his wool on the market, knowing that the difference between what it makes and 700c will be made up by the Government. Under that scheme, if it is true that we have 2 1/2 million bales to come in this four months in a historical market of 1 1/2 million bales, it seems to me and many other onlookers that it may well be that the deficiency is somewhere around $1 billion.

Okay, the Government is throwing in $300m. I have no conscience about that because the Government has a lot of wool growers' tax money. Having taken the income equalisation deposit scheme away some time ago and being clever enough to put it back after the end of the financial year 1989-90-another $6 billion wool year-it has plenty of potential IED money that could be being redeemed by growers this year had that scheme not been removed for, in my view, all the wrong reasons. So $300m would be much more than covered.

Some of the calculations-admittedly amateur because they necessarily have to be-would show that $500m could possibly have gone into IEDs in the last two financial years, 1988-89 and 1989-90. We will never know that, but I have no conscience about the Government throwing $300m into this deficiency payment scheme.

But what I do have a problem with is that, as it appears up until now to be open-ended, perhaps another $400m, $500m, $600m or $700m will be added to the $2.8 billion of debt-or at least the Minister seemed to think so because he announced in his press release that he wanted to increase the borrowing limits to $3.5 billion-and this will increase the growers' debt from $2.8 billion to perhaps $3.5 billion with no further collateral, nothing else, to sell.

As was described earlier by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), where it might have been a reasonable equation to forgo the $1.7 billion or $1.8 billion of growers' equity in the fund so as to leave the external debt at $2.8 billion and then to try to work one's way through the sale of the product, the 4.8 million bales, making sure in the process that it is locked up for a determined period-we are suggesting at least a year; and then after that the arrangements would be very transparent so that nobody would think the wool was going out through the back door-it seems to me that if we do that and the debt gets to $3.5 billion we will have a much greater chance of sinking that scheme as well. Not to exaggerate the point, it seems to me that this system of a deficiency payment with no bottom to it and a semi-infinite capacity to increase the debts of the Corporation is very unsatisfactory.

As I understand it, many people-in the Government, in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and in other places-have known for the last four months that there was a fair chance that this scheme would go. It must have been possible in that time to think up some sort of a system whereby the growers at least were encouraged to put a reserve price on their wool. That and the original problem of extra debts sinking the market support fund are the only reasons why we have suggested that the Government cap this debt. It must cap the debt. We could have picked a dollar figure, but what is important is that it cap the debt because otherwise it seems that-with no further collateral; nothing else to sell; no further wool-it is making it nearly impossible for the Corporation to get out from under that financial burden.

I mentioned a little while ago that it is terribly important that the arrangements for the disposal of the stockpile be transparent. There have been so many rumours around that people really do not trust the Australian wool industry in its totality any more. The only way that we can deal with that problem is to make it completely open.

I said earlier that I was in favour of the reserve price scheme. In fact I was an avid supporter of it. I have come to the conclusion however that the antics of the last two years by us all on this side of the water have meant that it will be impossible to get the purchasing side of this industry to trust us again. So what we have always been told will happen in the classical theory of cartels has come about; that is, they work for a while until human beings mess them up. We have finally made that come true, and it is very sad for me and many people in the industry that that has happened.

I just make one final plea: I ask the Minister to think about the supply side of this problem, knowing that the demand side will be slow to recover. I know that there are proposals to put wool into China and Russia. I know that we have marketing people going around the world looking at all those things. They may happen. But, if we do not get rid of the supply side problem, solutions to the demand side problem can be as good as we like but the overall problem will take several extra years to solve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a wool growing constituency. Indeed, the last time I spoke in this House on this matter I was criticised by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) because I dared to say at that time that perhaps not only did we have to consider the supply side problems, which have been outlined by the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), but also it was very important that consideration be given to demand and that in previous debates perhaps we were not considering that enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I do have an interest of course because my brother is a wool grower-a somewhat misguided one I might say; he is a member of the National Party of Australia. But I must say that he is a sincere and hardworking farmer, and this situation is a serious one. I became involved in the debate because I realised the importance of wool to our economy and to Australia. I believed that it was something that one should get a handle on.

We have heard today some monumental hypocrisy from honourable members on the other side of the House. The honourable member for Barker said that he was sad to see the demise of the floor price scheme. He quite rightly pointed out that this problem probably began when the Wool Corporation started to set its own price, when the industry became the voice for wool growers and when those controls which had previously been put in place by the Government were removed and the Corporation began to move in a way which was inconsistent with the market trend for wool not only in Australia but elsewhere. Because of Australia's pre-eminence in the market, that was a very important part of that price equation.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) came in here today and said that he would have said what he wanted to say today before but he could not get the opportunity to speak because of the use of the guillotine in the past. He suggested that the issue was too big for politics, but indeed what he came in here to do today was play politics.

The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) suggested that it was vandalism on the part of those who considered that the Wool Corporation should be sacked and disbanded. One needs to consider that the way in which this industry has been managed by the Wool Corporation over the last two or three years could be called vandalism. We should also consider the way in which the Corporation has been inconsistent in its treatment of the equation-which we all understand when we talk about markets-in relation to the difference between supply and demand.

In the last debate the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) talked about the demand side. I must admit that when I heard him speaking in this place I believed he would perhaps say something about price. He talked about tariff changes, production and EFIC-Export Finance and Insurance Corporation-cover for national interest in countries where there were difficulties in paying for the wool, but he was unable to bring himself to say anything about the price of wool. Honourable members on the other side, all of them with wool growing constituencies, stood in a row and to a man were unwilling to say anything about this measure which has become necessary because we have reached the stage where we have to buy back our share in the market.

There are unforeseen circumstances which have produced this necessity, some of which are beyond our control. What has happened in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, China and the circumstances in the Middle East are all things which perhaps could not have been predicted and are certainly outside our control. But it is very clear, I think, that the signals which were sent to farmers by the Wool Corporation-signals that were sent because of the price and the way in which it escalated-led farmers to believe they should increase their supply. That was an important message, and the Corporation has to answer for that. When speaking with my brother about the circumstances in which he found himself, the one thing he continually said was that there was no information provided: the developing circumstances were not explained to farmers and there was no possibility of knowing how things had changed.

I do not believe, as some others have suggested, that the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill will be temporary legislation. What we see here is a landmark initiative; an initiative which brings about a change in the way that wool will be marketed in the future. I do not believe we will find ourselves going back over the territory of the reserve price scheme because there is no possibility of going back that way. The transition that will occur during the next period when we are trying to sell the surplus wool will be very painful. I believe, whichever way one looks at it, there will not be any simple solution.

When we came into this place in November and discussed legislative measures to bring about a number of changes relating to an increase in the levy to 25 per cent, a reduction in the reserve price to 700c, flock reductions schemes, borrowing by government and monitoring, we believed that the sums would add up and that if we were able to get an improvement in the sales it would be possible to skate through and for the allocation relating to supply and demand for wool to be rebalanced. There were indications that quotas would be considered as a possibility. But, for a number of reasons, they were widely rejected, and I support that view.

There was an approach in relation to the slaughtering of sheep in order to reduce the supply side. Indeed, to some extent, I think that there has been some success in that regard. But one wonders about this, because the attitude of many farmers to lower prices is to increase production. Sooner or later in these circumstances-in any circumstances like this-it is necessary to bite the bullet. This legislation-which, as I have already said, I do not believe will be temporary-will change the future of selling wool in this country for as far ahead as we can see.

Whichever way one looks at it, we have a huge stockpile of wool and it will take some time for that to wash through the system. The messages that will be sent out will be on the demand side because wool will be competing with those other fibres which perhaps can be substituted for wool. The price of wool will also send out messages on the supply side to the farmers who will understand where they should allocate their resources. It is not something that will happen quickly, so we have to expect that there will be some pain.

I have some reservations about this legislation. I am particularly concerned about the fact that the Australian Wool Corporation at the last minute did an about-face, changed its approach and accepted that it was necessary to remove the floor price scheme. So we find that it is essentially still holding the reins. That causes me some concern. It is a sobering thought, and I am comforted by the fact, that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) will be in a position to be able to direct and scrutinise the Corporation's activities. But I am concerned that we now find the arsonist in charge of the fire brigade. It is something which I believe we need to watch very closely.

I am concerned also about the support scheme-or the deficiency payment scheme-because it is clear that there may be early shearing by farmers and a glut of wool coming on the market as a result of these deficiency payments being available until the end of this financial year. It is a worry that this could cause distortion and, in fact, militate against an appropriate market price being established.

I think also there are salutary lessons that we should learn from all of this. The first is that cartels, over time, cannot be expected to be successful and that markets must be sensitive to price. We need to contemplate this when we consider other initiatives. I notice in the media that there are discussions about a reserve price for wheat and I believe this experience should be very sobering; it is an experience that should tell us that we cannot contemplate such an approach in respect of that commodity. I think there is a message in this situation and it is pleasing that we find assistance provided for research. Marketing and research are critical if we are to sell our products overseas. Too many Australians, no matter what they are producing, do not allocate resources to marketing and research in a manner which will enable them to be the most efficient sellers of their goods overseas. In respect of wool, when one looks at the size of our share of the American market one can only conclude that our marketing expertise and effort in that country has been a failure. When one looks at the way in which we have been affected by this crisis, it is critical that we look at being more successful in marketing our wool in the future.

The final lesson is clear to all of us who are concerned about industry policy in this country-that is, that we should be considering approaches with regard to processing our wool and selling our product overseas. Many honourable members who have spoken in the debate have mentioned that and many of them have made salient points. The important thing is that finally the bullet has been bitten in respect of wool and the way in which we market wool. This decision is a watershed decision, and it is to be hoped that in the future we will see a stabilisation of a market price which rewards farmers adequately and enables us to sail through this very difficult period so that when we come out on the other side we have a market which provides for wool assurances into the future and provides wool growers with the opportunity to continue to do what they want to do as farmers.
