SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first day of February 1991 was an historic day for the wool industry when the reserve price scheme was over. The Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) suspended sales on that day as credit facilities from the Government had run out. This concluded 25 years of vigorous debate in the wool industry. I declare my interest as a wool grower, having participated in that debate since 1965. In 1965 the wool growers rejected a reserve price scheme. We should remember that fact. Fifty-nine thousand wool growers voted against the scheme and 51,000 voted in favour of a reserve price scheme at that time. Sir William Gunn, who has now appeared out of retirement to defend his scheme, was very vigorous in the debate at that time. During those debates concerns were expressed about the possible outcome if market forces were not obeyed in the selling of wool.

SPEECH.PARA: I go into the history of the scheme. In the 1970s wool prices were very low. A reserve price scheme, having been rejected by growers, was again introduced as a mechanism to help even out the fluctuations of wool prices. With government funds, a reserve price was instituted in October 1970. In 1971 the wool industry reached a very low point in terms of wool prices. In 1972-73 the present reserve price scheme was introduced by the McMahon Government and then later revised by the Whitlam Government. Up until 1988 there were two comparatively minor build-ups of stockpiles-one in 1975-76 and the other in 1985-86. As predicted by earlier critics, this gave confidence to the reserve price scheme operation that these stockpiles could be moved aside with the passage of time. This further added to the confidence of the reserve price scheme protagonists.

In the boom psychology of 1988-89, when 1,200c clean was the price being received for the better grades of wool, the reserve price was moved from 550c clean to 870c. Political self-interest of the Australian Wool Council in setting a price of a world commodity was very much in evidence when setting this reserve price. The reserve price scheme became an aggressive price setter, not a potholing, low price operation as it was first intended. One of the main causes of this dramatic change was the nexus between the Wool Council and the Australian Wool Corporation.

Political considerations overcame any rational assessment of the long term market trend. One of the problems in setting the reserve price at the high level was that thereafter people said that we could not have an open debate because we would destroy confidence in the wool industry. In my view blame could be sheeted home to a number of growers in New South Wales, who increased their production by 48 per cent and were instrumental in pushing this reserve price to a very high level. Of course, under these circumstances the reserve price scheme broke down.

Over the last week the Chairman of the Wool Corporation has publicly given the following reasons for the reserve price breakdown: the high prices received during the boom times; speculation over the reduction from the 870c to 700c reserve price figures; China going out of the market; record Australian production; the world economy slowing down; and, of course, the movement out of the wool market by the Europeans and the Soviets because they lacked the cash resources to buy.

In simple terms, the reserve price scheme brought about the situation where wool growers were buying their own product, paying the interest and paying the storage charges on the wool that they bought. In recent months the Wool Corporation has been buying anything from 35 per cent to 70 per cent of the offering.

The coalition, on the other hand, gave the reserve price every chance to operate. With great reservations, the coalition supported the change from 870c to 700c. It supported the Government's credit arrangements. It put forward the positive proposal of a flock reduction scheme, and, of course, it threw out the idea of having quotas because it knows that quotas will not work. Unfortunately, the growers were not aware of the big figures, so they were not fully informed on all the arguments about the reserve price at that time. Most growers believed the myth that the reserve price would protect their price from market fall.

The problem with the reserve price is that the supply situation continues and the demand factors send no signals to the wool growers. Good seasons over the last few years have indicated a very strong supply situation, and growers continue to produce, disregarding the true market situation. The cost of the reserve price scheme is considerable: the cost of running the Australian Wool Corporation, the $2.8 billion borrowings, the $1.8 billion of grower funds that have been injected into the scheme, the interest involved, the storage, and the administration. The monopoly of the AWC, of course, under the reserve price scheme meant that there was no futures market indicating trends in the wool market prices. The AWC, under the reserve price scheme, had total control of the system. The political and commercial considerations became confused in any debate about the future of the reserve price scheme. Of course, there were no other options available under these arrangements.

The cost of marketing wool in 1990, in comparison with the cost of marketing cotton, draws to the House's attention quite a considerable difference. The cost of marketing wool, according to the AWC's own sources, is about 107c greasy compared with 35c per kilogram LNT for cotton. The costs are incorporated in shipping, buying, research and development, and taxes. Of course, in regard to wool, taxes move from 8 per cent to 18 per cent to 25 per cent, with the statutory possibility of up to a 40 per cent tax in order to look after the wool industry, if that can be construed as being of any help. Other costs involve selling charges, warehousing and transport.

Innovative marketing arrangements were not encouraged. There was no incentive to change the process because all these arrangements under the reserve price scheme and the monopoly position of the AWC were very cosy. The AWC was not flexible in responding to any price signals because of the considerable political pressures in the field. The Wool Council of Australia, the Victorian Farmers Federation, the National Farmers Federation and the growers in everyone's electorates were dealing with the myths of the reserve price. No real figures were available, as I said, because everyone was concerned that any real debate about the reserve price might destroy this mythical confidence.

Further, the risks were all taken by the growers. They had the stockpile; they were paying the costs involved. The risks of the whole wool chain were not spread down the line. I refer, for example, to the exchange rate. There were also risks and incentives required for processors to upgrade their equipment. The wool growers took it upon themselves to look after the buffer stocks or the total wool scheme and moved it away from other people in the wool chain, which was so important.

I have referred to the fact that the reserve price scheme is finished; it is not just suspended. Anyone in the wool industry fully understands that. I do not understand why the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is suggesting that it is just suspended in a temporary manner. The stockpile is now standing at 4.8 million bales. The great problem facing the wool industry is what to do with the stockpile. I suggest that it be frozen for a year; that there be a selling program on a predictable basis; that the basis be clear and transparent so that buyers throughout the world can understand exactly what is happening to the stockpile. Maybe this should be incorporated in legislation so that buyers can have confidence. The stockpile should be drip fed on to the market at a predictable rate to be determined after the next three or four months, when we can see what might happen to the market. That will be a very difficult commercial operation. I do not think woolgrowers underestimate that problem.

The other problems facing the stockpile are the massive problem of storage and, of course, the interest payments on the money involved. Another problem that is facing the wool industry is the fact that we are now half way through the next production year, with another big wool clip coming forward to be sold in the current season. That will provide storage difficulties.

The debt which other honourable members have referred to of $2.8 billion, which is government guaranteed, is the amount of money that the Australian Wool Corporation has borrowed so that it can continue the operation of the floor price scheme. Obviously, that amount has been borrowed at commercial rates by the AWC, but enjoying the government guarantee arrangements. It should be noted that the growers have contributed $1.8 billion to the purchase of the stockpile. Most growers, the AWC and commentators agree that these growers' funds have now dissipated into the reserve price scheme and will never be seen again. The total debt will probably reach about $3 billion, depending on one's guess. I draw to the attention of the House and all wool growers around Australia that, at an interest rate of 14 per cent, future wool growers will be up for $420m per annum in servicing that debt.

With regard to the deficiency payments which the Minister is trying to bring forward in terms of equity-and the coalition supports that view-the Government has put forward $300m to contribute to the deficiency payment scheme. In my view, this is a de facto reserve price mechanism. The total payments could reach $700m, $800m or $900m, depending on what the price of wool is in the open market. Of course, in this situation there is no wool in a stockpile as collateral for this extra payment of debt either by the Corporation or by the Government. Because of the change of rosters in the wool selling season, we have 2 1/2 million bales to be sold when the market is for about 1 1/2 million bales.

The plan put forward by the Minister brings forward no firm policy. The deficiency payment that I have just referred to could easily be overspent, depending on the prices that emerge. The stockpile dissipation arrangements are not clear and that stockpile figure overhangs the market. The buyers will now operate in the open market, with no clear criteria as to the way in which they might place their valuations next week.

The great pain and suffering of wool growers in the short term has been caused by the overoptimistic reserve price. We will be reviewing this situation in June. There are always difficulties, when we move from a controlled market situation to a free market, in the transition period. We saw that in the tin industry around the world when it reached a similar situation to that of the wool industry. It had a monopoly position and it overdid it. We also saw this in regard to the egg quotas in New South Wales, where the Greiner Government had to buy out the producers at, I think, $60m. With regard to the fresh milk quotas in Victoria and New South Wales, when they moved from a restricted market situation to an open market, it cost the governments a lot of money. Likewise, when the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries cartel changed from a monopoly position to a free market it caused a great amount of pain amongst producers who thought they could hold the market to ransom.

A return to free and open market competition is the only strategy for the survival of the wool industry in the long term. The sooner the Government, the AWC and wool growers around Australia understand that and adopt that strategy, the sooner the Australian wool industry will return to profitability and prosperity for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a wool grower, I declare my interest in this legislation. I also declare my concern for all those wool growers in Australia who henceforth will have their income more than halved as a result of the downturn in the market and the successive measures which this Government has either taken or failed to take over the last few years. I know that many see the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill as almost inevitable. I do not. I think for a long while the Government has looked to excess at the arithmetic of a scheme which has more and more looked into itself. Any scheme which is going to acquire a product and not let that product go out to the marketplace must fail. My worry has been that, with regard to the arithmetic of trying to maintain the successive minimum reserve price (MRP) at 870c and then 700c, by calculating the level of the stockpile, the rate of acquisition and the funding of it, there was inevitably going to be an equation which led to an impossible situation, unless one was prepared at the same time to look at ways by which one could get wool back out of the stockpile.

SPEECH.PARA: Roughly, there are four markets for wool: the European market, the Japanese market, the Soviet Union and eastern European market, and the Chinese market. For about three years the Soviet Union and China were buying approximately 25 per cent of the clip. One of the tragedies over the last two years has been the extent to which those two countries-I am including eastern Europe with the Soviet Union-have largely withdrawn from the market. The product of that has been that the wools that those countries significantly bought, which were in the 22- to 24-micron range, have been the wools that have been going to a greater degree than others into the stockpile, and I am concerned greatly at the effect that the decisions of the Government through this legislation will have on the producers of those wools.

An average price per bale of $800 has been received in the last few years. Leaving out the two or three bale lots that come from the average backyard farmer or those who might have a relatively small flock, the average clip is somewhere between 30 and 70 bales. Take a 50-bale clip. For a big percentage of farmers, not just wool growers but farmers through a large stretch of Australia, the income from those 50 bales is critical to their income. Those 50 bales at $800 cost somewhere between $300 to $350 per bale per year to produce. As a result of the downturn in markets and the failure to promote and sell wool, farmers are now going to get about $400 a bale. Their margin, as I assess it, will be about $50 a bale, and $50 multiplied by 50 bales gives a very, very small margin indeed on which to survive, and that is without regard to the figures of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and the arithmetic that it presented at the recent National Agricultural and Resource Outlook Conference.

I want to look firstly at that arithmetic because there has been a significant drop in wool incomes, and that drop is paralleled by the same drop as is occurring in wheat. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), who sits beside me, said to me earlier today that he was concerned that in our concentration on wool we must not forget that other rural industries are also suffering.

In relation to wheat, there too is an enormous problem. Of course, export enhancement, common agricultural policy and a range of other international marketing additions are affecting wheat. But neither in wool nor in wheat should we place the blame alone on those export markets. In wheat as in wool it is the Government and the actions by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that have exacerbated the present position.

In wheat we are now in a position where, instead of having in our domestic marketing arrangements an underwriting scheme and a 90 per cent-plus first advance, they have gone. All this is happening with wheat at a time when the United States is enhancing its export enhancement program and at a time when we have seen the lack of preparedness of the Europeans to adjust their agricultural subsidies in the failure of the negotiations within the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

So a large percentage of rural Australia-and I left out the horticultural industries, which are also suffering-is going to have a significant drop in rural incomes this year. That is going to affect land values, and as land values fall-and 40 per cent of bank advances around Australia under the general credit worthiness of banks are predicated on rural mortgages-there is going to be an inevitable adverse consequence on the securities those banks hold and that will prejudice much of the financial system of Australia. Therefore, we have a drop in income, a drop in land values and an effect on the financial system. From there we start looking back at what is going to happen to employment, small business, service industries, farm machinery distributors and all those other people in the rural community. In days gone by Australian manufacturers would have provided the tractors and built the farm machinery; but that of course is no longer so. So the Government might say, `Imports will fall'. What is happening is that that chain is now significantly changed because of this Bill and because of what is happening in the rural industry.

People need to know that it is not price alone that is the necessary catalyst for selling wool-price is only one of the measures. There are many other aspects: the quality and reliability of delivery, and all of those other things that have never been better because of the stockpile. We now have a range of wools, which in the marketing sense we have never had before. None of those things has been used to the advantage of the wool grower or the wool industry by this Minister or the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) over the last few months.

My concern is that we need to address, therefore, the whole dimension of the implications of what is happening. We also need to register that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been responsible for the high interest rate policy and, if price is the factor, the present value of the Australian dollar is at least as much a cause of the failure to sell wool as is the minimum reserve price.

Looking at the barometer of where that dollar has moved, we see that even since the Gulf war began the dollar has firmed. The dollar is at about 78c, somewhere about 13c above where it should be if it were to be based entirely on our export revenue. The dollar is held high because of the level of interest rates and the inflow of capital which influences so much of the pattern of financial trading in our currency but does not actually affect the real substance of our economy. The difficulty in Australia is that we have this adverse chronic balance of payments problem and we have a currency that is far too high. So do not let us talk only about the MRP; let us look at other factors. I have been fascinated that there has been no reference to that by the Treasurer-no reference to the fact that if the dollar were to come down then perhaps the MRP would have been able to be preserved.

My worry in this legislation, however, really goes back to the changes introduced in 1987. As the Minister who introduced the Australian Wool Corporation in legislation that I brought to this House in 1972-which was assented to on 31 October-I had in that legislation two clauses which the Minister removed in 1987. I am not going to read those clauses; I will refer to them and tell the House what they did. Importantly, the Government and the Minister are the cause of the failure of the minimum reserve price scheme to work. The scheme that I introduced was not one that set a market price. It was a scheme that was designed as a potholing scheme. It was a scheme designed to take the bottom out of the market.

Of course, there was a great deal of controversy at the time it was introduced, and I know the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) referred to it tonight. I have no doubt that there were many at the time the scheme was introduced who felt that it was going to deprive the market forces of the opportunity to function as they should. It is fascinating that for so long it proved so successful, until the Minister changed the requirement of consultation with Treasury, removed ministerial control over the setting of the floor price and removed the requirement that the comparability of the wool price with that of other fibres be taken as a criterion in determining the market floor.

I say to all honourable members-and indeed to all those wool growers out there who are listening in tonight and who are concerned about this implication-that if they believe that a minimum reserve price scheme today has no merit, they should look at clauses 39 and 41 of the 1972 Bill because both of them provided controls which the Minister removed. I do not believe that second guessing the Australian Wool Corporation with the Wool Council worked. The nature of the involvement of the Wool Council has meant that the Corporation has not been able to get out and do its job as it must or as it should, and it has been compounded by market circumstances, which we all acknowledge are a part of the problem.

Where do we go and what do we do? All I want to do is get back to finding how we sell our wool to those countries who today are not buying it. If that 25 per cent of the market that takes the 22-to 24-micron wools could again be encouraged, it would enormously help the sales of wool through the stockpile. There is no perfect scheme. I wrote to all members of the Wool Council before their Launceston meeting and I set down a range of proposals. I do not pretend they are perfect, but some things still gall me.

Do honourable members know that there is still better than a 60 per cent tariff imposed on processed woollen goods imported into Australia? Where is the Minister's comment on that? We have Australian manufacturers who want protection, and I would give them a bounty. But above all, why the devil do we not help those wonderful Australian designers who want to buy superfine wool? Why do we not allow those who want to buy woollen goods made up in Australia to import the fabric if they wish? We do not because we apply this ridiculous tariff and all this rubbish about the Government doing all it can. It is nonsense.

There are a lot of other things. I have suggested export market development grants. I have talked about export finance insurance cover up to 100 per cent for notional interest which would enable wool to be sold into some of those eastern European countries and into China and the Soviet Union. I have talked about credit not only to the Soviet Union but also on a wider front. I have talked about ways by which the Government might even allow wool to go to manufacturers in those countries on credit terms, allow it to be sold in the processed form and then allow payment to be made at the end of that process.

If those ideas are not the right ones, Tom Hughes, in that excellent article he wrote for the Bulletin a week or two ago, referred to another two. There are plenty of ways by which we can stimulate sales, but of course that is not the only problem. We have to understand that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, out there with his hand on his chest, went around telling the wool trade of the world that the 700c was going to stick. I was delighted when he said it. But it is no use a Minister making such a guarantee-and indeed the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) echoed it in answer to a question from the honourable member for Gwydir-and then forsaking it.

I have a letter here from a wool buyer which says that our customers in Europe, Japan and worldwide are distressed. The Government's word has been broken. Now contracts to exporters are not being honoured; losses are going to be enormous to customers and exports. But the shame is on Australia and being an Australian where our word is worth nothing-and that is due to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

I think we need to understand that there have already been a range of requests from various wool importers for damages-and I say all of this with no prejudice to any legal action that might be taken. A range of importers and people in the wool trade are going to lose money because of the Minister's guarantee. The Japanese, the Europeans and the British have all been put in this position, and the Minister has not even said to them, `Look, I'm sorry; I couldn't sustain the MRP'. I am concerned that the Minister should say to them, `We had no option; we have had to terminate the MRP' and, further, `What I'm concerned about is that you come back and start buying wool again'.

There are a range of things that the Minister can do. I do not think that the former buyers deserve compensation, but I think they deserve stimulation. I want them to come in and buy and, unless we get those 22- to 24-micron wools bought, we are going to have a whole lot of growers who are not going to be able to sell half of their clip.

There is a great deal that I want to say but I do not have the time to say it. As far as this particular legislation is concerned, I am very concerned that there is nothing in it to stimulate sales of wool; nothing in it to placate in any way those buyers of wool. I believe that the MRP has been mishandled by the Minister, in particular, but sadly, to a lesser degree, by the Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool Council as well.

I think now, sadly, the time has come for us to change the membership of the Wool Corporation. I would like to see a marketing director and I would like to see more commercial members of that Corporation able to promote and sell our wool; but, above all, let us recognise that the role of the International Wool Secretariat (IWS) must be preserved. We have to maintain our research and development allocations and we have to capitalise on the market opportunities that are there.

Only a few months ago, I saw a new fur produced from wool, and that fur was being launched on the European market in the same week as the sheep reduction scheme was announced-and of course the media over there had this whole series of campaigns showing the bleeding woolmark, which was a total negative for wool. So a great deal can be done and is being done. We have to maintain the IWS and its effort.

I am not happy about the wool industry supplementary payments scheme. I think it is plagued with difficulties. It is quite impossible with that $300m the Government is providing to satisfy the shortfall for those whom, it has been suggested, probably will not even be able to sell their clips in the short term. There is a real problem in my view in the nature of the handling of the stockpile. I have not mentioned it, but I think what we have to do is have a sunset clause, and phase out the stockpile. We ought to make sure that we do not release the stockpile in such a way as to bear down on the market. We have to make sure that the stockpile is isolated in the short term. I think we ought to find a way by which then it can be progressively reduced to the point where it will go altogether because while it is there it is going to bear down on the market.

This piece of legislation is a difficult piece of legislation. It is not one which I think has been well drafted, as the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has identified. It is one which in panic has been brought in by the Minister. It is obviously not his preferred piece of legislation, but it is the Government's legislation. My concern is for the Australians I represent who I think as a result of the failure of this minimum reserve price scheme are going to be a lot worse off.

There is an enormous financial crisis now impending in rural Australia, and I do not believe this legislation, the Government's response to wool growers, to wool buyers or, for that matter, to those in the wheat industry or the horticultural industry, is good enough. It saddens me that, until the next Federal election, I cannot see that it is going to be corrected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share many of the concerns that have just been expressed by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). I think that the wool marketing support scheme as it was originally conceived and implemented in the early 1970s was a very good scheme that brought stability to the wool industry out of the chaos that had been a feature of the industry prior to that time. Unfortunately, the scheme that had been in operation for some considerable time has been brought into disrepute and has now been made unworkable, and in my view that has been caused by bad management and greed on the part of the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that much of the bad management of the industry has been caused by the Australian Wool Corporation, and I would in no way try to excuse the actions of the Wool Corporation itself. I think that in many ways not only have its actions been highlighted by bad management decisions and a lack of policy planning, but also it has been gravely incompetent in the way that it has misled the wool industry and the wool growers throughout Australia.

I know that part of the proposal now before the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is to replace the present Wool Corporation with an administrator and, to be frank with honourable members, I could think of nothing better because I have absolutely no faith whatever in the present Wool Corporation or the membership of that Corporation, and I would advocate to the Government that it should be sacked in total and replaced by some other body. If the only alternative is an administrator, then it should be an administrator that replaces the present Corporation.

I think that added to the incompetent management of the wool industry by the Wool Corporation has been the greed that has been expressed by the wool growers through the Wool Council of Australia. They have claimed a price for their product that has been unrealistic in the marketplace. They have claimed that price, it would seem to me, as a result of pressure by their bank managers based on the debts that they themselves have accumulated, but it bears no relationship whatever to the value of their product in the marketplace.

I would remind all wool growers and all honourable members of this House that any product, be it wool or anything else, is only worth what somebody else will pay for it. What the wool industry through the Wool Council and the Wool Corporation has done is to deceive itself that its product is worth more than the marketplace will pay for it.

What we need at the moment more than anything else is a selling scheme that will allow wool to be sold to the trade for a price that the trade will pay for it so as to allow wool to flow through the scheme from producer to end user on a free and open basis. That cannot happen while we have an interventionist scheme that decides that that product is worth more than the user will pay for it.

As a result of that intervention, as a result of bad management by the Corporation, as a result of greed on the part of the Corporation as expressed through the Wool Council, Australia has now accumulated a stockpile of close to five million bales of wool, with an accumulated debt in the wool industry of about $3 billion. My view is that that stockpile of wool will be a blot on our copybook and will distort the wool market for at least the next 10 years, because ultimately that five million bales stockpile of wool- albeit that it may be frozen on a short term basis-must ultimately be fed into the marketplace, and while it is being fed into the marketplace it will distort the future sales of wool.

Added to that, we have a situation where the wool industry, through the Wool Corporation, now has an accumulated debt close to $3 billion. That debt, most of which has been borrowed from overseas sources, is guaranteed by the Australian taxpayer. My view is that if the wool industry is allowed to sell its product to the market for whatever the market will pay, there will not be sufficient income generated through the wool industry to allow that debt to be repaid and at the same time allow wool producers to remain solvent. So ultimately the Government will be faced with the situation where either it forces a considerable number of wool growers to the wall and they become bankrupt because of the high taxes and levies that are imposed on their product or it passes on the debts that are accumulated by the Wool Corporation to the general body of taxpayers.

Although that decision may be delayed for some time, my view is that ultimately the Government will be forced into the situation where the debts of the Wool Corporation will be passed on to the general body of taxpayers. It is on that basis that nobody in Australia can claim to be distanced from the problems that are currently being experienced in the wool industry. All Australian taxpayers will be required to pay the debts that have now been accumulated.

In the long term, the ultimate objective of whatever scheme the Government or the wool industry develops should be that wool can be produced in Australia and allowed to flow through to the market and the end producers without any constraint. On that basis, I believe that the present market stabilisation scheme is probably dead because there is no way that the industry or any other person can intervene and claim that a product has a value higher than the marketplace can pay for it. The present scheme probably met its doom in 1987 when the wool industry, through the Corporation, decided that wool had a value of 870c a kilogram, albeit that a number of major buyers, in particular China and Russia, withdrew from the marketplace at that time, and that its product was worth more than the marketplace was prepared to pay for it. I think that was sad and we are now coming to the realisation that wool or any other product must be allowed to flow through to the market on a normal and orderly basis.

In the present circumstances, I think it is necessary for the stockpile of 4.8 million bales to be frozen because we will not get orderly marketing of the present clip of wool until that stockpile is frozen, although that stockpile must be allowed to flow through over an extended period of time which ultimately will distort the marketplace. Flowing on from that, the debts of the Corporation will not be able to be covered by wool growers. The tax levy will not be sufficient to cover the debts that have now been accumulated. It will be necessary for that to be passed on to the general body of taxpayers.

One solution that has been suggested in general discussion in Australia is that a flock reduction program ought to be put in place. There is no question that that will happen. Regardless of whatever scheme might be introduced by the Government, there is no question that the lack of returns will force a stock reduction program. The sad feature of the whole program is that I have heard many economists suggest that supply should be brought into line with demand. Plainly, if we gear up the wool industry to accommodate an increase in demand, supply of the product cannot be turned off. I am afraid that many city-based economists do not understand the simple fact of wool growing life that the sheep are still out grazing and at the end of the season must be shorn and that that shorn product will add to the stock of product. It is not good enough to say that we ought have a stock reduction program and think that 20 or 30 million sheep can suddenly be shot and removed from the scene. They cannot be removed; they will still be there producing wool and will still need to be shorn at the end of the season.

Whatever problems we have now with the wool industry will not be solved by this interim measure that the Government is now moving to bring in. It may help in the short term, but it will not solve the problems of the industry. While the Government may bring in these interim measures, I strongly suggest that it wait to determine its final position until the Vines committee of inquiry has had an opportunity to report. The Government should determine what its future strategy might be based on the recommendations of the Vines committee of inquiry.

I conclude by saying that I have personally totally lost confidence in the competence of the Australian Wool Corporation, and I strongly suggest to the Minister that the Wool Corporation be scrapped and replaced by an administrator. I have totally lost confidence in the recommendations that might come from the Australian Wool Council, because I believe the Wool Council has been motivated only by greed, and I do not believe that those are sufficient to be able to influence government policy. I strongly suggest to the Minister that the decision he makes be based on bringing long term stability to the wool industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last 12 months have been extremely stressful for wool growers. It is most regrettable that they have been starved of information about what has been going on in their industry. Major decisions have been made either by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) or by the Australian Wool Corporation. These decisions have been dropped on wool growers with little warning or explanation and, understandably, that has left them in a state of confusion and despair. A few days ago the Corporation suspended sales because it had simply run out of money and the Government would not guarantee it any more. That point ought to be made clear: the Corporation suspended the sales and the Minister, following upon that, suspended the reserve price scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: We are left with a situation today where growers now have difficulty believing anything that the Minister says after his statement that the 700c floor price is immutable. Growers also have difficulty believing anything that the Corporation says, particularly after its string of projections in its business plans that it has been putting to us over the last 12 months or so. The latest projection had a certain number of heroic assumptions in it-for example, that the Russians would come in as significant buyers before the end of the selling season and the 700c floor could be held with a 35 per cent tax and a 70 per cent quota. That would have returned growers something less than 320c a kilogram. Our calculations said that we probably would have needed at least a 40 per cent tax and a 60 per cent quota, which would have meant wool grower incomes after 1 July-if this were implemented-falling to 252c. So we would have had growers selling their wool to buyers at 700c and getting 252c in their pockets, which is a totally ridiculous and unsustainable situation.

On top of this, we have debt today at $2.9 billion and a market share for wool at an all time low. I find this loss of market share particularly distressing. After all, a cardinal rule of business has been violated. It appears that the wool reserve price scheme has gone the same way as all other primary industry floor schemes where supply could not be controlled in response to the higher than marketplace prices that were sought. We have seen this with coffee, cocoa, oil, tin, rubber and so on. Most of these schemes collapsed after about 15 to 20 years because those administering them lost sight of the original goal. I guess that when a scheme is running fairly well it is human nature to start using the floor price as a price setting scheme rather than a price smoothing scheme.

The history of the 20,000-odd commodities that are traded in the world show that at some stage in their life they have had a wide variation of price. Therefore, floor price schemes, given enough time-if they are inflexible-are going to be sorely tested. The wool reserve price scheme, if it had stayed on its long term trend line of about 580c, possibly could have held. I think that is a strong possibility. But the Minister handed over power to the Corporation a couple of years ago-and to his credit he admits it was a mistake-and we saw the price rise dramatically over a two-year period from 508c to 870c, a rise of some 70 per cent.

That 870c was put in place when the market price for wool was in free fall. It was not much over 1,000c at the time. So it was set in place at about 85 per cent of the market price-a price that was in free fall. It was done against a reversing exchange rate. It was done when China, Russia and eastern Europe were pulling out of the market. It was done when United States reaction to higher prices was starting to trickle through. It was done when there were some signs of a world downturn in the textile market overall. It was done when a massive oversupply was obviously developing.

All the ingredients were present for a market price that was headed not only downward, but considerably below the long term trend line. The elementary rules of charting would tell anyone that, and to this day I am at a loss to know how this was overlooked by the Corporation. There were, of course, people on the Corporation and on the Australian Council of Wool Exporters who were pressing for 1,000c a kilogram, but even at 870c it was defying gravity, it was doomed to failure, and the result was a rapidly increasing stockpile with massive amounts of borrowings to fund it.

Of course, when the floor was dropped by the Minister to 700c, it did improve the wool-synthetic-cotton ratio and, given enough time, that probably would have helped. Regrettably, it had only six months. It takes about 18 months for these things to flow through, as people would understand. Probably the last chance for it to work was in early January of this year.

Some of us were alarmed to hear an accusation made the other day by Don Booth, the President of the Australian Council of Wool Exporters, that when the buying by the Corporation had dropped into the high 20 per cent range the Wool Corporation, instead of dropping 7,000 to 10,000 bales on to the weekly market as it had been doing for the previous week, put 56,500 bales on to the market. In his opinion that blew the trade buying out. The following week I think it was 44, then 47 1/2 and then 60 per cent-if the figures he gave are correct. I think that is worth investigation. So today we have $2.8 billion of debt, there is to be no more lending without government guarantee, sales are suspended and the floor price is suspended.

One good thing that has come out of it, I suppose, is that quotas have been abolished. That is great news. I, like every other member with a wool growing electorate, have had numerous complaints about the inequities of quotas. Never in history have they worked. They are full of inequities. They have had no coalition support whatsoever. I for one have been surprised that the Wool Corporation went ahead spending growers' money, knowing that quotas could never see the light of day because we would not support them. Why the Corporation did that is quite beyond me.

Since the suspension some industry leaders are saying that the abolition or suspension of the reserve price scheme is going to throw growers into poverty, into chaos, and we will move back into the old days of boom and bust, poor prices and so on. I ask how this could be. I was alive when we did not have that scheme and, apart from the early 1970s, things did not seem to be going too badly. Logic tells me that there is something wrong with this statement when the same growers who are saying this send their beef, their lambs, their pigs and so on out to auction without a floor price and seem to get by. Also, the great wool properties of Australia and the great wool industry of this country were established over the last 150 years before this scheme came in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. If one looks at the table, the figures are quite revealing. The number of bales sold each year in the 17 years previous to the scheme is much more stable than for the 17 years that the scheme has been operating. The average number of bales that were sold in the 17 years previous to the scheme was 4.21 million a year, and for the 17 years this scheme has been operating the figure is also 4.21 million bales a year. So we have not sold any more wool as a result. If we convert the prices-and I have converted them to 1988-89 dollars-certainly in real terms there was more variation in the 17 years previous to the scheme, but the growers were getting a 46 per cent higher income.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise there are other things such as productivity, relative prices of other commodities, et cetera, to be taken into consideration. Nevertheless, growers were getting about 50 per cent more money in their hands than they were in the years that the scheme was operating. So I find it difficult to understand how things were so much worse before the scheme came into place. It has not been demonstrated to me factually yet.

Of course, in the first 15 years that the scheme ran it went pretty well. It did what it was supposed to do. It cost the growers about $100m a year to run it and made many of them feel much more secure. That was an average of about $1,500 to $2,000 for each of the 60,000-odd growers in this country. But today we find that the average grower owes the Corporation $48,000. This is, of course, offset by the marketplace value of the stockpile.

In recent times the AWC wanted to borrow another $1,000m, which would have blown out that grower debt to the AWC to $65,000 each on average. By a number of projections, had this been done the stockpile would have continued to grow to about 8.6m bales, with a debt of over $4,000m, a selling price of 700c and the grower getting 252c in the pocket.

In the short time remaining I would like briefly to cover a few other things that we need to do to get wool moving. First and foremost, I think the wool price mechanism needs flexibility. It has not had flexibility since the scheme has been in place. Cotton and synthetics, for most of their life, have been able to move up and down in tune with consumer needs and demand-in other words, the marketplace. Wool, unfortunately, has not been able to do that. When there is a downturn compared with other fibres, wool is put at a distinct disadvantage. In other words, it tends to be shut out of the marketplace during downturns.

Another concern I have is that I believe the operations of the International Wool Secretariat can be improved. Australia last year kicked in about $190m of the $260m budget-something in excess of 72 per cent. I believe this organisation needs revamping. It needs competition to get it moving. When I was in Hong Kong with the National Party China wool delegation we had a briefing by staff there, including top staff. Quite frankly I was not impressed with what they told us and the way in which they answered our questions. To be honest, I would not have fed half of them. I think a bit of competition injected into them would have done them the world of good.

The range of colours and designs of affordable woollen fabric is very limited today. If honourable members doubt that, they should ask any woman. There has been very little imagination with design and colour. Synthetics and cotton seem to be almost unlimited in that area. I think it is very regrettable that wool, a product very dear to my heart, is missing out. We seem to be losing out on so many things. Hospitals used to have woollen blankets but now they are all cotton blankets. Official sports gear in this country-tracksuits, et cetera-used to be made from wool; now they are cotton. A lot of mountaineering and camping gear used to be made from wool; now it is synthetic, and so on.

We all recognise wool's good points; it is soft, it breathes well, it is warm, it is hydroscopic and it has low flammability. We can be very proud of what we have developed in this country. We are improving on these qualities. It is time we recognised wool's bad points so that we can work on them. We have to recognise that it shrinks, it creases, it has a high cost, not only to buy but also to maintain. For example, we have to dry-clean instead of wash products, vis-a-vis synthetics. There are too few designs and colours, boring ones at that, which I have just mentioned. It is prickly close to the skin. It is hot, it stains readily, it has poor wearability-my wife can attest to that because she is always darning my woollen socks-and it is time that we concentrated more on some of these things.

I think the IWS has had too much concentration on the top end of the market. It has followed the west European cocktail circuit which it had to do, but it has neglected the middle range wools. A classic example of that was the Bicentennial fashion parade where these useless garments were paraded. It was a great night for the people who were there but there is not a woman in my electorate who would want to buy and wear one of those garments. There is a recognition that blends have been neglected. For example, if we blend wool we can get durability back into the wool and we have the best of both worlds.

I am concerned about the stockpile. We have a massive 4.8 million bales in stock-more than we usually sell in one year. It costs the grower, depending on what the interest rate is at the time, $5,000 to $10,000 a year to maintain that stockpile. Therefore, it is desirable to get rid of it as soon as possible. However, not wanting to flood the market, it is a fine balancing act. Even if we release it at, say, 2 per cent a month, it will take 4 1/2 years to get rid of it. Two per cent is 100,000 bales a month, which has a depressing effect on the market. We do have that problem.

The reserve price scheme has been a buffer stock scheme which I think has become outdated. It is inherently inefficient as a mechanism for spreading risk for growers. Much better would be a buffer fund scheme where one buys stocks in when prices would have dropped below the floor and one sells them when they rise above the floor. One has costs of physical storage and consumer delay in getting access. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a little graph demonstrating that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The buffer fund scheme overcomes all those difficulties. It is much more logical and less costly. Time is short, so I must finish. If the Government is fair dinkum, income equalisation deposits should be brought back and put in place so that each grower can do this type of thing to suit his own situation. Growers must become educated in future so that they can sell ahead to lock in prices and stabilise income if they want to. Therefore, we have a whole host of more efficient, less costly, more effective and more personalised options available to replace the comparative clumsy, costly and now somewhat outdated buffer stock scheme. It is tragic what has happened to the wool industry in this country over the last two or three years-tragic because growers ultimately will have to pay for that. Regrettably, it will take five years or more to work through these mistakes to get them out of the system. However, with the correct policies put in place we can restore again, I believe, wool to its rightful place as our premier export income earner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining this debate I would like to declare an interest as I am a wool grower. I would like to begin by talking briefly about the importance of the industry and then confine my remarks to two major areas because I think most of the other points I would like to raise have already been covered by my colleagues more than adequately. Those two areas I would like to talk about relate to some of the recent history of the reserve price scheme and, in particular, the role of the Government and the role of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and also some of the current proposals that have been put forward to try to get us out of the problem and some of the shortcomings. I then wish to highlight some of the very good points of the amendments that have been moved by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd).

SPEECH.PARA: As many honourable members have already pointed out, the wool industry has been the backbone of rural Australia virtually since European settlement. For well over 150 years it has been the most successful industry, it has been the largest industry and it most certainly has built this nation to what it is today. The fact that it has survived for well over 150 years shows not only its resilience but the innovation that has been available. The people who have been involved in wool growing for so many years have led the way for so long and have made a contribution to the growth of this nation second to none. I think that is something that the industry can be proud of. It is something that all honourable members should remind themselves of when so often we now talk about other industries and tend to overlook the massive contribution that is made by the rural industries and, in particular, the wool industry.

If we look back just over two years ago we find that the wool industry contributed nearly $6,000m to the export earnings of Australia. It was Australia's No. 1 export earning industry. More importantly-I think this is a point that honourable members should be reminded of from time to time-the wool industry, like most of our rural industries, is almost 100 per cent wholly Australian owned. That is a very important point. When we see the figures related to our export earnings, we see it being done by Australians. We are not talking about big land holders. By and large-as has been said many times-the average wool grower is not a big land holder and is not a big operator. There are in excess of 60,000 individual farmers who are contributing to making this industry so great.

Unfortunately, as has been well documented already, we are now in a crisis that probably could have been avoided, certainly it could have been very much lessened in its impact, had the Government not made some dreadful mistakes, mistakes that may have been compounded by others, but mistakes that ultimately must be seen as the responsibility of the Government, and particularly the Minister at the table. I pay tribute to the fact that the Minister has sat through this debate. I think it is something that some of his colleagues ought to learn from because too rare is the time when a Minister sits through a debate on a piece of legislation that he has introduced into this chamber.

If we start to go back to where the reserve price scheme went wrong, we can stop at the 1987 legislation, legislation that was introduced by this Minister, legislation that the Minister believed had finally got the industry to the position where he wanted it so that he could hand over the running of the industry to industry leaders. No doubt the Minister did this in good faith but the fact is that it has all gone horribly wrong and the ultimate responsibility has to lie with the Minister himself. Why did it go horribly wrong? It went horribly wrong basically because the Minister sat on his hands when he knew he should have been acting and when he knew he had the opportunity to do something about it.
It is interesting to note an article that the Minister wrote for the Stock &Land last week. When speaking about the fact that the reserve price scheme had been raised up to 870c, he said:

The only events that could have been foreseen were that the Reserve Price Scheme would be put under stress with a floating exchange rate, that a minimum reserve of 870c/kg would induce extra production, and the negative reaction of customers to the very high prices of 1987 and 1988. These factors were foreseen but ignored.

I emphasise that last point-`foreseen but ignored'. I would say to the Minister that he must have been the one who ignored them, because he is now trying to wash his hands of the fact that he allowed this disaster to develop and did nothing about it until the eleventh hour. To say that there were not warnings out, as some have tried to pretend, ignores the fact that there were some very clear warnings around.

In the brief time I have available, I just draw attention to one warning. That appeared in an article in the Weekend Australian at the end of May 1988. That article, written by Julian Cribb and entitled `The price that could floor the wool industry' set out with chilling foresight just what was going to happen if the wool industry adopted an 870c floor price. That, of course, was written prior to that fateful decision. As was said in the introduction:
The wool industry is poised to take a decision that could have a devastating impact on its future and on the national economy.

I emphasise that last point. The article went on to set out, chapter and verse, just what could happen. The Minister cannot deny that things were ignored, because he was one of the ones who ignored these warnings. He sat on his hands when the industry, under his new legislation in 1987, set in train some of the events that have led to the current crisis.

But the Minister has more to answer for than that. He is part of a government that has pursued macro-economic policies that have made very much more difficult the problems confronting the wool industry, wool growers, small business and people right throughout Australia-particularly those who are trying to get on in the export game. I am talking about the fact that for the last three years he has been party to the Government's deliberately running a high interest rate policy, a policy that has not only put up the costs of many people but also has led to a higher value of the Australian dollar than would otherwise have been the case. Again, that exacerbated the problems that the wool industry faced, because clearly it made our exports more expensive.

I would like to take the Minister up on another point-one that some of his colleagues have been keen to back up, including the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), when they talk about lack of information. We heard the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) talk about this too. The answer to that question should be: where was the Minister? We cannot just blame the Australian Wool Corporation or the Australian Wool Council-although I am critical of both, because I do not think they have kept the growers properly informed. The Minister, with his Department, has access to all the information and to what the Corporation was thinking. Yet he sat on his hands and did not tell the industry what was really happening until it was virtually too late.

Let us look at the Minister's behaviour in the latest round of amendments that he brought forward. After the floor price had been suspended, he came out with a big statement; but the statement is so vague about what he will do after the next few weeks that again it really does not give any direction to the industry. It is another case of saying, `I would like to help, but I am not too sure what I am doing'.

On 9 November, after having looked at the Corporation's plans, the Minister announced that he would agree to quotas. He said that he may not be impressed with them, but would go along with them if it was necessary. But, in his interview last Tuesday, when he announced his latest plans, he said, when asked about the question of quotas:
They would have been murderously difficult to introduce.

He must have known that back in November, yet he was prepared to go along with that plan and tell the industry that he was prepared to legislate for that. I think he has a lot to answer for on that, because we are looking at a pattern of indecision, a pattern of sitting on his hands and a pattern of coming in with too little too late. Of course, as has as been mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), the same thing has happened with income equalisation deposits-they have been brought in too late. In the press conference last Tuesday the Minister said:
The Cabinet will have to meet again to take decisions on the longer term.

How long does he need? He has the Department there. The Department has been giving him advice, no doubt for months, that he might have to be preparing some alternative plans. The Minister must have known about it; yet he says Cabinet will have to meet again.

What would those decisions involve? They would involve just about everything. In the longer term, we have to look at what we are going to do with promotion, research and development, and management of the stockpile. They are pretty critical decisions. The decisions also include what we are going to do with management of the debt and what is going to happen with the operations of the Australian Wool Corporation board. To top it all off, the Minister could not even make a decision whether to suspend the floor price indefinitely or allow it to be sneaking back on 1 July. He could not even give us an answer on that.

How will the buyers react with all that indecision? The buyers are already in a rage with Australia; they are already utterly disgusted with the behaviour of the Minister, who goes around the world giving an immutable, ironclad guarantee of 700c for the next 18 months. What happens? It is not the same as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) saying, `I cannot tell you that I am going to drop the exchange rate', because the Treasurer does not deliberately travel around the world making that statement and promoting it. This Minister went around the world and promoted it, but he knew in his own heart that it probably could not work.

What are we seeing? Indecision after indecision. Time is running out, but I could go on to talk about some of the other things that the Minister has done to the wool industry and of which he is not very proud-things such as the commitment he gave before the 1987 election about promotion. As soon as the election was over, he saw fit to break that commitment-not once, but twice.

The honourable member for Murray has outlined in some detail how the Opposition is determined to give a much clearer view about where we should be going with this industry so that growers and the buying trade know what the future of marketing is going to be. There is no doubt we are going to face some very difficult times and there is no doubt that many growers will suffer enormously-and not only the growers, but their families and, even sadder, in many cases their children. Today I heard a tragic story about a young boy in my electorate. These are the sorts of things that are coming out of this crisis. I cannot help thinking that, had the Minister not made such a terrible blunder in 1987, we may not have seen the terrible hurt that will now be seen in much of rural Australia. It is not just the wool growers-and, of course, the wheat growers, who are suffering similar problems for other reasons-but those who live in the country towns, those who service them and those who are working to try to make this country greater.

In conclusion, while the Minister may have operated in good faith, he has made a very grave mistake. He may have admitted it and may even feel lousy about it, but he is responsible. He may have meant well, he may have wanted the industry to run itself and he may have even put faith in its leaders, but under his own legislation he is responsible. In short, he and his Government have failed. There used to be a thing called the Westminster tradition. I do not know whether the Minister's Government believes in it nowadays, but it is something that I would have thought he would consider very seriously.
In conclusion, as my colleague the honourable member for Barker said last week:

One can hear Government members pouring out blame on everybody else but themselves. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am deeply disappointed by the action of the Government and others that has brought our great wool industry to its present parlous situation. I speak as one of the many who supported the retention of a floor price. I supported its retention right up till the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) announced that he would go back on his word and scrap the floor price. For the past 18 years-in fact, since 1973-the floor price has provided stability for the wool industry, and in particular has enabled growers to plan and budget for future seasons. Wool growers now face dramatically reduced incomes and a huge interest bill. On top of this, the Government is trying to saddle them with an open-ended supplementary payment scheme which could cost up to $1 billion in additional debt to the Australian Wool Corporation and therefore ultimately to the wool growers.

SPEECH.PARA: Already through the Australian Wool Corporation's borrowings Australia's 60,000 wool growers are in debt to the tune of approximately $42,000 each. An additional $1 billion debt will result in that indebtedness blowing out to $58,000 per wool grower-a figure I believe most wool growers would find untenable. For this reason, the National and Liberal parties have moved an amendment to limit wool growers' debt by ensuring that a blow-out in Corporation borrowings will not occur. The National and Liberal parties would like to see the additional Corporation's borrowings for the supplementary payment scheme limited to $200m and not permitted to blow-out to the suggested $700m proposed by the Government.

In addition, it is interesting to do some calculations which would be of significance to wool growers. If the floor price had been retained at 700c a kilogram clean and the proposed 35 per cent wool tax and a 70 per cent quota introduced for the 1991-92 selling season, a wool grower's cash flow would equate to approximately 319c a kilogram clean. If the wool tax was 40 per cent and the quota 60 per cent-figures suggested as being more realistic to fund the stockpile-a wool grower's cash flow would equate to approximately 250c a kilogram clean. This effectively means that, if 21-micron wool sells for any more than approximately 300c clean, wool growers will be better off in terms of their cash flow.

But, if the original legislation introduced by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who was then the Minister for Primary Industry, had been left in place and not amended in 1987, the wool industry would in all probability not face the problems it does today.

Wool is one of the few commodities in the world for which Australia can control or strongly influence the international market. The success of the scheme is reflected in the fact that during the scheme's 18-year history the Federal Government has never been called upon to honour any loans it has guaranteed for the maintenance of the floor price scheme. Yet in many areas, including the car and steel industries to name a couple, the cost to taxpayers has been millions of dollars in restructuring assistance and so on. However, in the hour of need of Australia's greatest agricultural industry, the Federal Government was only able to offer some $300m, even though it is an industry that has earned billions of dollars in export income. To be fair to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, I believe that he did try to have that amount increased but Cabinet was not amenable to his pleas.

Since this Government came to office in 1983, the wool industry has earned over $29.1 billion in export income, propping up the Federal Government's balance of payments deficit. As if the economy is not in a bad enough state now, just imagine what depth of recession or perhaps depression we would be in without our great wool industry.

The Minister has gone back on his word and announced the suspension of the reserve price scheme for the rest of the 1990-91 selling season. This is a decision we must now reluctantly accept because it appears that the retention of the scheme is no longer viable. As I am sure the House can appreciate, this decision has left growers in an extreme state of uncertainty, and this is typified in the electorate of Riverina-Darling. I know that most honourable members here would be aware that the Riverina and west Darling areas produce a great amount of the wool that is exported from Australia.

As the House would be aware, the majority of the wool stockpile consists of middle micron wool, or wool typical of that produced by wool growers in the Riverina and western New South Wales. It is these growers-the producers of 22 to 24 micron wool-who will be severely affected by the Federal Government's decision to suspend the floor price scheme.

Many of these producers in the Riverina and western New South Wales are in many ways worse off than others as they are geared up specifically for wool production and cannot easily move into the production of another commodity. They were not speculators. They did not move into wool to cash in on the boom. Many properties growing wool have been owned by the same family for two or more generations, and wool is their livelihood-not cattle, grains or any other agricultural commodity; just wool. Wool is all they produce, and that is why the decision being taken by this Parliament to suspend the floor price, even admitting that this result was inevitable, could have a devastating effect on many growers.

Many have borrowed money after lengthy consultation with their banks, and then they have run into high interest rates. They have done their figures based on the retention of the floor price, erred on the side of caution, and now find that due to the scrapping of the floor price they do not know where to turn. They do not know whether they will be able to meet their next interest repayments and, if they cannot, what action their bank will take. Will the bank increase its interest rates, placing them further in debt; will the bank defer their repayment; or will the bank sell their property? All these questions are going through their minds, and we cannot blame them for being extremely anxious about their future and that of their families.

In addition to the financial distress that will be suffered by wool growers and their families, those small businesses in country centres that rely on wool growers for their income will also be seriously affected. Already country businesses are noticing the effect of the rural crisis, and there will not be one village, town or city in my electorate that will not be adversely affected by the debacle in which the wool industry now finds itself.

When farmers are not spending, no-one is spending. That is the influence our rural communities have on our total economy. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) stated recently that the unemployment level today is the result of high interest rates 18 months ago. Imagine the effect this downturn is going to have on major metropolitan areas in the next 18 months to two years. I just ask the banks to be considerate and to show some compassion to those farmers and small business people who approach them because they are experiencing difficulties in meeting their debt repayments as a result of the wool crisis and the rural crisis in general.

Honourable members would be aware that the rural wealth producing system is presently in dire circumstances, and this has been highlighted by the visit this week to Canberra by the National Farmers Federation. We in the National Party have been bringing this message to Canberra for several years, but it is only now when the rural sector is actually in deep crisis with some farmers' positions being irretrievable that the Government appears to be taking some notice.

Since 1983 the farming sector has been under siege from the present Federal Government through rises in taxes and charges. One of the latest examples was the increase on 1 January of meat inspection charges to recoup 100 per cent of the cost of meat inspectors, which has added tremendously to costs in the rural sector, despite pre-election promises by the Minister that this would not happen. While this has been going on, there have been no reforms on the waterfront, in the transport sector or in industrial relations.

I cannot understand why this Government continues to attack and destroy the very sector, along with the mining industry, that has in the past and will in the future, if it does not succumb in today's crisis, keep Australia's economy afloat. On top of all this, we now find that the wheat industry is under siege from a trade war being waged by the United States of America and the European Community. So those farmers in my electorate who are both wheat and sheep producers, as distinct from the sole sheep producers in the west, still have nowhere to go.

One matter that constantly concerns me about the wool industry is that most of our wool leaves Australia in a large bale, returning in the form of high quality cloth. For a country that produces the best fine wool in the world, this situation is an absurdity. What is even more absurd is that, when our own wool re-enters Australia in the form of cloth, it attracts a 35 per cent tax. Only those wool fabrics lighter than 125 grams per square metre or more than 115 centimetres wide are exempt-in other words, blouse weight wool unsuitable for tailored trousers or suits. One of the major reasons why we are not a producer of fine woollen garments or cloth is that our cost for production is not competitive with that of our major competitors.

But the wool industry is only one example of where we are hogtied by our industrial relations system. Who in their right mind would invest in Australian manufacturing with our present penalty rates, holiday loading, lack of productivity and our rigid centralised industrial relations club reigning supreme? This situation is being highlighted as Australia experiences the worst recession, a recession we had to have, since World War II.

As I said before, the crisis in the wool industry is going to hit hard on top of the crisis already being experienced by rural Australia. In fact an indication of this is evident within my electorate where a number of families in isolated areas will not be able to afford to send their children to school. While up to the completion of the primary school stage children can be educated through distance education even though it may be difficult, the provision of secondary education will be almost impossible for some. It is important, then, that the rural adjustment scheme be upgraded and sufficient financial assistance be made available to assist those many farmers who will find themselves in financial trouble.

Also of great importance is the rural counselling scheme, which is already overworked in many rural areas. Rural counsellors have earned for themselves very high reputations for the quality of assistance they provide in advising and counselling those who find themselves experiencing economic difficulties and sometimes psychological trauma.

The Wool Council has asked that these amendments to the Wool Marketing Act be opposed in the Senate, but this would be an irresponsible action because it would prevent wool sales from starting for at least another three weeks and it would place at risk the $300m offered by the Government to assist with the supplementary payments. About 2.5 million bales are still to be sold before the end of June, and this amount has to be divided by the number of weeks left.

Restoring confidence in the wool industry is of paramount importance, and to reject this legislation would only hinder this objective. There is no doubt that, although the Government has had months to prepare a structure for the future of the wool industry, it has failed to do so. I am afraid that, despite the fact that there is great despair and uncertainty in the rural sector, the Government has once again let rural producers down. Unfortunately, we will in the not too distant future be back in this House once again debating this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill is possibly one of the saddest debates that I have ever heard in this Parliament because it brings home to us all the very real human cost that can befall the people of Australia due to the decisions made by members of this House and, in particular, by the current Government. The Government announced on Monday, 11 February the suspension of the minimum reserve price scheme for the rest of the 1990-91 wool selling season. It is the firm view of the Opposition that it is not just a case of suspension; it is time that the Government, the industry and the Australian people, who undoubtedly will be affected by these decisions, faced the fact that the system as we have known it since 1973 is now dead. SPEECH.PARA: Some of us in this House, and I would be one of them, can trace our relationship to the wool industry as far back as 1837-a long time ago. TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
