But in stark contrast on this occasion we are seeing before us the cost in real terms to the lives and the futures of all Australians, because our balance of trade and our balance of payments is so closely related to the survival of our rural industries.

SPEECH.PARA: For so long it was the belief of this nation that Australia was riding on the sheep's back. One thing is certain: the sheep is now on its own back and we are looking for somewhere else to lie. There is only one answer to that problem and it is simply this: we have to support the industry to the extent that we are competent to do so, because at this particular time the problems that it is currently facing have been largely due to the wrong decisions having been made in the past. It is very noticeable that in the second reading speech of the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) the Government actually had the honesty to say what those problems were. For example, we were told that the decision to suspend the operation of the reserve price scheme was inevitable. Certainly, as we have stated, the Opposition supports that view. The Minister stated:

It was no longer possible to permit the Australian Wool Corporation, on behalf of Australian wool growers, to go on purchasing greater and greater quantities of wool, levying higher and higher taxes, and incurring more and more debt to do so. The hope that consumer demand would recover and that the Corporation's stockpile and debt would be stabilised has not been realised. At a fixed minimum reserve price of 700c per kilogram, buyers of Australian wool have stayed out of the market.

The most important words perhaps are `have stayed out of the market'. If one reads the Minister's second reading speech and studies the events of the last few years, the Government's inability to make the right decisions at the right time becomes, sadly, starkly evident. One of those bad decisions, for example, was made when the minimum reserve price for wool was increased to over 800c by the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) between 1986-87, and by more than 70 per cent from 508c to 870c in 1988-89. I have yet to hear an adequate explanation as to why that decision was made at that particular time. It is a sad reflection on the industry perhaps that the beneficiaries at that time-namely, the wool producers-who were of course only too happy to have a high price for their wool, were never told what the long term dangers would be of taking an approach which was in the interests of the producer but which ignored the interests of the consumer.

Perhaps one of the greatest lessons we have to learn from this unfortunate imbroglio is that at the other end of the pipeline, some 18 months down the road, the mills of Europe, Japan, China and elsewhere have to buy our commodity and produce a finished good with it at a market price which they can afford. Therefore, it is not just a case of looking to the interests of the producer, but also those of the consumer-not in the sense of the final market consumer but the person who initially buys the raw product and makes something of it.

Nevertheless, the effect of the minimum reserve price did a lot to support and stabilise the industry in those early years. It was not ever designed, and should never have been used, as a mechanism for continually forcing up the price to artificial levels which ultimately could not be sustained by the industry as a whole.

However, on the other side, certain events took place, in 1990 in particular and even earlier, for which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has to take responsibility. In October 1990 the Minister was aware that the floor price was no longer sustainable. He established the Vines inquiry to look into the whole implications of the wool marketing and selling arrangements. We have heard all sorts of reports about people going around Europe with their loose talk, suggesting to the manufacturers what the impact of lower prices would be. We have the famous Campbell letter which was referred to in Question Time today and which has been referred to by speakers in this House tonight. I seek the leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the letter which the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) wrote to a newspaper in the town of Biella in Italy, which town has as one of its major industries the utilisation of Australian raw wool.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
January 19, 1991
Dear

As an ex woolgrower and the Federal Member of Parliament for the seat of Kalgoorlie, a seat that includes all the pastoral areas of Western Australia, I have an abiding interest in the wool industry. While Australia does not ride on the sheep's back to the same extent as it did up until the 1960's, wool is still an important major industry and certainly the most decentralised industry in an otherwise very urbanised society.

I am continually amazed at how ignorant the Australian wool growers, who produce the world's best fibre, are of the wool processing industry; and how little the European wool processors, who produce the world's best woollen material, know about the Australian Wool Industry. There is an excuse for the wool growers as they have been under the spell of the Wool Corporation who have been trying to turn the industry into a religion, where faith replaces reason, and blind loyalty is preferred to honest inquiry. There is no defence for the processors unless they too have become entranced by the corporation's mumbo jumbo.

There are two problems currently facing the industry, one is the present price and the other, a much more important one, is continual loss of markets. Even the blind or the drovers dog can understand that withholding Australian wool from the market when wool is easily substituted can only benefit other wool producing countries or lend to substitution by other fibres. Predictably this is exactly what has happened.

Moreover, it is surprising that the processing industry in Europe does not realise just how badly the Australian Wool Corporation has handled the industry and that the Reserve Price plan is doomed. Belatedly a majority of wool growers, in terms of volume of wool produced, now realise how badly the Australian Wool Corporation, Wool Council and the International Wool Secretariat have served them in recent years. These people are militantly keen to get rid of the present systems.

An illustration of the intellectual bankruptcy of the AWC and the Wool Council is the proposal to impose quotas on wool production. They cannot devise an equitable management scheme and it is doubtful if the government will provide the necessary legislation for its implementation. As a member of the government I will certainly vote against any quota proposal. Australia is poised for a complete reorganisation of its wool industry. It is just as much in Europe's interest as ours that we get it right.
Yours sincerely
GRAEME CAMPBELL MHR
Federal Member for Kalgoorlie

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Frankly, although the honourable member did make some sensible observations, he did say-and honourable members should not forget the date: 19 January of this year-that `the Reserve Price plan is doomed'. That letter was translated into Italian and appeared in the local newspapers. For the benefit of the House, I have a copy with me of the two Italian articles which refer to that particular situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply say to the House: is it any wonder that manufacturers were no longer buying Australian wool when they no longer had the confidence that the price which they were paying could be accurately reflected in the final price that they would obtain for their finished product? We all know-we have been told by the AWC for most of last year-that the pipeline was virtually empty and therefore the industry had to come back. We waited and waited but, apart from a short blip in the early stages of this financial year, the industry did not return to the wool markets of Australia. It did not do so because of that fundamental problem of lack of confidence in our marketing situation.

Therefore, one of the proposals which the Opposition strongly supports in this context is the handling of the stockpile. While, on the one hand, we are now proceeding towards an open market system for the sale of wool on a regular rotational basis, on the other hand, we are still facing the problem of massive over-production in the past which is reflected in the existing stockpile. We are firmly of the view that unless that stockpile can be gradually allowed onto the market on a regular basis, underwritten by regulations approved by this Parliament, there is no prospect that the overseas consumers of our wool will be prepared to trust the market because they will say-and with some justification-`While you talk about a free market for wool, on the one hand, in fact you have the capacity to influence the supply to that market because you have the massive overhang of the wool stockpile'. For all of those reasons, therefore, the Opposition will be moving a range of amendments to this legislation which will strengthen the capacity of the industry to survive and overcome what is indisputably probably the greatest threat to its survival this century.

The discipline of the marketplace is therefore of fundamental importance. It is important to Australian growers, to our balance of trade and to the survival of this great industry. Above all, the way in which the Government handles this situation will to a large degree determine whether Australian rural people will ever trust the Australian Labor Party again.

Firstly, the Opposition exposed the failure on 8 May 1990 of the Soviet Union to pay its debts to the Australian wool industry. Opposition representatives had meetings with officials from the Soviet Embassy. The Opposition called on Government members such as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) to intervene to try to get the Soviets to meet those payments. They finally began to react many months after our original calls.

In May the Opposition called for changes to the insurance scheme for wool exporters to the Soviet Union, and at the time the Government ridiculed that call. Later the Opposition proposed a range of credit arrangements and counter-trade, which the Opposition believed would help redevelop demand for Australian wool in the Soviet Union. Admittedly the Government finally adopted policies similar to those the Opposition had been calling for well before the Government acted. However, if only the Government had acted in time it would have done something to stimulate demand for wool in the Soviet Union. The Government stands condemned for sitting on its hands and doing so little when the Opposition was calling for so much to be done.

Secondly, both the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia separately led delegations to China. Those delegations covered a range of issues but in particular they concentrated upon ways of encouraging the Chinese back into the wool market. It is worth reflecting that we were again ridiculed by the Government for going to China, yet when we got there we had the opportunity to speak with Ministers, officials, Chinese technicians, representatives of Chinese woollen mills and the like. They were initiatives that we took well in advance of the Government and they were ridiculed by the Government, but ultimately the Government realised that it would have to follow suit.

The Opposition did a great deal to try to encourage the Chinese and the Soviets to return to the market. It is a matter of deep regret that the Government responded in such an adverse, party political way to many of the suggestions we made. I only hope the Government will not react in such an adverse and party political way to the suggestions we have made today to try to help contribute to resolving the wheat subsidy problems in relation to the United States.

The supply side of the story of the wool industry has always been enormously important. It should always be remembered that one must get the supply and demand curves to meet somewhere. If one wanted to maintain the 700c floor price, one had to reduce supply as well. We proposed a slaughter scheme, recognising that something like 45 million sheep would have to be slaughtered if the supply and demand curves were going to meet at 700c.

The result was that there was virtually no action at all on the part of the Government and, for that matter, the Wool Corporation. Yes, they introduced a scheme, but a scheme which politely could only be described as a `wet scheme'. They added to that the system of quotas which, as other speakers have pointed out, was absolutely riddled with anomalies and, in the case of my own State of South Australia, quotas which were particularly discriminatory and particularly harsh. At least they have now gone.

In conclusion, we have to ask ourselves: what should we do now? How can we encourage confidence to return to the market? The Government has interim measures; the issue is still not resolved. The Government has had a long time to resolve this issue and it keeps introducing interim schemes. Now is the time to finalise the issue and the Government should do that, first of all, by terminating altogether the reserve price scheme. It should freeze the stockpile for 12 months and dispose of it subsequently according to a legislated timetable so that the international marketplace knows exactly how much wool from the stockpile is going to come onto the market at any given time. If we do not do that, we will end up with chaos. As far as the debt of the Corporation and the growers is concerned, the Government apparently wants to blow that out by between $700m and $1 billion. We will only support increases in borrowings of $200m, otherwise the debts will just destroy the growers for all time.

Finally, my colleagues and I do not oppose this Bill because we do not want to jeopardise the $300m from the Government in supplementary payments to those growers who will be selling their wool between now and the end of the season. I come back to where I began. In the 10 minutes that I have had, I guess the point above all that I have endeavoured to get across here is that there is enormous pain, enormous sorrow and enormous anguish in rural Australia, including my own electorate. I have been very struck by the tears, the concerns and the worries of so many wool growers in my electorate. So many of these problems have been caused by the macro-economic policies of this Government; its short-sightedness; and its decisions to make politically expedient judgments, rather than judgments in the long term interests of the industry, and for that it stands roundly condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The economic earthquake which has hit the wool industry with the collapse of the reserve floor price scheme has not just affected wool producers themselves. It has reverberated throughout the entire economy. It has struck most directly at the confidence of the entire spectrum of rural industries, and it has struck those primary industries at a time when their future in the wider context of Australia's economy has never seemed so perilous. The Parliament must not forget that in dealing with the profound issue-the fate of the Australian wool industry-it is dealing with an entire sector of the economy, and it is dealing with a community which has had its livelihood virtually torn out from under it.

SPEECH.PARA: The shock waves will impact throughout all of regional and rural Australia. Overall spending emanating from the rural sector will fall $5 billion. Some $1.2 billion of this will be taken out of the regional towns. The small businesses which service the rural sector will be threatened, as primary producers themselves are, by the deepening of the rural crisis. It will also spill over into the supply network, from farm machinery to fertiliser companies, which draw their economic life from the rural sector.

This Government has always seen the primary industries as playing nothing more than an annoying and subsidiary role to its preoccupation with the so-called mainstream industries. In the matter of the management of Government policy applying to the wool industry, this is more than patently obvious. The policy approach to wool has been characterised by sheer carelessness. The fact that the industry is now driven to embrace a drastic and radical solution to its problems is largely a legacy of the chaos which has been at the heart of the Government's rural policy process.

We know, for instance, that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) recognised the dire plight of Australia's wool producers as early as last October. We know that since then he has not struck a policy direction. It is no wonder that the floor price scheme cracked wide open. It is no wonder that growers are left picking up the pieces of an industry shattered by the collapse in confidence of international buyers.

For its part, the coalition has stuck hard and fast to a 700c floor price. It sought an effective stock reduction program which would have seen the supply problems affecting the industry become more manageable. It wanted to give the industry every conceivable chance to hold its own in the marketplace. It wanted to give growers and producers the chance to keep their mastery over their own economic destinies. In difficult times, this was a difficult course of action, but not in itself an impossible one. Prevarication on the part of the Minister and policy uncertainty struck at the credibility of the scheme and, in the context of the range of other supply and demand problems facing the industry, credibility was a key issue.

The nature of the management of the crisis was such that others directly connected with the industry have also been financially savaged by the suspension of the reserve price scheme. The various State based private treaty wool merchants have been appallingly hurt by the policy turnarounds of recent days. Many of these private treaty wool merchants carry huge inventories, relatively speaking. Though reeling from losses under the earlier floor price reduction of last year-the 870c to 700c reduction-they, like everyone else in the industry, read the Minister's assurances that all was well with the current floor price. Now the asset values of these inventories have been slashed. Moreover, these private wool traders face very substantial losses.

I call upon the Minister to clarify the status of the private buyers and just where, if at all, they fit within the operation of the supplementary payments scheme. There is a great deal of uncertainty in the minds of private treaty merchants at present. I have private buyers, located at Leongatha, Yarram and Bairnsdale in my electorate, who are extremely concerned about their economic future. Indeed, I spent Saturday morning last with the Leongatha buyers who have been in the business for many, many years-Ansell Biggs and now his son Ross-and I am very worried having had a look in their shed at the huge stockpile which they, being very small business people, have now to carry.

The shake-out which now faces the wool industry is utterly unparalleled. It will come to represent a massive forced restructuring of an entire industry sector. The coalition now has little choice but to side with the course of action which ensures the long term viability of the industry in its changed economic context. While the reserve price scheme in different circumstances might have had a continuing and important role in industry marketing measures, it is now an ineffective instrument for defending producer interest. To go on accumulating debt, expanding quotas and increasing levies would have laid the industry to waste. Wool producers must now face the future as best they can.

The Australian Wool Corporation itself now accepts that objectivity and the best road for the wool industry to take under the circumstances is the open market. On its own reckoning, the Wool Corporation has determined that the quickest road back to stability for the wool industry is by dismantling the minimum price scheme as it has previously operated. The Vines committee might well find some half-way house, a scheme tailored closely to market realities as they have emerged, but the orderly marketing scheme as it functioned in the past has been crippled. It is a profoundly regrettable course of action. It will cause immense suffering. But now there is no choice.

Difficult as it is to admit, the real problems for the wool industry are only just beginning. Those growers who are yet to sell at auction over the remainder of the 1990-91 season will find some measure of assistance by way of the deficiencies payment scheme, $300m of which will be met from the Commonwealth funding. But the burden of the industry's supply problem will not be easily evaded.

Growers will remain responsible for the $2.8 billion or 4.8 million bale stockpile and the corresponding debt management strategies arising from interest repayments-$450m a year-and storage costs. They will have to meet the additional deficiency repayments which break beyond the $300m mark. In the context of the extension of the industry's borrowing limits, we can anticipate that this scheme may blow out to $1 billion. What that amount would finally be is impossible to determine, and that in itself is a grave source of concern to the industry.

The consequences for wool growers will be enormous. Struggling to meet debt repayments on a huge stockpile, in addition to the burden of a further $700m in loans to cover the deficiency payment scheme, growers cannot be expected to cope. Three-quarters of Australia's farmers are already carrying debt. Twenty per cent of total gross income for 1990-91 is spent on interest repayments. How many growers can be expected to pull through as the debt burden gets even heavier? Assuming that the wool industry exercises its expanded borrowing rights, levies and debt servicing will remain a part of the wool sector's life for years to come. On this basis, I warn the House that this is only the first of many occasions to come upon which it will be forced to return to debate this issue.

The crisis in the wool industry and its consequences will be felt well beyond this single day and well after this particular debate has concluded. To be frank, I do not see a way out of it at this time. The easy avenue would appear to be for the industry to obtain an enhanced efficiency payout under the supplementary payments scheme, but this might total $1 billion. On this basis, the industry would be receiving from the Commonwealth and from the taxpayers of Australia a $700m liability because taxpayers would be providing a guarantee. It totals $1 billion, being a $300m cash transfer and a $700m borrowing guarantee.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would appreciate that the cash transfer will not buy equity of any kind. It will simply be a cash payment of such a magnitude that, should the $700m be called upon in the future, will tie the hands of future governments for years to come in respect of their broader fiscal strategies. In essence, it would set future governments back years in addressing key economic issues.

Despite their central role in the economy-especially the precarious small export sectors-the agricultural industries have come to feel themselves strangers in their own land. For the present Government, agriculture is a symbol of the past and nothing else. In its worst financial moments, at its deepest point of economic malaise, the wool industry alone is still a multi-billion dollar industry which overshadows all the other hype that the Government can muster about the so-called Australian manufacturing sector.

The Government is fixated with appeasing its metropolitan constituency, fixated by its industrial unionised political base. The Government has only ever considered farming and farmers as peripheral concerns. Look at the Government's preoccupation with the manufacturing sector and its concentration on protection levels propping up the automotive industries and the like. Here the Government is pumping its resources into an economic sector pump primed by tariff and other protection and soon to be injected with another shot of economic steroids come 12 March. Here it is unable to impose a comprehensive economic plan on an automotive industry which has sucked enormous funds from domestic consumers for decades.

The Government has always looked upon rural Australia as an alien constituency. If it were more than this, if there were some genuine commitment which recognised the objective economic significance of the agricultural industries-wheat and cereal grains, wool, dairying, citrus and beef-then there might have been some concerted effort to improve their cost structures; that is, there might have been a drive to reduce that array of added cost which clings to the industry and threatens to strangle its long term viability.

The agricultural industries have suffered decline in terms of trade-that is, the ratio of input costs to the value of production-which have ballooned out in the past seven years. On every other conceivable economic indicator, the rural sector has been hit harder than any other area of economic activity. Its asset values have collapsed.

I draw to a conclusion because of the time limits imposed upon all of us. There is so much to be said with regard to the problems surrounding the great wool industry. There is obviously no quick solution to the problems. The wool industry has had to operate in a highly uneconomic environment. The settings are all wrong. The problems are not so much with the wool producers as with what happens off the farm-the cost of capital, interest rates, transport and handling, cost of fuel and problems with the waterfront. This Government has been sidestepping the real problems for far too long and the longer it delays deep reform the more the next generation will inherit a profoundly inefficient economy.

What has happened to the wool industry? All sorts of circumstances have brought it to its knees, but those problems have been accentuated by a highly inefficient and poorly structured and administered economy. Wool producers today face a very uncertain and, for many of them, grim future. Whatever decisions this Parliament makes, not all wool producers will be saved-and that is a matter of the utmost responsibility and concern for this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what I understand to be the very few moments left available for this debate, I want to touch on what I see as important issues. At the outset I would like to acknowledge that, as is the case with unemployment and bankruptcies, the ugly statistics inherent in the current wool dilemma ultimately translate into personal hardship and misery for real human beings out there.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, Australia's wool growers and their families are feeling an immense amount of pain, and are likely to feel more. Many are understandably emotional. As I have spoken to wool growers over the telephone in recent days, and out in the field in the electorate over the last few weeks, I have been very conscious of a wide range of emotions-confusion, anger, frustration, fear-and perhaps above all else uncertainty about the future, much of which, I might say, stems from the fact that there has been an appalling lack of information flowing to growers from their industry chiefs.

All of these emotions are understandable as, in common with wheat growers and so many others across our beleaguered nation, these people are deeply worried, not only about their future, but about their children's futures as well. So we need to keep in mind when we are debating issues in this somewhat isolated and insulated chamber in this somewhat isolated and insulated city that we are talking about issues that impact massively on the lives of a very substantial group of Australians out there. We have a responsibility to do everything we can for them not only to ease their short term pain but also to ensure their long term viability, not only for their sakes but for the sake of communities as well.

As someone who has sought to support the floor price and the selling mechanisms favoured by the industry, I think the first thing to place on the record again tonight is that the scheme, as we have seen it operating, is not the scheme introduced in 1972. The original scheme sought to avoid `undue fluctuation or irregularity'-in the words of the Wool Marketing Act-in prices which were to be at levels appropriate to the comparative position of wool in world markets.

Furthermore, the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) was to make fortnightly reports to the Minister and to the Treasurer in relation to the reserve prices determined by the Corporation, wool purchased and held by the Corporation and sales reports. At the same time the Minister could, on behalf of the Government of the Commonwealth, give a direction in writing to the Corporation with respect to the operation of the reserve price scheme of the Corporation, and the Corporation was obliged to comply with any such direction.

The Wool Marketing Act 1987 not only effectively altered those modest, anti-potholing objectives of the original scheme, but also massively restricted the power of the Minister to direct the AWC, including the power to set the level of the reserve, to the point where the Minister really only retained the power of veto. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) was surely right to refer to this as perhaps his worst mistake. It was a tragic mistake.

That having been done-on the basis, presumably, that wool industry leaders had matured to the point where they could be allowed greater autonomy-those leaders went on and pushed the reserve price up about 70 per cent in two years, in defiance of all sound economic reasoning and, as I understand it, against all conventional wisdom in relation to charting practice.

What needs to be understood is that this stupidity was to cost not only traditional wool growers dearly-and I feel especially sorry for those people-but also those who are not traditionally wool growers. That is to say, many people, seeing what appeared to be not only a high but also a guaranteed reserve for wool, moved into wool production in the face of uncertainty and doubt in other farm sectors, particularly the grain industry. Both groups now face a dreadful prospect, and of course a broader rural community will as well as the impact flows on to small businesses and shopkeepers and so forth in small towns. No better example of the disguising of market signals could be found than this one, and ultimately-as is so often the case in these instances-the people most hurt are the ones we wanted to help in the first place.

In the very short time that is available to me-since I would only be rehashing ground that has already been well covered tonight if I spoke about the legislation before us-I wish to consider some positives and the need, as I would see it, to develop a more aggressive, outward looking approach to the future for wool. Without hope there is no future, and the industry must now seek to do all that it can to build a future for itself. Right throughout this unhappy episode it seems to me we have failed to look adequately at the need to get wool out into the marketplace, or into the pipeline-in the terminology that has been used so much. In other words, we have failed to shift more of the product.

I would suggest for a start that new leadership is desperately needed, and needed now. Firm control and positive direction are needed-the sort of direction that can achieve, broadly, the following objectives. Firstly, there is a need to protect the production base-that is to say, the 70,000 wool growers in this country-by keeping the wool tax and other impositions as low as possible, which is yet another reason, I would suggest, for keeping a strict cap on the borrowings for funding of supplementary payments.

Secondly, there is a need to carefully allocate adequate research and marketing funding to develop new products, perhaps with new brand names, and to sell them effectively. Thirdly, there is a need to work very hard at establishing genuinely strong and effective levels of value adding in Australia. Herein lies a story of escaped responsibility-the failure of this Government to bring about the reforms needed to restrain costs and to deliver genuine productivity and efficiency improvements in the labour market.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said before that by far this is the most difficult and important decision I have ever made for Australia's farm industries. There has been a lot of talk about what my mistake was. My mistake certainly was to give the power to set the minimum reserve price to the Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool Council of Australia. When this was debated in 1987 there was no opposition about giving industries their own way. I just looked up some of the debate. Leading for the Opposition at that time the then honourable member for Gwydir praised the Bill very much. He said:
The Bill aims to place the Corporation on a sound commercial footing.

He had some concerns about my setting up a statutory selection committee. He said that the industry was quite capable of choosing its own people. The only objection the honourable member for Gwydir had at that time was that he did not like my putting in place some equal employment opportunity bits and pieces.
The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), still the present member, was even more adulatory. In contrast to what he said today, he then said:

The Australian Wool Corporation is a success and there are simple reasons for that. From the beginning it was a very enlightened statutory authority. It is not one that has worked on the old arrangement of being totally subservient to government. This legislation gives it substantially more independence and autonomy.

. . . the Corporation to date deserves the congratulations of this Parliament for the wonderful job they have done. It is now quite sensible and proper that the apron strings should be untied for the Australian Wool Corporation because it has been a success.
The then honourable member for Ryan said:

We also welcome the way in which the Government has backed away from intrusion in the industry . . . This is a contribution to the deregulation of government corporations and a contribution to an industry which is very highly regarded throughout Australia . . .
The then honourable member for Maranoa was also very supportive and said that I was not going far enough in getting the Government out of the industry. We all learn with hindsight.

My mistake was in believing that this was an industry that could take mature long term commercial decisions. My mistake was in trying to get the Government out of the industry and not to exert paternalism or patronage. My mistake was in believing that the concepts of a corporate board, commercial flexibility and accountability would be comprehended by the Wool Council of Australia. The Wool Council of Australia and the Australian Wool Corporation's mistake was to lift the minimum reserve price by 71 per cent over two years.

I have qualified my comments on several occasions. We would have had the same problems, or some problems, even if the reserve price had been held at 508c. The board of the Wool Corporation under Mr Hugh Beggs has to understand, and has understood, that in its dealings with government it is not negotiating with government on behalf of growers but exercising its best judgment as a statutory marketing authority of the Commonwealth Government. But anyhow, we all learn.

I now refer to people who have spoken in this debate. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) called for my resignation. If I resigned at this point it would be rather silly. The most important thing is to fix it up. People have been all over the shop on this issue. A majority has said that we should have acted more quickly. There are other people who say we not should have done it at all, that is, remove the reserve price scheme. The contrasts were the honourable member for O'Connor and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair).

We all know that the first principles in buffer stock schemes in commerce in general are that markets set the price and that buffer stock schemes always fail. If we control price without controlling supply we are bound to get substitution. What we have been doing in the wool industry for a long time is similar to what has been done in Europe with the common agricultural policy and what the United States did in the early 1980s with wheat.

To the `go fast to wipe it out, 1 July 1990 brigade' I simply say that the decision has been no easier now qualitatively; it is just as difficult a decision. Quantitatively, it would have been better to have taken the decision then. Politically, I believe it would have been impossible to wipe out a scheme that has survived for 17 years last July. There is real depth to the view of the status quo.

I think the person with the most experience and knowledge here, the right honourable member for New England, full well remembers the heated debate in the 1960s and the early 1970s when the government of the day acted against the industry because of the situation in which they were placed. I think there was a deficiency payments scheme, the price had slumped to 29c a pound and they made it up to 36c.

What we face after these 17 years where it has worked has been an unique set of circumstances. The Wool Council of Australia is still dead set opposed to the Government's action. It basically believes it runs the Australian Wool Corporation. I think it would be fair to say that the majority of members on the Australian Wool Corporation board are still opposed to the Government's action, though they did resolve in terms of the fact that I could not guarantee I could get quota legislation through the Parliament nor could we continue to go on and on.

In the position in which I am placed, I understand full well that the Government does not control the Senate. The legislation that we put through on dairying was delayed for a year. There are matters relating to fisheries and sugar that get blocked in the Senate. I know full well that unless there is a fair degree of industry acceptance out there, no government has a chance of getting really rapid and radical change. I can do arithmetic; I have been very well aware of the arithmetic. I set up Sir William Vines, a man of enormous status in his industry, to look at the longer term because I knew that this industry had long term problems.

In terms of the go-faster brigade, it was worth trying to hold the price. I did not go to 600c on 1 July last year, particularly because of the situation with the European buyers. It was worth a go. We asked the Corporation to give us a business plan and then a strategic plan. But the market went very bad through August and September with the collapse of communism in eastern Europe and all the things that were happening in the Soviet Union through that period. We introduced legislation. I went on an overseas mission and offered the roll-over credit facility to the Soviet Union. I think all that was worth a go. I was trying to demonstrate that if the reserve price scheme had to go, by then it would be obvious and accepted by many-certainly by the Wool Council and the Australian Wool Corporation.

Some people say that we need to wrap it all up now. I simply say that the reserve price scheme is the centrepiece to the institutional framework of this industry. We would be absolutely stupid to scuttle the institutions of this industry now. To the `never remove the reserve price scheme' brigade I would say this: we tried everything to hold the reserve price scheme. We started off a bit over a year ago with a 4 per cent wool levy to pay for the reserve price scheme. Then it was 10 per cent and then 15 per cent. We legislated for it to be 20 per cent and the Council and the Corporation fixed it at 18. Then we moved to 25 per cent and now the proposal is 35 per cent with an upper limit of 50 per cent. So it has gone from 4 to possibly 35 per cent. No-one can accuse us of not trying to stick to it.

The word `immutable' comes up. I was in exactly the same position as the Treasurer (Mr Keating), with a fixed exchange rate that simply has to hold the line until it is impossible to hold it any longer. Some things in all this terrible, tragic mess could have been foreseen-that once we floated the currency, the reserve price scheme was going to have to be fundamentally changed. I do not have a clear knowledge, but I know that work was done in the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and that this was put before the board.

We could foresee the response to the high prices through 1988 in terms of customer demand and, of course, we could foresee that 870c would give us larger supply. It is also certain that some of the research and development funds could have been better applied to market analysis and the reserve price scheme itself and that work could have been better integrated on the International Wool Secretariat. But we could not anticipate the collapse of communism in eastern Europe; we could not anticipate what has happened in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and is still unfolding today; nor the way that China moved to free up the economy and then to put the checks back on. The warm northern winters, changes in the structure of the world textile industries, more latterly the invasion of Kuwait, and now recessions in the United Kingdom and the United States were obviously caused by the Australian Treasurer!

But at some time we had to change course. The Australian Wool Corporation deferred sales. There was a view around that once we started heading for five or six million bales and a $3 billion to $4 billion debt, we really had to start thinking again. By January the business plan was shot to pieces. Quite frankly, I met with the Wool Corporation on 21 January, we thought there were sufficient funds available to get through to March and April-that is, sufficient up to $3 billion. We were prepared to go further; as honourable members know, the $3 billion was uncapped. But, once we started the 55 per cent buy-in rate, in about the third week of January, once we were getting well away from the business plan that required only a 28 per cent buy-in rate, we had to do a fundamental reassessment. It was not March or April; it was virtually the next week, on 24 January.

There was very legitimate opposition to quotas. I will stand by the words. They would have been murderously difficult to introduce and it would have been just as bloody as the scheme we are trying to put in place now on supplementary payments. All I am saying is that at some time we had to change. If we do not sell 45 to 50 per cent of product two years in a row, and still have the second-biggest year's production on record on our hands, if we are going for $4 billion plus borrowings, which is close to one year's average revenue, and heading for six to eight million bales in stock five years out-that is, heading for over one to 1 1/2 years production, and this after five years levy at 35 per cent-at some time we have to change. The figures and the various projections show that a 600 kilograms quota at 35 per cent tax is 314c; yet we are selling at 700c. For 700 million kilograms at 35 per cent tax, people are really getting about 341c gross, and still selling at 700c. They are thus encouraging fibre substitution and encouraging the world to move away from wool.

We all know what the previous Government in New Zealand had to do with its meat industry plan: it had to put in $1 billion to bail the industry out. All of this was a question of judgment, a question of balance. It was an extremely difficult decision. My first experience with the wool industry was through 1971-72, when I was on sheep properties throughout Australia on the objective measurement project. I know full well what they went through in the years leading up to that time.

I want to reflect on some of the contributions of honourable members. Everyone has put a lot of work into this. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the Deputy Leader of the National Party, said that this was hastily drawn up. Yes, we had about a week to act. Officials worked night and day, for the reasons I have just explained. We had to get the proposal through Cabinet. There was no sense in bringing it in any earlier than last Thursday, because the Opposition had to have some chance to assess what the Government was proposing. I think the legislation is fine, and the Government will be opposing the amendments, but we had to act very quickly. That is why we have not got all the measures in place now that we have taken the decisions we have. The members of the Government are not the experts. I have half of the wool division with me in the House tonight, so those opposite should not think they will suddenly go down and run the Wool Corporation, as the honourable member for O'Connor thinks.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party is quite right about all the reasons for the collapse, about Sir William Vines allegedly putting forward propositions of 500c-which he denies-the allegations about the letter by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), the sales by the Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics submission to the Vines inquiry and Madam Davletova's cancelled trip. But really what was causing this skittishness was the size of the stockpile and people doing their sums about whether the industry, and eventually the Government, the taxpayers, could carry this debt. That was the problem.

I could answer many points made by previous speakers. The politics of the wool industry are quite profound. I understand that. This is probably the most powerful, oldest established and most sophisticated industry. As I have said already, there is lot of depth in the view that the reserve price scheme be kept; I do not think the Government could have moved any more quickly and I think we had to stay with this scheme as long as we could.

The honourable member for O'Connor says that we have to take over and put in a receiver. Who the heck do we put in when we have a core of people there who know how to do things? There has been a lot of editorial comment about that-the absurd unreality of the Government stepping in and just taking over next Monday. The reason why the Government did not take over the stockpile-quite apart from 2.8 billion reasons-is that, if the Government hangs onto the stockpile and then starts putting it on the market, the allegation would be immediate that we would be taking the market down.

I would think 70 to 80 per cent of graziers in Australia are opposed to this legislation; the Wool Council of Australia, of course, is still writing in and I am getting a lot of cards and letters. The Wool Corporation has announced tonight, quite precisely, what is happening to the stockpile. That will require me to issue guidelines later this week under the Wool Marketing Act as amended. I will be doing this. These are quite tough stock disposal rules. What will have to be put in place before the start of the next season is an arrangement whereby the stockpiles treatment can be transparent. There needs to be some flexibility, but it needs to be very predictable. We will arrive at that position when we move for more legislation during April and May in this House.

By the start of sales, hopefully next Monday, we will need to have rules and guidelines on how a supplementary payment scheme will work. Of course, that is an enormous amount of work to be done indeed. My officials and the Australian Wool Corporation are working through that.

The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) talked about value adding. All I can say is that Senator Button and I have done three reports on this matter. It is an old chestnut and the honourable member should read those reports because it is not all that easy.

The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) commented on the question of the reserve price scheme (RPS) providing stability. Yes, but since the float of the dollar, one cannot have stability of price in overseas countries and Australian currency at the same time. We now have a chance for ultimate stability with the treatment of that stockpile itself. Right now we are working on how long it is held for, how the debt is rescheduled and whether we put the paper out into longer borrowings or roll it over more quickly.

I will not tolerate too much criticism of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. All the estimates are based on assumptions at the time. ABARE, and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics before it, basically got this a lot more right than a lot of people in the industry.

The honourable member for Maranoa also raised the question of a full time or part time chairman. I have always been of the view that the Australian Wheat Board and the Australian Wool Corporation should have a full time chairman but it all depends on the role of the managing director and whether the board is prepared to act corporately or sees itself as a servant of wool growers only. I think it is very important that we understand the relationship between a chairman and a managing director. I will not go any further into that.

The honourable member for Maranoa-I am giving him a bit of time because he knows a lot about it-raised this question about immutability. No-one will believe my word on other commodities. Wool was the only commodity where we tried to set the prices. It is the only commodity where we are pricemakers in any sense. For the rest we are really pricetakers on world markets.

The honourable member for Maranoa commented on the stockpile and freezing, and referred to the New Zealand situation and its stockpile. There is only about a 5 per cent to 10 per cent coincidence with New Zealand wool and ours. Most of it is Romney and about 35 micron and up. I have only a nitpicking comment with the honourable member for Kalgoorlie.

I thought the honourable member for Barker was basically right on everything he said, including his comments on the income equalisation deposits (IED) scheme. I think it would have been best to have had a non-rortable or slightly rortable IED scheme. However, the honourable member for Barker's major criticism was really to try to get a better supplementary payment scheme. All I can say is that the alternative is nearly impossible. We put more dollars in, put the levy up or get less for the grower. As I said, we are still working out the guidelines and we will certainly have those together by next Monday. However, if we have a cap on this money, it implies we will have to wait until 30 June to get a full accounting and then it would have to be distributed. Some people might accept that but I think it would be very difficult indeed.

Like everyone else, I have run out of time. I am sure we could all talk for hours on this industry. It is Australia's greatest primary industry and it is a very sad day but in the end I hope this will be shown to be a very necessary day. (Extension of time granted) I am overcome, Mr Deputy Speaker. This has never happened to me before.

The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) raised the question of early shearing and double presentation of wool. As a result of events leading up to 30 June last year, we have a natural hedge against that. A lot of wool was shorn early then. By specifying a range of types and by putting in possible severe penalties, which is the reason for another item in the legislation which the Opposition is seeking to amend, we might be able to obviate all those problems.

The honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) gave a very good and detailed history of this. He said that the supplementary payment scheme is a de facto reserve price scheme. I have to say no, that it is really about intraseasonal equity and also equity within these past four or five months. There have been a very large proportion of fine wool clips-and big ones at that-while from Queensland there are some very big clips of quite coarse wool. It is intraseasonal within the past four months if one looks at the composition of the clips themselves. The honourable member for Corangamite says they will have to come back in June. We will be back in April-May.

The right honourable member for New England said that I had looked at the arithmetic in excess and then gave his own arithmetic-and I am not saying that in any sort of smart alec way. As I said earlier, he fully understands the depth of and the concerns in this debate and its long history. I do take the view that the exchange rate has particularly exacerbated the problem for export industries. To my mind, the exchange rate in Australia is not related enough to the current account deficit and demand for foreign exchange. Too much emphasis is placed on asset values and speculation in the Australian economy.

He said that there was a 60 per cent tariff on cool wool material. We did decrease the 35 per cent tariff to zero per cent on 125 grams per square metre cloth and below, but for over 125 grams per square metre the tariff rate is 35 per cent for wool and cotton and 40 per cent for synthetic. In the upcoming industry statement, perhaps we can look at that again. He said that we ought to stimulate sales. As with the last component of Sir William Gunn's plans, we can in any case do that whatever scheme we put in place.

As to contracts and wool importers, I do not think we will have the situation we had with the 20 per cent drop where people could calculate exactly what the drop was going to be. With a free market, in the next week or two we are going to see a great movement away from the excessive prices of the reserve price scheme to wool being priced on the basis of demand. We will probably see the value of some types of wool go up and the value of other types go down.

I think people will be able to get over contracts being held or simply shuffled along a bit in a free market a lot more easily than they would be able to get over a discrete drop. We all know that people will try to weasel out of their contracts, but I think the trade should understand that this industry was facing bankruptcy whichever way we went, and that was not in its long term interests. There should be a big attempt made to hold on to those contracts and to stretch them out. It is quite possible to do that.

The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) said that I should put in an administrator, and replace the Wool Corporation or free it from the Wool Council of Australia. Again I simply say I would not have the legal power to do all of those things even if I wanted to. I need to preserve the institutions and the structure, and the reserve price scheme is the centrepiece of the institutions. We would create absolute chaos if we did not go for a two-staged approach.

The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) says that the industry has been starved of information. I really do not know what the situation is. Some people think that there is too much information around. All the time I hear of people who do not even know the name of the Chairman of the Wool Corporation. The honourable member for Parkes said that the trend price should be about 580c. I have been assuming that it is about 650c. We could have an academic debate about that. The reality is that 650c, and certainly 700c, is not a market clearing price, and we would still have to go into debt if we took the price down to even 650c or 500c. I could comment on a lot of other things. I think I have already covered the points of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew).

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the private treaty merchants?

—I will just finish with a comment on the private treaty merchants. The legislation is written so that the supplementary payments will be available to wool producers. Section 140 mentions supplementary payments to wool producers. These payments will be available whether the wool is sold through the auction system or through the private treaty system. There should be no disadvantage to the private treaty merchants vis-a-vis the brokers. There will be a necessity for a test certificate and a few other regulatory items. This has already been discussed by the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that we will be able to get around the private treaty merchant problem, except for where wool has been bought before the sales were deferred. We are still working on guidelines in consultation with the private treaty merchants and other elements in the industry. Unless we have every `i' dotted and every `t' crossed, I do not think there is much sense in me speculating about how we are working through those problems.
That is all I would like to say at this time. I thank honourable members for giving me additional time. This is a terribly important debate. Again I thank those honourable members who have spoken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not intend to take anything like the time allocated-just two or three minutes-because a great deal has been said in this debate about the tragic situation now confronting the wool farming industry and I do not intend to mention those details.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Saturday I was at the Oberon district show and was able to speak to many farmers, all of whom spoke gloomily about the crisis. Many of them were going home this week to engage in slaughtering activities in regard to some of their own flock. I want to assure them that I will be doing all I can to ease the burden that many of them and their families will face. I want to take a totally different line for just two minutes and give to them a poem that came into my hands some time ago called `Optimism'. As I have said, there has been a lot of gloom and doom spoken about this crisis, but I want to put this poem called `Optimism' on the record and over the airwaves to give a bit of encouragement to those farmers and their families- their wives, children and grandparents -who are facing great problems. It reads:
Two frogs fell into a deep cream bowl,
One was an optimistic soul;
But the other took a gloomy view,
`We shall drown,' he cried without more ado.
So with a last despairing cry,
He flung up his legs, and he said `Goodbye!'
In other words, the problems he was confronted with were so severe that he thought that as he was going to drown he might as well drown straight away. So he did. The poem continues:
Said the other frog with a merry grin,
`I can't get out, but I won't give in,
I'll just swim around till my strength is spent,
Then will I die the more content'.
Bravely he swam till it would seem
His struggles began to churn the cream!
On top of the butter at last he stopped,
And out of the bowl he gaily hopped!
What is the moral? This is easily found:
If you can't hop out, keep swimming around!

That illustrates one of the things we ought to be concentrating on from this point onwards. I pray that we as a nation and as individuals will from this point take ourselves by the scruff of the neck and the seat of the pants and, rather than dwell on all the negative criticisms that we have heard today, determine to do something positive to help our farmers through this crisis. I pray that we spread the word about how important it is for us, the people who have, and the farmers who are able to make ends meet in the communities to look for the farmers who are having difficulties. All of us should come to the aid of our farming commun-ity right now and help as much as we can.

Finally, I want to mention the final speech of Sir Winston Churchill when he was speaking to his old school. It was probably the occasion of the final testimonial that was given to him. In response he staggered up with his walking stick and said to the great gathering of staff and boys, `Never give up. Never give up. Never give up. Never give up'. Then he sat down, which is what I will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will also be very short because most of the things I intended to say have been said. This is a very sad day for the Australian wool industry and the thousands of individual producers and the communities that depend on them. The failure of the reserve price scheme was not the result of its concept-a concept to give growers a role in the marketing of their own product, to provide some form of equity between growers and to provide stability in the processing and textile industries. The failure is by now well documented: a set of circumstances that even in hindsight many of us would have had difficulty in avoiding.

SPEECH.PARA: The general economic downturn, particularly the withdrawal of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) and China from the market, effectively removed 19 per cent of that market. The impact of the Gulf war was the final act in the disastrous world economic scene. The mismanagement of our domestic economy by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) saw our export industries incur a domestic cost structure of record high sustained interest rates and high inflation for the second time in the last eight years. I make the point that most of the problems in Australian industry-whether they be in primary or secondary industry-have had their inception in the interest rate regime. It is a tragedy to read today that in the primary sector farm incomes are expected to drop some 70 per cent. As I have said, this is the second time in about eight years that we have had to face this disastrous situation-a situation that in 1983-84 saw a massive exodus of people from the land, particularly our highly skilled and highly educated young people. This devastated our rural communities and is still causing them enormous stress.

I am concerned that we are seeing tonight the beginning of the destruction of a culture of farming in this country. We are talking about wool, but over the last few weeks in this Parliament we have talked about the citrus industry, the wheat industry and the manufacturing industry-and on Thursday night we will be discussing a dried fruits Bill. The dried fruits industry is very important to my electorate and I believe that piece of legislation will move that industry slightly towards the trend we have been discussing tonight, where we will see 100 years of the operation of a very efficient industry under very difficult circumstances disadvantaged by legislation that will upset a very disciplined and highly controlled marketing system.

It is very easy in retrospect to establish blame or point to our errors of administration. Such an exercise serves little purpose except as a lesson for the future-and most of us know that the only value of a study of history is so we can make the same mistakes again. But a review of the past few months raises a number of issues which are worthy of reflection. I put them very briefly on the record. In 1987 the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) decided to remove legislative checks and balances from the operation of the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) and reduce his own level of direct responsibility.

The raising of the floor price to 870c gave it a market-setting function rather than a support mechanism. As I have already mentioned, we have seen an unprecedented set of factors in eastern Europe, the USSR and China. The floor price was reduced from 870c to 700c, despite the Minister's promise not to lower it for two years, and, understandably, breaking that promise failed to restore market confidence and in fact promoted further speculation. The activities of the Vines committee have been mentioned, as has been the suspension of sales by the AWC which, in itself, provided a clear indication that the Corporation was bankrupt and could not continue buying in. Finally, of course, there was the realisation that the proposed increased levies and quotas would not be sustainable and would create inequities between growers.

Throughout the last few months the coalition has fully backed the floor price, recognising that continued public comment would only exacerbate the situation and that ultimately the AWC and the Government had the legislative and administrative responsibilities. I am concerned that the announced changes which we are seeing here will leave growers without any clear outlook for the future and will leave the trade in limbo after the existing selling season.

I conclude my remarks at this point, but obviously we are discussing important legislation tonight and over the next few weeks members of this Parliament will be trying to restore confidence in Australia's wool industry as quickly as possible. Confidence today will be the key to the industry's future and I believe that the coalition's amendments, which will be moved shortly by my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), will allow wool sales to commence next week with as much certainty about the future as is possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleague the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), I will not take up much time. I probably have as much time as the wool industry has at the moment. The wool industry does not want platitudes; it wants a few answers. I suppose that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) will be judged in due course, and he knows that as well as I do. The Minister says that he believes that the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill is terribly important, and it is not for me to judge whether he thinks that is right and whether he is genuine in that belief. He will be judged at some later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at how important this matter is to the other side. Let us run through the members of the Australian Labor Party who have spoken on this-to quote the Minister-`terribly important issue'. I refer to the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), who I doubt has ever seen a sheep, and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who I am sure has seen lots of them. That is the extent of the terrible concern over the state of the wool industry that we have seen from the Labor side of the House. That will be reflected further down when the ultimate judgment is made on how this Government has handled the wool industry. Labor members will be judged in due course and will be judged very harshly.

During Question Time this afternoon a question was asked by the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) as to what happened with the Vines committee of inquiry into wool marketing prior to Christmas and whether there had been discussions about a possible 500c reserve price. If I am incorrect no doubt the Minister will correct me, but my clear recollection of what happened this afternoon was that the Minister did not deny that that may have happened. But a short time ago he said that there had been a denial. Somebody has been on the telephone, having realised the precarious position in which that answer left the Government as to what the Vines committee potentially would do to this industry.

The Minister said that he had only a week in which to act. If he had been told what the Vines committee was saying, he would have had plenty of time to act on this legislation. The reality is that what has been proposed by the Government will destroy the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC), there is no doubt about that. It will not be able to service this massive debt. What the industry is looking for and what it is now getting is some leadership. The Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), has put up a proposal that will save the AWC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who will save them?

—Despite what the honourable member for Kalgoorlie says, the AWC will be the long term saviour of the wool industry. It knows very well that it has made significant mistakes over the past 10 months, and I am not here to cover up for it. It well knows that it should have given the woolgrowers a far better insight into what was happening. We told them, and the Deputy Leader of the National Party said that the Wool Corporation was not telling the growers. But that is now history, and let us get on with some answers.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, the cap that is proposed by the Opposition is a sensible approach. I gather that many woolgrowers have been listening to this debate. I assure them that we are supporting the figure of $300m. I have had 10 phone calls tonight and only one caller out of 10 realised that we were supporting that, and an extra $200m extension of borrowing. I hope the message is now clear that that is what we are supporting. It will put some people who will be selling between now and the end of June in a difficult position. That gives me no joy, and it will give no joy to the Deputy Leader of the National Party or to the Minister, but it is a fact of life, regrettably, that that will happen.

There are a number of ways in which this matter can be approached. An interim payment initially after sale, with a final dividend, is one way to approach the matter. Obviously it must be worked out in the very near future. That would appear to me to be a sensible approach. We must get this industry back on its feet again. We must stop what has happened overseas in the last 12 months. There is total loss of confidence in the industry and I know that the Minister agrees. We must start restoring that confidence. Regrettably, the reserve price scheme is finished, let no-one have any doubt about that. Therefore, we must pick up the pieces and approach this on a sensible, rational basis. The Government's proposal will destroy the AWC because the AWC will not be able to support this debt. The coalition's proposals will save the AWC and the industry and in due course we will get recognition for the amount of work that has been done, for the input of the coalition and the fact that we have got the answers to this very serious national problem. It is not a country problem or a rural problem. It is a national problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise one or two issues at the close of this debate. It is typical of this Government to raise expectations and then fail to deliver. We have again seen this done in this area. Only a few months ago we had an iron clad guarantee that we would have a floor price for two years. I think everybody can remember the iron clad guarantee given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that the wool industry could be certain of its future. The floor price was set at 700c. Off the Minister went around the world to tell many of our wool buyers that that was the case. But like in so many other areas, this Government raises expectations but does not deliver. So it was the case with the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sad reflection on this Government that we can think back to so many instances of its failure to deliver, whether it be child poverty or capital gains. The same can be said about this year's Budget surplus which was going to be $8 billion; we are now told it will be less than $4 billion; and it will probably be down to zero. The Government raises expectations but it cannot deliver.

I would like to pick up on what the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) was saying. This Government's attitude to the rural sector in Australia is typified by this debate. Only four government members have come into this House to debate and show any concern for what the Minister says is a vital industry for this country. Only four members of the Government have been prepared to come in to the House and debate this issue. That tells the Australian public how much the Australian Labor Party is really concerned about people in rural towns and cities, about our balance of trade problems and about a vital industry. But one thing is certain about this debate-and that is that rural Australia faces a crisis which will flow through and affect most other people in the community.
