SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, page 2, line 23, proposed subsection 141 (2), omit ``(whatever the source of that money)'', substitute ``(whatever the source of that money, but amounts payable from so much of that money as is attributable to payments to the Corporation under paragraphs 47 (1) (a) and (d) are not to exceed in the aggregate $200,000,000)''.
(2) Clause 4, page 3, lines 21 to 24, omit proposed section 146, substitute the following section:
Disposing of wool stocks
`` `146. While guidelines are in force under section 144:

(a) for a period of 12 months beginning on the commencement of this Part, the Corporation must not sell, charge or otherwise dispose of its stocks of wool or wool products except in very limited circumstances as prescribed by regulation; and

(b) in any period after that described in paragraph (a), the Corporation shall only sell, charge or otherwise dispose of its stocks of wool or wool products in a publicised, orderly and predictable manner, as prescribed in a subsequent enactment.''.
(3) Clause 4, page 4, line 36, omit proposed paragraph 148 (2) (b).

The reason for moving the first amendment relates to the supplementary payments scheme. I want to make it very clear again that we support that scheme in principle, and we support the Government's contribution of $300m to that scheme. Our concern is that there is no limit on what the wool growers themselves may be required to pay for that scheme. Guesstimates of up to $700m and beyond have been made of the amount that would be added to the already great debt of $2.9 billion confronting wool growers.

We are looking at a potential debt to growers of over $3.5 billion, and an annual interest payment of about $600m. That could mean that 20 per cent of wool growers' income, already dramatically reduced, could be required to meet those interest payments. That is just not a viable situation for wool growers. It is not, and I believe the Minister knows that. There will be an annual brawl between the industry and the government of the day as to who should pay that interest bill.

In a genuine, constructive desire to limit that debt this amendment has been moved to put a cap of $500m on the total scheme. There has been some criticism by the Wool Council of Australia that we are not providing, by this amendment, reasonable equity to those 35 to 40 per cent of growers who are still to sell their wool this year. That is not the intention at all. In fact, the Government, through the guidelines that it is releasing for the supplementary payments scheme, will itself be attempting to limit the cost of that scheme by a different method-a very messy and complicated method-which will also mean that growers will not be receiving the full equity at the 700c level.

The method we are suggesting is very clean and open. More importantly, it sends a signal to growers to apply some discipline themselves in providing their own reserves so that their wool is not given away followed by a blow-out in cost. Hopefully, it sends signal to buyers as well that they will not be able to pick up wool almost at no cost, that a market is established and that there is a recognition of the greater problem to the wool growers. That greater problem, beyond the immediate problem of reasonable equity to growers who are still to sell their wool this season, is that massive debt which is there, and will be there for some years while the stockpile remains. That is the reason for that amendment. I believe, and the coalition believes, that it is possible, through a reasonable market operation with those disciplines in place, to provide equity with that $500m cap.

The second amendment concerns the disposal of wool stocks. Honourable members will note that in that amendment we are requiring that the procedures for the management of the stockpile be as much as possible by legislation rather than by regulation, and that they be for a period of 12 months beginning at the commencement of the sales hopefully next week.

A complete understanding of stockpile management is an important part of restoring confidence in the industry and providing a market for it. The size of the stockpile overhangs the market and threatens a reasonable price for potential buyers, especially if there is any uncertainty on the management of the stockpile. That is what our amendment is about.

The Minister indicated that later this week he will issue guidelines for the management of the stockpile until the end of June. Why can he not enshrine those guidelines in legislation for a period of 12 months? The Minister has foreshadowed further announcements beyond the end of June. However, those buyers who will return to that market when it reopens will be looking not only at the situation between now and the end of June but also beyond the end of June.

The AWC must perform a delicate balancing act: on the one hand it must ensure a clearance of what is still an excessive production of wool in this country unless there are new market opportunities with the free market and, on the other hand, the Corporation will have to reduce that stockpile in an orderly way so that the wool growers' massive debt is reduced.

Initially it is important to establish confidence and security in the new market. To do that there should be a freeze on the stockpile for 12 months with limited provision for sales to certain categories for either contractual purposes or special requirements. Beyond that 12-month period further legislation will be required so there is clear security and confidence in the market.

Our final amendment concerns the regulation making power of the Minister. The Minister has conceded that the legislation is hastily drafted. The Minister already has the usual regulatory powers in section 148, which are the standard powers given to him in this type of legislation. In addition, the Minister wants special power to amend `any provisions of this Act other than this part'.

The third amendment seeks to delete that particular clause because it makes a mockery of the legislation. It basically gives the Minister power by regulation to overrule any other part of the legislation. The Minister says he needs that power because penalties may have to be provided for those who abuse the scheme. If that is the case, let us have that provision in the legislation. If the Minister believes he needs something then let us have it up front in the legislation, as I said when dealing with the stockpile. The Committee should not just give the Minister these powers to act as he likes.

I commend those three constructive amendments to the Committee. We believe that they will improve the overall operation of the Bill to the benefit of wool growers at this very difficult time. I foreshadow a division on this matter to demonstrate our feelings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government shares the Opposition's motive but not its support for these amendments. The motive is how to get the maximum amount of money for growers in the free market between now and 30 June by encouraging people to put on a reserve rather than just taking any price. The problem that both the Government and the Opposition face is that we are dealing with, and making estimates on, some sort of static situation. The reality is that we cannot guess the free market price or how much wool will be sold in the months and years ahead. The equation is a net return from the status quo balanced up against the rest of this year to get intraseasonal equity versus the net returns of the free market to 30 June. After 30 June, the situation will be different.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a limit to what can be put into legislation if the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) is to be a flexible commercial organisation. I do not know what amendments, if any, will come back from the Senate but we are really dealing with a situation where, as I said, there is not an enormous amount that we should be putting inflexibly into legislation.

By and large, I believe that far from helping wool growers, these amendments put the effects of the suspension right back on those growers who happen to be selling between now and the end of June because those growers would not get supplementary benefits under this proposal until July, at the earliest. They would get a lesser payment than currently proposed.

A great number of back of the envelope costings for this scheme have been getting a lot of currency lately. A proper costing takes account of the types of wool coming forward until June, the likely market response to those types, the provisions of the wool tax legislation, tax receipts and cash flows-the type of complications that really do not get taken into account on the back of an envelope. When these complications get taken into account, the picture is quite a bit different.

This particular amendment is put up in order to respond to some of those back of the envelope calculations. We do estimate, after careful work, that the cost of supplementing growers receiving a 375c floor price equivalent is $677m. That amount is estimated to cover the difference between what the grower is paid and what he would receive in hand under a reserve price of 700c. This amendment would only allow supplementation above a 527c floor price.

The amendment achieves nothing but disruption. It means either less money for the growers, a higher levy, other legislation or more money from the Government. I really think that it is very difficult and hopefully, before this is run in the Senate, I may be able to convince the Opposition of this.

On the guidelines for the stockpile management, the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), is now aware that the arrangements for handling the stockpile between now and 30 June have been announced this evening. I am quite sure that he, like me, will want further clarification; but at this stage they are suitably clear and straightforward and the guidelines will be gazetted on Friday next, assuming that we continue to have the Opposition's kind cooperation in passing this legislation.

I have already announced that the guidelines to apply next year will be announced as part of the Government's response to the report of the Vines committee of inquiry into wool marketing and as part of the package of measures dealing with the AWC's debt position. Again, I understand the Opposition's desire to have these guidelines to allow for an orderly, public and predictable disposal of the stockpile; however, too much order and predictability would allow the AWC's position to be speculated against, and the complex task of drawing up the guidelines will be done after proper investigation of the stockholdings.

As to the Opposition's third amendment, this subsection allows for regulations to amend the Act. I accept that this sort of thing is usually regarded as bad law. This provision is temporary and ceases to exist on the proclamation of the cessation of the supplementary payments scheme and the cessation or suspension of the minimum reserve price. I do acknowledge that it is an unusual form of drafting. However, I am advised that it is perfectly constitutional and lawful. It would only be used after careful consideration and, if it is of any value to the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, I hereby undertake to consult him on its use should I ever contemplate using it. The maximum penalty under this Bill is $2,000. We may need to move if we find some anomaly or something that has not been anticipated in this very new situation. As I said at the outset, I accept the Opposition's motives, but the Government cannot accept the amendments.
Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Lloyd's) be agreed to.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the prescribed minimum value per head of sheep, used for valuing natural increase and calculating taxable income, create a taxable income for the producer which will never be realised.
(2) Will he reduce the prescribed minimum value per head of sheep from $4 to a level which would reflect current market conditions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Taxpayers owning livestock may adopt either of two methods of valuing livestock: cost price or market selling value. Under the cost price method, livestock is valued at the cost incurred in purchasing or producing the livestock. In the case of livestock created by natural increase, it is recognised that there are difficulties in determining the appropriate cost price. For this reason, minimum values are prescribed as an estimate of the cost of natural increase. It is important to note that these values do not relate to the market selling value of the livestock.

If a taxpayer using the cost price method of valuation sells livestock at a price lower than cost price, then the taxpayer will incur a loss in the year of sale which will be deductible for tax purposes. Where a taxpayer has chosen to use the cost price method of valuing livestock, this is an appropriate outcome. It is also worth noting that where a taxpayer using the cost price method sells livestock at a profit, then that profit will not be recognised until the year of sale. This is a recognised feature of the cost price method of valuation; it defers the recognition of both gains and losses in the value of livestock until sale. If taxpayers wish to gain immediate recognition of losses on production, then they can use the market selling value method of valuing livestock. This method, of course, also immediately recognises gains.
(2) A change in market conditions does not necessarily mean that the cost of production of natural increase of sheep has fallen. There is therefore no basis to change the minimum prescribed values.

Moreover taxpayers can elect to bring the natural increase of livestock to account at the actual cost of production if this is less than the prescribed minimum value for that class of livestock. This should alleviate the problems faced by any taxpayer whose cost of production of natural increase is lower than the prescribed minimum value.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the Auditor-General's report on his Department's AIDS grants which reveals serious breaches of Government guidelines and funding management deficiencies including payments being made before approved commencement dates, payments being made without conditions being met, inadequate monitoring of funded projects and shortcomings in reporting and acquittal proceedings.
(2) What sum did the breaches referred to in part (1) cost.
(3) What action will be taken (a) against those persons responsible for the breaches and (b) to prevent these breaches happening in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, my attention has been drawn to the Auditor-General's report. Criticisms in the report relate to funds management aspects of some of the 1988-89 Community Education Grants and Commonwealth AIDS Research Grants (CARG) and Commonwealth AIDS Prevention and Education Grants (CAPE). Funds provided for these grants represent approximately 13% of the Department's total program outlays in the fight against AIDS of $42 million and $61 million in 1988-89 and 1989-90 respectively.

(2) Following standard audit practice, a sample of the above grants to the value of $3.1 million were examined. Deficiencies where a cost to the Commonwealth were identified related to early payments of some grants representing a cost to the Commonwealth in forgone interest. The Auditor-General's report does not identify which grants were paid early and it is therefore not possible to identify the size of the potential cost to the Commonwealth.

(3) (a) As there was no suggestion of wrong-doing on the part of persons administering these programs, no action has been taken against those persons. It should be noted that administration of these grants involves dealing with community groups, individuals and organisations who do not always have the required skills or understanding to comply with strict `legal' Government guidelines and conditions.

(b) The Audit Office was advised prior to commencement of the audit that computerised monitoring systems were being implemented to rectify problems identified by departmental officers. This was noted in the Auditor-General's report. These systems are now operational and monitor all aspects of grants administration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 5 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he taken any steps to inform non-English speaking pensioners about the new charges for prescription drugs under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 21 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the justification for continued preferential tariff levels for Singapore under the designation of a developing country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The rationale for the Australian System of Tariff Preferences (ASTP) is to assist developing countries compete against the products of developed countries on the Australian market. The current ASTP came into effect on 1 July 1986 following a comprehensive review of the former scheme. In undertaking the review, the Government was conscious of the effect of developing country preference margins on Australian industry. It also took into account the concerns of developing countries in relation to predictability and coverage of preferences under the arrangements then in place.

As a carefully balanced compromise, the current scheme provides universal product coverage, a uniform five percentage point preference margin and no product or country exclusion provisions. Some 130 developing countries are eligible to participate in the scheme. Singapore is still recognised internationally as a developing country.
